story:
No one likes to be asked for money.
Throughout my twenty years producing theatre, I've always found it  tremendously embarrassing to ask for help, preferring to pay for it out of my own pocket before putting my hand out.
No one likes to ask for money.
No actor (technician, designer or director) in storefront theatre is comfortable talking about the lack of compensation. No gas money. Part-time hours. Donated labor. Meagre profits that go into paying rent and utilities. The amount of money spent on each production never recovered...unless you have underwriting.
The end result is that theatre is not a profitable business without patronage and most shows end in the red. Even larger spaces that seat hundreds have gala fundraisers to help them pay the bills.

    What We Need

    I'm guest directing at The Garage Theatre in Long Beach.
    Plain and simple, my goal is to take my cast of ten and make sure that they receive compensation for the US Premiere productions of Scottish playwright Linda McLean's WHAT LOVE IS and THE UNCERTAINTY FILES.  (Some of the money will also supplement stipends that the production has already received for its technical staff.)
    I will not be taking a penny from your contributions.

    • I'm asking only for $3000.00. That's it. All of the money will go to actors, technicians and designers.

    What You'll Get In Return

    • I'll set aside the best seats in the theatre, personally chosen by me. 
    • For $500 or more, I'lI provide you and your friends with a personal talk-back after the show, with me and the cast.
    • I'll put an ad for your business in our program.
    • I'll provide you with necessary tax write-off paperwork from The Garage Theatre.
    • I'll give you my undying gratitude.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't donate, but wish to show your support:

    • Please share this link with others and tell them why you support what we're doing.
    • Come see the show, opening May 20.

 Other Ways You Can Help If you can't donate, but wish to show your support:  Please share this link with others and tell them why you support what we're doing.
 Come see the show, opening May 20.

story:
Short Summary

Award winning author, Liane Moonraven is the Creator, Writer and Executive Producer of the Carmen Online Theater Group, the world's first Black female-owned Audio Horror Theater Group. Each week, Liane shares her own real, true and private ghost stories which are the events that inspired her to write the audio theater horror series,"The Burbs." 

With a coveted 2016 HEAR Now Audio Theater Festival submission under her belt, less than six months after the launch of the Carmen Online Theater Group, Liane is among only a few Black women horror authors & voice actors who are creating this kind of unique audio (and overall sensory) content and experience in the audio theater industry. 

We are soliciting funds to assist Liane with hiring additional highly talented and diverse actors (character voices) and to cover production costs (mix/mastering/sound design).

The exciting debut of Liane's Ghost Stories, Season Four  of her highly popular audio horror series, "The Burbs" as well as other "stand alone" audio theater projects are currently in production.


Please support this talented artist in her efforts to create new productions and new  opportunities for other talented actors, writers, and producers in the horror genre in her pursuit in creating a complete audio horror theater network.

story:
Who?


Hello! We are Fluff Productions, an all-female theatre company dedicated to producing innovative and exciting new writing with all-female casts and predominantly female production teams. We have staged a number of hugely successful runs in London and Edinburgh, as well as regional tours, all receiving rave reviews.

What?


This year we are heading up to The Edinburgh Fringe Festival with 'Agent of Influence: The Secret Life of Pamela More' by Sarah Sigal and directed by Jessica Beck, which will be performed at The Underbelly from August 4-28.

The piece is a solo show performed by Fluff Productions’ own Rebecca Dunn. We have a fantastic creative team on board including Alberta Jones (illustration and set design) Phil Hewitt (sound and lighting design) Katharina Reinthaller (assistant director) and Carla Almeida (associate producer).

Why?


The character of Pamela More first came into existence in Sarah's play 'World Enough and Time', which was produced by Fluff and performed at Park Theatre in 2014. Pamela represented one strand of the play which followed three stories about women in British history across three eras. Pamela's character and story were overwhelmingly popular with reviewers and audience members. The Stage commented:

“my favourite section was the comic tour de force of Rebecca Dunn as Pamela, whose candid observations and juicy bon mots deserve a spin-off show of her own”  

With this in mind, Sarah, Becca and Jessica set about developing Pamela's story into a one-woman show.

The Play!

Agent of Influence: The Secret Life of Pamela More

‘Mid-calf, navy blue day dress with pearl buttons by Victor Stiebel. Dove-grey tweed jacket and fox stole by House of Hartnell. Hat by Elsa Schiaparelli. Perfect for luncheons, jaunts around town and spying on fascists.’

Lady Pamela, fashion columnist and socialite, is recruited by MI5 to keep notes on Wallis Simpson and Edward VIII, suspected to be colluding with the German Embassy. But Pamela suddenly realises that what began as an adventure has led to a deadly struggle for power in a world in the shadow of war.

Where you come in...

As many of you will know putting on any production is a costly business, particularly for The Edinburgh Fringe, so any support that you can offer, large or small will be fundamental in getting us up there and giving the play the best exposure possible.

We are looking to raise £5000 through this crowdfunding campaign which will make up approximately 50% of our entire budget.

This money will go towards:

  • Theatre hire

  • Rehearsal space hire

  • Accommodation for cast and crew

  • a design budget for the show

  • press and marketing

  • Travel costs

  • Fees for performer and creative team

  • ....and much more....

We have a number of exciting perks if you choose to donate, from social media shout outs, to signed photos, to tea with Lady Pamela herself!

The serious bit!

Agent of Influence: The Secret Life of Pamela More is a comedic piece, but it also explores the 1930s, a period in history which we feel is extremely relevant to the political climate today. We hope to utilise this piece of theatre to develop conversations about Britain and the future of Europe.

Spread the word!

We completely understand that some of you will not be able to offer us any financial support, but there are plenty of other ways you can support us! Firstly by sharing this page far and wide with all your family and friends to spread the word.

And please follow Lady Pamela on Twitter and Instagram @UndercoverPam and give us a shout out if you see the show.

Thank you all so so much for all your continued support. Lady Pammy is eternally grateful.

story:
Short Summary

My first stage play, CLEAVE, is invited to participate in the Grace Infused Theatre Festival in Columbus, Ohio on July 11th. Director Owen Robertson has graciously offered to bring a merry band of actors all the way from Florida to perform. We are launching this campaign to help cover the cost of travel for our group. 

CLEAVE is an ironic drama in which the pregnant wife of a self-proclaimed prophet gives birth to her child on the day the world is predicted to end.

This opportunity means a lot to me personally. Participants of the festival will receive a "Gilbert Award," named after my late friend and mentor, Jack Gilbert, whom I worked with at Act One. I am honored and humbled to take part in representing what is just a tiny portion of Jack's legacy.
https://graceinfusedtheatre.wordpress.com/2015-grace-infused-theatre-festival/honoring-jack/

After the festival, plans are underway to mount the show in Tampa, Florida with the same cast. That means your contributions will potentially go toward the development of not one, but SEVERAL performances. It is our hope that your contributions today will help plant the seeds for CLEAVE to flourish for years to come.

What We Need 

Your contribution will go towards defraying the cost of travel for the director, actors, and playwright, including:
  • Transportation to Ohio
  • Housing and meals

If we surpass our goal, any additional funds will go to pay the actors an honorarium. It is our sincere desire to honor their time and commitment to the project. 


Other Ways You Can Help

No dinero? No problemo. Here's some other ways you can help:

  • Share and tweet this campaign to your groovy cohorts.
  • If you live near Columbus, come out and see CLEAVE in person!

story:
Help Walden Shakespeare make this "Dream" a reality!


Help us kick off our inaugural season at NARA Park Amphitheater with A Midsummer Night's Dream!! We have an incredible space, a fantastic cast and are ready to launch this company and provide FREE outdoor theatre at NARA Park. Cast includes actors from Sleep No More, The American Repertory Theatre Institute and Island Shakespeare. We are thrilled to be bringing this production and FREE outdoor Shakespeare to the community.
But to make this amazing production happen, we need your help! We need to raise $10,000 to cover our remaining production costs. Some of these costs include:
  • Rehearsal space $1400
  • Insurance $1000
  • Sets and Props $1000
  • Costumes $1000
  • Electrical / space costs $1100
  • Crew $1000
  • Housing $2500
  • Travel costs $500
With the help of your donations, we can make this "Dream" a reality! In return for your generous support, you will receive our undying gratitude, the company's love and devotion, and some awesome rewards including:
  • Copy of production poster signed by the cast
  • Thank you cards from cast
  • Personal video messages / performances from the actors
  • Custom Walden Shakespeare blanket
  • Picnic dinner
  • VIP reserved seating on the lawn 
  • Producer credit
  • Special thanks on our program and on our website
  • A shout out on Facebook 
  • Song dedication in pre-show music 
  • Wine from local Nashoba Winery 
  • Bottom's Donkey ears!

...AND you'll have the satisfaction of knowing that you are part of an effort to bring FREE OUTDOOR SHAKESPEARE to the community. 

We only have 45 days to reach our goal, so please give early, and give often and spread the word! And remember, no amount is too small. If we reach our goal, all the funds will go towards our production costs. If we exceed our goal all funds will help towards our next production in summer 2016!
Many, many thanks for your generous support!

We hope to see you this summer at NARA Park!
Walden Shakespeare Presents:
A Midsummer's Night Dream 
by William Shakespeare
at NARA Park Amphitheatre
July 24, 25 and 26 at 7:30
We encourage audience to come early and enjoy the pre show at 7:00.
Cast:
Sai Somboon, Jeff Lyon, Doug Chapman, Brandon Harris, Kristi Artinian, Patrick Toon, Brennan Gallagher, Sam Adams, Rececca Odorisio, Milia Ayache, Ingrid Werner, Ben Thys
Directed by: Careena Melia
Stage Manager: Cati Pishal
Associate Producer: Kristi Artinian
Videographer: Kalmia Strong
Illustrations/ logo: Emma Kramer MacDonnell
Music Director: Doug Chapman
Production Assistant: Rachel Karp
PR - Jenny Weinbloom 
Special thanks to Jeannette Hawley, Pigpen Theatre Company, The American Repertory Theatre, and Acton Parks and Recreation.

story:
Tommy, the double album turned Broadway musical production by iconic British band The Who, is set to rock your socks off this May in Downtown LA's Little Tokyo!

Once every season, East West Players magically blends Eastern and Western influences to their mainstage musicals, and The Who's Tommy is no exception!

This show is THE largest production in EWP’s 50 year history -- featuring a 17-person cast including Broadway veterans, seasoned professionals, and rising talent, along with an award-winning team of creative designers, and six onstage musicians!

We are bringing this  this 1960s classic to the 21st century with an immersive and interactive production that will include a surround sound system (the only way you are meant to listen to the music of The Who), mind-blowing visual projections, and eclectic costumes that will forever alter your theatre-going experience!

But to accomplish all of the above, we need your support to raise $10,000 via Indiegogo by Opening Night on Wednesday, May 13, 2015!

Please consider making an online contribution today and help make this dream a reality.

Story of The Who's Tommy
Deprived of sight, hearing and speech by the shock of what he had witnessed as a child, young Tommy Walker seems lost to life – until he reveals an uncanny talent for the game of pinball. When his lost senses are suddenly restored, Tommy is hailed as a living miracle. The classic rock musical arrives for the first time at East West Players in an electrifying new production.

WHO is the creative team?
Directed by Snehal Desai
Musical direction by Marc Macalintal
Choreography by Janet Roston (NAACP Award, Ovation Award, Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Award)

Set design: Stephanie Kerley Schwartz (Ovation Award)
Costume design: Jenny Foldenauer (Ovation Award, Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Award)
Lighting design: Karyn Lawrence (iSquint Student Design Competition Award)
Sound design: Cricket Myers (Tony Award nominee, Drama Desk Award, Ovation Award)
Projections design by award-winner Sean Cawelti (Ovation Award, Sherwood Award)
Props by Marissa Bergman
Stage Manager is Ondina V. Dominguez

WHO is in the casT?

  • Joseph Morales (In The Heights Nat'l Tour, Bombay Dreams)
  • Deedee Magno Hall (If/Then Broadway, Miss Saigon Broadway & Int'l Tour, Wicked 1st Nat'l Tour)
  • Cliffton Hall (Miss Saigon Broadway, 1st Nat'l Tour & Int'l Tour, Wicked  1st Nat'l Tour)
  • Parvesh Cheena (NBC Outsourced)
  • Also featured are Araceli Prasarttongosoth, Van Brunelle, Michayla Brown, Ryan Castellino, Cesar Cipriano, Cailan Rose, Constance Jewell Lopez, Maxwel Corpuz, Michael Daniel Dashefsky, Christine De Chavez, Caitlyn Calfas, Marius Beltran and Tina Nguyen.

WHO is East West Players?

As the nation's largest producer of Asian Pacific American theatre, EWP uses the unique platform of live theatre to tell multifaceted stories of the Asian Pacific American (APA) experience, seen through a social justice lens; provide unique arts education programs for youth; and to develop new artists. Founded in 1965, at a time when APAs faced limited or no opportunities to see their experiences reflected outside of stereotypical and often demeaning caricatures in the American landscape, EWP is currently celebrating its 50th Anniversary as the largest producer of Asian American creative work and longest running theatre of color in the country. 

East West Players is well established as a gathering place for the community; it is a place where people of all backgrounds come to experience a story that has universal themes. We’re now asking for your support in helping us to continue bringing you these stories.

East West Players is well established as a gathering place for the community; it is a place where people of all backgrounds come to experience a story that has universal themes. We’re now asking for your support in helping us to continue bringing you these stories.

story:
Last year Nerdology Musical Theatre was founded by teens by three Bay Area high school students, Chloe Xtina, Rachel Pendleton, and Emma Waldman, as a place for young adults to create art combined with pop culture. The teens gathered a team of enthusiastic friends and got to work in Chloe's attic. Together we worked on marketing, finance, graphic design and operations to produce our first show: Buffy the Vampire Slayer's Once More, with Feeling. With three sold out shows, the student ensemble rocked the socks off audience members at The Flight Deck, a new theater in Downtown Oakland. Now Nerdology has more supporters, company members and publicity than ever!

Over the past year, we have been expanding the company to form new relationships and include more teens from a wider area. Our company now includes teens from ten different high schools around the Bay. 

Media Alliance took us on, and became our fiscal sponsor. That means all of your donations are now tax deductible! 

Thanks to many volunteer hours on the part of Nerdology teens, all of our rehearsal space is being donated by Shotgun Players. 

 

Company members volunteering at Shotgun Players new rehearsal space.

This summer, We're taking on a new challenge. With your help, Nerdology hopes to produce John Dempsey's Zombie Prom! Your donations will pay for:

-Theater Space

- Set

- Costumes

- Props

- Tech

- Printing posters, cards, flyers and programs

Thank you for continuing to support youth arts!

story:
Responses from Audience Members:

"I've never felt such joy and warmth as Amy inspires." ~Peter Byrnes
"So beautiful in every sense of the word. Loved every minute." ~Loren
"My cheeks hurt from smiling! I'm walking out feeling that much freer. That much more passionate to follow my dreams." ~Shelley Davison
"Incredibly funny and clever" ~Guzel Gjenasaj
"I'm so moved. I felt like I was showered by her love and passion throughout the show." ~Saemi Nakamura

Click here for ticket information:
~ Tickets ~

Connect with Amy and Support the Show~<3

Amy Walker is an actress, singer, and performance artist with chameleonic range, who has been featured on the TODAY Show, NPR, Inside Edition, and numerous theatre and film productions.  ~ www.AmyWalkerOnline.com ~

With over 40 million views on YouTube and beyond, she has joyously shared her inspiring work for over 7 years, (for Free!) because she believes in accessible art.

We, The Vibes Team, have created exciting ways for you to connect with Amy and help bring her uplifting, comedic variety show to London for a special performance on 12 September, 2 pm, at the Tristan Bates Theatre, in the West End.

  • It's important to us to make the show available to all, at least on video.
  • That's why we hired a professional editor for the recent LA show and trailer.
  • All contributors at the $25 level will receive the show video, plus other perks!
  • <3~May your Generosity Return to You in Abundant Ways!~<3~<3~<3


Our Budget~ and how we're minimizing it

Total Costs include:

  • Venue Rental: $657.00 USD
  • Editor for Trailer and Show: $1,200 (he gave us a discount from $2,300!)
  • Airfare: $1,430
  • Ground Travel estimate for 10 days of prep and show: $190
  • Grocery stipend at $40/day for 10 days: $400
  • Flyers/posters $25
  • Housing: $0! Covered it with home-stays!
Total: $3,902 ~ Only asking for $2,762 to pay the editor and airfare, plus 5% for Indiegogo's fees. Anything above that will help cover the full cost~

What We're Doing to Meet the Costs:
  • Aiming to sell at least 41 of 70 tickets to cover Venue Rental~ Let's sell 70!
  • Reaching out to friends for home-stays wherever possible
  • Marketing as inexpensively as possible, with social media and friends~<3
  • Amy will teach a workshop in London to help with costs.
  • If we don't reach our goal, Amy will pay off the rest as she's able~
  • If we exceed it, you will help us recoup costs and make this a Super Success!            ~If we exceed total costs of the trip, Amy will use any extra funds toward updating her ancient camcorder for better quality YouTube videos! Win-Win!


On a Personal Note from Amy~

I'm Deeply Grateful to pour my heart into this show and have people laugh, cry, and walk out feeling uplifted and inspired. 

Bringing the show to San Francisco, Seattle, Langley, here in L.A., Sydney and Melbourne has been incredibly fulfilling~ and challenging in many ways. I've taken it as far as I can stretch my pockets, and now I open it up to your warm support.

This will be my first time in London and the UK, having grown up inspired by actors like Emma Thompson and Julie Andrews, who began my fascination with accents in Mary Poppins! I'm Excited to soak up the accents and culture and share my insights and inspirations with you~<3

  • I'll also Finally get to meet UK followers and e-friends In Person~ Hugs!
  • It's been so special to meet people in each location who've followed my work for years, and receive their beautiful responses. What a gift~<3 


Other Ways You Can Help

Low on funds? You can still contribute~<3

  • Share this campaign and Refer your Friends! If they purchase the perk of $11 or more, we'll award you a special thank you perk: the MP3 recording of Amy's We Are Connected song, a social media shout-out, your name listed on Amy's website, the show video, and an e-Certificate with the title of Officially

    Generous Person! 

  • Refer a business or venue owner! 

    Our $475 and $1000 perks are perfect for the business owner and / or someone who has a venue for Amy to perform in.  We shall thank you with the MP3 recording of Amy's We Are Connected song, a social media shout-out, your name listed on Amy's website, the show video, a personalized outgoing voice message in the accent of your choice and a mailed Certificate with the title of Officially Generous Person, signed by the whole Team! ;-)

  • Send Good Vibes! It helps, and we're grateful!~<3

Click here for ticket information:

~ Tickets ~

story:
For forty years Athens, Georgia has been a town on the cutting edge of culture. More than just a cradle of alternative rock and the home of R.E.M. and The B-52s, it is a vibrant and thriving community for visual and performing artists across the spectrum. In any arts-friendly community, however, there are those artists whose work doesn't fit neatly into established categories and genres but remains nonetheless important and worthy of exposure. We call these artists "fringe artists" and we're putting together a festival to bring them together and showcase their visionary work.


The Classic City Fringe Festival will follow in the footsteps of fringe festivals that have been held around the world since the 1940s and bring the work of uncensored actors, filmmakers, circus and cabaret performers, comedians, alternative theater companies and many more together in a celebration spanning several days and several venues. We are launching the Festival October 22-25, and response from the alternative arts community has been enthusiastic.


Though planning is in the early stages as we recruit artists and venues and network with local businesses, administrative and material costs could become daunting, which is why we're calling upon friends of the arts, especially those who would like to see more exposure given to artists working outside the mainstream. This fundraising campaign is to help us out in covering the costs of printing and publicity, office space and transportation, and all the details necessary to put this exciting and ambitious event together. It is our desire to be able to cover the production costs for our artists. Your donations will help us launch the first of what we plan to make a yearly extravaganza of alternative arts and performances and make our community ever stronger.

Marty Cronk and Megan Dunn were interviewed by Andrew Shearer for Online Athens. To hear that interview please click below.
Online Athens Interview by Andrew Shearer

story:
Our Mission

There are a lack of roles for women and ethnic minorities in film, television and theatre.  Statistics come out every year and they are very disheartening.  However there is a hunger for a more diverse representation of the society we live in — all ages, races, genders, and sizes.  The Hollywood ideal of size zero, male, Caucasian and twenty is very limiting and damaging.  People want to see themselves represented — it’s how we relate to the story.  

Rather than becoming discouraged we decided to take action! We created Jet Girls Productions to produce theatre and film projects with a mandate to bring more diversity in all its forms to stage and screen.  Our productions will focus on creating original works and re-imagining previous works.  Prior to Jet Girls we have written, produced and acted in numerous theater, television and film projects. 

David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross is our first production as a team.  This is a chance to feature an extraordinary ensemble of female performers with a fresh take on one of the great modern classics.  We chose this play because the themes of greed, competition and ambition are not male or female characteristics.  

David Mamet says ‘the play is about a society based on business, a society with only one bottom line: How much money you make.'  There has been a shift, especially over the last few decades, of women entering this business mentality.  We are obsessed with wealth and the promise of getting something for nothing.  With the gap between the rich and the poor widening this play is as relevant today as when it premiered in 1983 in London, England. 

The Perks

We're trying to raise $4000 to cover some of our production costs.  100% of the funds raised will go towards paying for rehearsal space, theatre rental and rights to the play.  Surpassing our goal will allow us to create a better set design, sound design and help us with our marketing campaign.  

We have some great perks that include shout outs on Twitter from the producers, tickets to opening night, producer credit in the program and gimlets with the cast post show.  

The Cast and Creative Team

Cast 

Elizabeth Saunders....................Shelly Levene  

Julie Brar.....................................John Williamson 

Francoise Balthazar................... Dave Moss

Laurel Paetz................................George Aaronow

Marianne Sawchuk......................Richard Roma

Rosemary Doyle..........................James Lingk

Robinne Fanfair...........................Detective Baylen

*This is a Canadian Actors' Equity Associate Production under the Artists' Collective Policy

Creative Team

Anita La Selva.....................................................Director

Lisa Sciannella...................................................Stage Manager 

Jan Venus...........................................................Costumes

Emanuel Pires....................................................Photographer

Janal Bechtold...................................................Sound Design Indiegogo Video

Julie Brar (Jet Girls Productions).....................Producer

Marianne Sawchuk (Jet Girls Productions).....Producer

Gerry Sutherland...............................................DP

Daniel Mansour..................................................Sound Operator

Philippe Gosselin...............................................Director/Editor Indiegogo Video

Showtimes

Red Sand Castle Theatre 922 Queen Street East, Toronto, Ontario

Preview April 15 8pm $15

April 16-19, April 22-26 8pm $20 Cash Only

Tickets- 416-845-9411

Spread the Word!

Help us spread the word by sharing this campaign through your social media platforms!  Tell your friends about this great show!  Every little bit helps.  Thanks!

story:
What is Desolation Manor?

In short Desolation Manor is an extreme interactive haunted house and escape room venue in Cedar Park, Texas. In addition to these two on premises events, if we get the revenue in place to do so, we may also do some "on the road" type events and we are in the process of developing a horror-genre live action role playing (LARP) game which should go live this fall.

Collectively we are a group of people with more than 30 years of experience in the haunted house and special FX industry and an intense passion for scaring other people yet still provide them with the best value for their entertainment dollar.

The guy above is me, Paul Fiero, I'm co-owner, general manager, and part of the creative team of this venture.

We would like to invite you to share in the nightmares we create for other people and possibly even experience it a little bit yourself, but in order for us to bring this event to life we need your help with this campaign. Your contributions will help us get this thing off the ground and opened for business. It is a monumental task ahead of us but I promise we will not disappoint.

 What We Need & What You Get

  • Ultimately we need $150,000 but we are asking for $75,000 right now to secure our space, acquire materials for our sets, and finish putting our special effects together.
  • We have a variety of perks available to contributors from t-shirts and towels to back stage tours and professionally applied makeup and there is even an opportunity to get involved with actually scaring people in the haunt.
  • If we don't reach our campaign goal it is not for naught, we will not give up. Maybe it delays our opening a little bit but we will open.

 The Impact

Your contributions will help us to achieve a dream.

  • There are only two major haunts in the Austin metropolitan area and by helping fund our campaign  you will be helping us bring a third major haunt to the area.
  • As I mentioned earlier, collectively our assembled group has more than 30 years of experience in this industry. Individually and together we have been part of several successful haunted houses and movie productions.
  • Let your contribution to this campaign help us bring your worst nightmare to life. I promise, you won't regret it if you join us.

 Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • We understand if you aren't in a position to donate to our campaign right now you can still help us by emailing all of your friends and acquaintances with this campaign information.
  • Also, please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
By the way, we are watching you..........

story:
History in the Making

My name is S. Christopher Boggs. I have been an actor/director/producer and writer within the Little Rock theatre community for a number of years. In late January of 2014, I came up with a crazy idea for a play and pitched it to my wife. She loved it and encouraged me to start fleshing the story out. Roughly a month later, "The Winning Numbers" (TWN) was finished. I reluctantly put the script down for a while, but then quickly picked it up again and began fine tuning it.  It has been my good fortune to be a member of Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) and even more fortunate that TWN was considered for their 2014-15 season. 

The weekend of April 24th-26th 2015, TWN will have its World Premiere performances at The Studio Theatre, where Community Theatre of Little Rock currently performs. A special VIP show will be held on April 23rd. I can not tell you how excited, nervous, elated and stressed out I have been over the past year and how excited, nervous, elated and stressed I am about the next couple of months (AHHHHH!!!). 

The cast and crew of "The Winning Numbers", along with Community Theatre of Little Rock, are seeking support from donors like you. Donation will go to help offset the cost of building our set, purchasing costume pieces and props, handling publicity, etc., so that all of the revenue from the actual production can go directly to Community Theatre of Little Rock. CTLR will be celebrating its 60th season here in Central Arkansas. The revenue generated from this production will give an added boost to the quality of shows we plan for the 60th and beyond.

If you have been involved in theatre on any level, you know that sets are used and reused again and again. The wear and tear on set flats, staircases, furniture, props, costumes, etc. can be very costly to the budget. So, new flats, among other necessary items, will help refresh the look and feel of future productions for years to come.  It is my hope, that the funds we raise here on IndieGoGo for this show will help provide CTLR with new flats, furniture and other needed essentials that they haven't had for a number of years. 

So your donations will help us two fold: We will be able to have flats, furniture, etc. for our World Premiere Production of "The Winning Numbers" and CTLR will have new equipment to use for many years to come. 

Synopsis of “The Winning Numbers”

“The buzz around the offices of Dingle, Martin and Associates is ‘the state lottery is at an all time high.’ For employees like Emily and Max, winning the lottery would mean comfort and happiness. For Roberta, it would mean a better education for her twin sons. Louie would finally be able to buy that house he’s always wanted. Scott could really get ahead of the curve. And for Stacy and Brewster, it might even mean wedding bells. But when things don’t go as planned, and the employees start plotting against each other."

UPDATE: Nov 15, 2014:

The Cast and Crew of "The Winning Numbers" met at cast member Bob Bidewell's house to have a preliminary read through of the script. This was a chance for everyone to meet and get to know each other. We laughed a lot and began delving into the script. We have a number of veteran actors/actresses in the cast as well as a few new folks. I asked each of them for their reaction to reading the script together as a cast. Here's what they had to say...

Jennifer Baltzley (Stacy) said "Feeling so honored to be cast with such amazing talent!  It's going to be a great show!  Can't wait!"

Chris Miller-Marshall (Louie) said "I knew I needed to be a part of the show after a few pages and uncountable chuckles."

Danny Troillett (Brewster) said "Well-written and fun. Anyone want to go in on some Lottery tickets?"

Stacy Williams (Max) said 

Jerry Woods (Alex) said "Where are my lines?"

Liz Turner (Emily) said "The characters are lovable and real. *sneeze*"

Kevin Crumpler (Randall) said "That will buy a lot of happiness!"

Brent Wood (Scott) said  "The Winning Numbers is a hilarious script with an amusing take on coworker relationships and shenanigans within an office. Do not miss this show!"

Roben Sullivant (Roberta) said "I was simply thinking how awesome it was to be one of the 'chosen ones' to debut the show. It's well written and hilarious - AND, it's already a drinking game! 'Snort, snort, giggle!' I haven't laughed so hard in a long time!"

Tamara Boggs - Stage Manager said "My husband's brilliant!"

Here's what readers of the script had to say:

Drama Teacher and Actress Jane Balgavy said "Characters that are rich and real interact as we all do - and for one of them, a life changing piece of paper is all they need to change the game!"

Horror Fiction Writer Kat Yars said "The Winning Numbers will keep you laughing from the opening to the very twisted ending. Well developed characters and plot lines will keep you guessing what will happen next. A great play, I cannot wait to see on the stage."

Director and Actor Frank O. Butler said "It's an interesting look at greed, and how it can blind you of many things if you're not careful. It has characters from different walks of life with different motives as to why winning the lottery is important, even if it's a one-in-a-million longshot. I think audiences will definitely identify with at least one of these characters during the course of the show."

Film Maker and Actress Jess Carson said "It's a quirky, fun and engaging piece of writing that will be sure to keep the audience engaged and in giggle fits."

Film Maker Nick "CK" Helms said "With The Winning Numbers, Mr. Boggs has crafted an excellent tale of a seemingly typical office group who band together to try and win the lottery in order to get out of their mundane lives. You can't help but match the characters up with people that you may have worked with in the past and it just makes the story even more humorous. I would definitely recommend this to others in hopes that they will enjoy it as much as I did."

Playwright Betsy Kelso said "In a time of such great financial uncertainty for so many, Chris Boggs has tapped into some truly relevant and compelling themes with 'The Winning Numbers.'"

Drama Professor and Actor Tom McLeod said "...kept me guessing till the very end!"

Actress Lori Ann Freda said "Boggs has created a lighthearted, funny play that is clever and entertaining! A whimsical story of office life and dreams of winning big! This is definitely a crowd-pleaser! Can't wait for the masses to enjoy this great piece!"

Personal friend Melissa Berkey said "


About Community Theatre of Little Rock

  "Founded in 1956, Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) is Central Arkansas' oldest and finest theatre tradtion. CTLR is a nonprofit, volunteer organization striving to enlighten, educate and entertain our community.

Since its inception, CTLR has performed in many venues in Little Rock, Arkansas. In the very early years, The Perish Hall at 9th and Louisiana, Trinity Parish Hall, Robinson Auditorium, a renovated feed store at 609 Center Street and The Medical Center Auditorium provided performance stages. In the 1960’s and 1970’s, National Investors Life Building, the Arkansas Arts Center, Student Union became our venues. The 1980’s found us performing again in the Arkansas Arts Center, UALR, the Excelsior Hotel, The Arkansas Repertory Theatre, Little Rock Garden Council and Hall High School. Capitol Keyboard Theatre became our home until the Arkansas School for the Blind offered us the use of Woolly Auditorium beginning our 2002-2003 season. The 2008-2009 season was an exciting time for CTLR, as we moved to The PUBLIC Theatre downtown. On July 1st, 2014, CLTR moved into The Studio Theatre on 7th Street.

We continue to provide our community with live theatrical productions of the highest quality, as well as, providing opportunities for talented people of all ages to perform and participate in every phase of producing live theatre.”

How You Can Help:

Please consider donating to our fund raising efforts. The perks for helping support our efforts are listed and we are looking forward  a great event.

If you have questions, concerns, etc., please feel free to contact us at any time.


See you on the Boards,

S. Christopher Boggs
Author/Director of "The Winning Numbers"
President/Publicity Coordinator
Community Theatre of Little Rock
story_txt: History in the MakingMy name is S. Christopher Boggs. I have been an actor/director/producer and writer within the Little Rock theatre community for a number of years. In late January of 2014, I came up with a crazy idea for a play and pitched it to my wife. She loved it and encouraged me to start fleshing the story out. Roughly a month later, "The Winning Numbers" (TWN) was finished. I reluctantly put the script down for a while, but then quickly picked it up again and began fine tuning it.  It has been my good fortune to be a member of Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) and even more fortunate that TWN was considered for their 2014-15 season. The weekend of April 24th-26th 2015, TWN will have its World Premiere performances at The Studio Theatre, where Community Theatre of Little Rock currently performs. A special VIP show will be held on April 23rd. I can not tell you how excited, nervous, elated and stressed out I have been over the past year and how excited, nervous, elated and stressed I am about the next couple of months (AHHHHH!!!). The cast and crew of "The Winning Numbers", along with Community Theatre of Little Rock, are seeking support from donors like you. Donation will go to help offset the cost of building our set, purchasing costume pieces and props, handling publicity, etc., so that all of the revenue from the actual production can go directly to Community Theatre of Little Rock. CTLR will be celebrating its 60th season here in Central Arkansas. The revenue generated from this production will give an added boost to the quality of shows we plan for the 60th and beyond.If you have been involved in theatre on any level, you know that sets are used and reused again and again. The wear and tear on set flats, staircases, furniture, props, costumes, etc. can be very costly to the budget. So, new flats, among other necessary items, will help refresh the look and feel of future productions for years to come.  It is my hope, that the funds we raise here on IndieGoGo for this show will help provide CTLR with new flats, furniture and other needed essentials that they haven't had for a number of years. So your donations will help us two fold: We will be able to have flats, furniture, etc. for our World Premiere Production of "The Winning Numbers" and CTLR will have new equipment to use for many years to come. Synopsis of “The Winning Numbers”“The buzz around the offices of Dingle, Martin and Associates is ‘the state lottery is at an all time high.’ For employees like Emily and Max, winning the lottery would mean comfort and happiness. For Roberta, it would mean a better education for her twin sons. Louie would finally be able to buy that house he’s always wanted. Scott could really get ahead of the curve. And for Stacy and Brewster, it might even mean wedding bells. But when things don’t go as planned, and the employees start plotting against each other."UPDATE: Nov 15, 2014:The Cast and Crew of "The Winning Numbers" met at cast member Bob Bidewell's house to have a preliminary read through of the script. This was a chance for everyone to meet and get to know each other. We laughed a lot and began delving into the script. We have a number of veteran actors/actresses in the cast as well as a few new folks. I asked each of them for their reaction to reading the script together as a cast. Here's what they had to say...Jennifer Baltzley (Stacy) said "Feeling so honored to be cast with such amazing talent!  It's going to be a great show!  Can't wait!"Chris Miller-Marshall (Louie) said "I knew I needed to be a part of the show after a few pages and uncountable chuckles."Danny Troillett (Brewster) said "Well-written and fun. Anyone want to go in on some Lottery tickets?"Stacy Williams (Max) said Jerry Woods (Alex) said "Where are my lines?"Liz Turner (Emily) said "The characters are lovable and real. *sneeze*"Kevin Crumpler (Randall) said "That will buy a lot of happiness!"Brent Wood (Scott) said  "The Winning Numbers is a hilarious script with an amusing take on coworker relationships and shenanigans within an office. Do not miss this show!"Roben Sullivant (Roberta) said "I was simply thinking how awesome it was to be one of the 'chosen ones' to debut the show. It's well written and hilarious - AND, it's already a drinking game! 'Snort, snort, giggle!' I haven't laughed so hard in a long time!"Tamara Boggs - Stage Manager said "My husband's brilliant!"Here's what readers of the script had to say:Drama Teacher and Actress Jane Balgavy said "Characters that are rich and real interact as we all do - and for one of them, a life changing piece of paper is all they need to change the game!"Horror Fiction Writer Kat Yars said "The Winning Numbers will keep you laughing from the opening to the very twisted ending. Well developed characters and plot lines will keep you guessing what will happen next. A great play, I cannot wait to see on the stage."Director and Actor Frank O. Butler said "It's an interesting look at greed, and how it can blind you of many things if you're not careful. It has characters from different walks of life with different motives as to why winning the lottery is important, even if it's a one-in-a-million longshot. I think audiences will definitely identify with at least one of these characters during the course of the show."Film Maker and Actress Jess Carson said "It's a quirky, fun and engaging piece of writing that will be sure to keep the audience engaged and in giggle fits."Film Maker Nick "CK" Helms said "With The Winning Numbers, Mr. Boggs has crafted an excellent tale of a seemingly typical office group who band together to try and win the lottery in order to get out of their mundane lives. You can't help but match the characters up with people that you may have worked with in the past and it just makes the story even more humorous. I would definitely recommend this to others in hopes that they will enjoy it as much as I did."Playwright Betsy Kelso said "In a time of such great financial uncertainty for so many, Chris Boggs has tapped into some truly relevant and compelling themes with 'The Winning Numbers.'"Drama Professor and Actor Tom McLeod said "...kept me guessing till the very end!"Actress Lori Ann Freda said "Boggs has created a lighthearted, funny play that is clever and entertaining! A whimsical story of office life and dreams of winning big! This is definitely a crowd-pleaser! Can't wait for the masses to enjoy this great piece!"Personal friend Melissa Berkey said "About Community Theatre of Little Rock  "Founded in 1956, Community Theatre of Little Rock (CTLR) is Central Arkansas' oldest and finest theatre tradtion. CTLR is a nonprofit, volunteer organization striving to enlighten, educate and entertain our community.Since its inception, CTLR has performed in many venues in Little Rock, Arkansas. In the very early years, The Perish Hall at 9th and Louisiana, Trinity Parish Hall, Robinson Auditorium, a renovated feed store at 609 Center Street and The Medical Center Auditorium provided performance stages. In the 1960’s and 1970’s, National Investors Life Building, the Arkansas Arts Center, Student Union became our venues. The 1980’s found us performing again in the Arkansas Arts Center, UALR, the Excelsior Hotel, The Arkansas Repertory Theatre, Little Rock Garden Council and Hall High School. Capitol Keyboard Theatre became our home until the Arkansas School for the Blind offered us the use of Woolly Auditorium beginning our 2002-2003 season. The 2008-2009 season was an exciting time for CTLR, as we moved to The PUBLIC Theatre downtown. On July 1st, 2014, CLTR moved into The Studio Theatre on 7th Street.We continue to provide our community with live theatrical productions of the highest quality, as well as, providing opportunities for talented people of all ages to perform and participate in every phase of producing live theatre.”How You Can Help:Please consider donating to our fund raising efforts. The perks for helping support our efforts are listed and we are looking forward  a great event.If you have questions, concerns, etc., please feel free to contact us at any time.See you on the Boards,S. Christopher BoggsAuthor/Director of "The Winning Numbers"President/Publicity CoordinatorCommunity Theatre of Little Rock

story:
Who we are:

The Youth Empowerment Performance Project (YEPP) is a unique youth theatre initiative that creates a safe environment for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) youth experiencing housing instability or homelessness to explore their history, investigate new ways to address their struggles and celebrate their strengths through the process of developing a theatrical performance piece. Throughout the one year season, we also provide resource advocacy around housing, employment, food, clothing, education, health services, among many other basic needs.  In order to achieve our mission, we blend harm reduction, social justice, popular education, theatre of the oppressed, transformative and restorative justice values and frameworks.    

New Season, Two Ensembles, Two Productions

For the first time, we will be working with two ensembles at the same time: Leadership Ensemble and Emerging Ensemble.  We will be doubling the number of youth we work with! 

  • The Leadership Ensemble will be structured with current and former ensemble members. We will be providing the same support described above but through a leadership lens. With this ensemble we intend to build the new generation of leaders in the program.  
  • The Emerging Ensemble will be structured with youth that have never been in the program and would love to go through a healing journey using the arts as a therapy and grounding tool.  

Why do we exist:

We exist to end youth homelessness among LGBTQ individuals in Chicago and beyond.  
  • 40% of youth experiencing homelessness identify as LGBTQ, whereas only 7% of the general youth population identifies as LGBTQ.  
  • Each year, between 500,000 and 2.8 million youth experience homeless according the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. 
  • 5,000 young people die every year because of assault, illness, or suicide while on the streets.  LGBTQ youth experiencing homelessness are twice as likely to attempt suicide (62%) as their heterosexual peers (29%). 
  • HIV rates for youth experiencing homelessness are 2 to 10 times higher than reported rates for other samples of adolescents in the U.S.  
  • The average age that a young person starts experiencing homelessness is 14.7 years old. 

How we engage:

Performances- We travel around the country creating awareness through our performances about the different issues that LGBTQ youth face in the streets. We traditionally include a dialogue with the audience after each performance in order to create a stronger human connection. 
Workshops- As part of our social dedication to build awareness and educate communities, we facilitate many different kinds of workshops around harm reduction, trauma informed practices, youth work, and how to use art and creativity as healing tools.  
Panels- We participate in different dialogs around the country regarding how to address and end youth homelessness, as well as how to create safe and trauma informed spaces for young people. Our members provide a distinctive first-hand perspective which are valuable for speaking engagements and other presentations. 


What our audiences say:

"Beautiful. Honest. Powerful. So thankful for you all and this performance." 


"I feel so honored to have shared this space with all of you. You inspire and empower."


"Thank you for granting me the honor to witness the beauty of your souls."


"This was so dynamic. I am leaving this place with so much hope for my own life. Thank you so much for finding strength within your on story to empower those around you. I will never forget this experience." 


"This was a wonderful performance. Thank you all for allowing us the chance to see life through your eyes."

story:
Short Summary

May and June are amazing times to be a Dance Major at the Professional Performing Arts School! Our Annual Spring Concert showcases the hard work and dedication of our 98 talented dancers who train M-F for 1.5-3 hours at the prestigious Alvin Ailey(r) American Dance Theater, a longtime arts partner of PPAS. The goal of the program is to give students superior dance training with a diverse dance curriculum. And because our PTA is a 501(c) 3 non-for-profit organization, your donation is tax deductible!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $2,000.00 to cover expenses for our concert weekend and our year end Senior/Instructor Year End Brunch. Our expenses include:

  • Kraft Services for our Students for Friday and Saturday performances
  • Decor & Refreshments for our family opening night reception
  • Food & Gifts for the Senior-Instructors Brunch 
Donors will receive honorable mention via our social media and monthly newsletter and depending on your gift, complimentary ticket(s) to our Opening Night Cocktail Hour!

The Impact

With your support, the PTA can create a concert weekend that supports  the needs of our dancers and celebrates our community of families, instructors and students. Our efforts continue next month  as we celebrate our graduates and their journey as PPAS/Ailey students.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our link with others and learn more about our school by visiting us online at www.ppasnyc.org.

story:
Introduction 

Thank you visiting our IndieGoGo fundraising page. Your time is greatly appreciated and we hope to have your support on our project. My name is Aaron Langford and I am the writer and director of ThreeWay, which is the sixth play that I've wrote. I began by co-writing a play four years ago that was about bullying and mental health issues. O2 awarded me £300 to create it and tour it around schools in the North East of England, which resulted in the project receiving an Anti-Bullying award. After the success of the project, I was later awarded another £2,500 from O2 for a new play, which was a sinister twist on the fairy tale Cinderella that also explored mental health issues. This was staged 2 years ago at the renowned Sage Gateshead in their 600 seater venue. Since then, I have wrote another 4 plays, which collectively have covered many issues, including mental health issues, existentialism and romance. My last play Lunaria was staged last year at the Woking Youth Arts Centre through the kind support of Peer Productions.

About ThreeWay
ThreeWay is a new, innovative piece of theatre that offers a new perspective into the world of dating, relationships and mental health. It explores these topics through comedy and reveals a polyamorous relationship that accidentally unfolds between three people, none of whom identity as this. ThreeWay's part-verbatim quirky, witty and relatable to all, regardless of sexuality, and with the combination of awkward comedy and situations, it aims to have the audience laughing out loud throughout.

This project is important to me/us because we believe that dating has actually became terrifying for so many people these days. With the rise of applications such as Tinder and Plenty of Fish that dehumanise the whole process, it's not hard to work out why. ThreeWay highlights this with comedy and exposes awkward situations that most of us might be far too familiar with... Ever tried to act really cool in front of someone you like, only to fail miserably and come off looking like a creep? I have... So much so that I've lost count.  
ThreeWay now contains a dark, unexpected twist that will keep you on the edge of your seat! This is to highlight our other issue of mental health, which is not talked about enough. I'm sure you all know someone who suffers and many others still suffer in silence. For this reason, it is so important that ThreeWay is staged so it can make everyone have a great experience and also help those who need it.  
Our performances of ThreeWay will be held at Spotlites, Venue 278 at the Royal Society of Edinburgh at The Create Theatre. These will be from Thursday 4th of August until Saturday 13th August. 
All contributions are extremely appreciated.

Every little contribution makes a massive difference. Without the support we have had so far, we would not have been able to secure our venue at the exquisite and beautiful Royal Society of Edinburgh building, managed by award-winning company Spotlites in August 2016. With your support you will be ensuring this project goes ahead at EdFringe 2016. We may have secured the venue but we still have such a long way to go, as the budget below shows. Costs include monthly payments for the venue, travel costs and general expenses, such as accommodation and equipment for the project.  

What We Need & What You Get

We currently need just over £2,500 pounds. We know this may seem like a lot but we believe we have something worth funding. We are confident that we can do it with your help and have already received funding from O2 Think Big!
Venue Cost - £948.00
Travel Costs for cast and equipment - £500
Accommodation Costs - £1,200
Total = £2,648
So, let's talk about the perks you will get for supporting us!
£5.00 - A Thank You card for your support. 
£10.00 - A Thank You card + A gift for your support. 
£20.00 - A Thank You card + A gift + A mention in our shows programme, for your support.
£50.00 - A Thank You card + A gift + A mention in our shows programme + A copy of the script in PDF format, for your support. 
£100.00 - A Thank You Card + A gift + A mention in our shows programme + A copy of the script in PDF format + An extra very special gift from the cast , for your support. 

Risks & Challenges

There is always the potential for problems when creating and touring a show. However, the important thing is to ensure safeguards are in place to prevent or minimise them. 

Our biggest concern is not reaching our total funding goal, it was originally £3,000. However, we were presented with the opportunity of extending our show from 5 shows to 13, which meant our budget was increased to £3,500.  Your generous support on Kickstarter, has made sure that we only need £2648 now. 

In terms of finding this cost, I have successfully raised this amount in past projects. I've been very lucky to have had these opportunities over time it has given me the skills necessary to not only create a show but also manage and produce one. I started off by co-writing a play three years ago that was about mental health issues, which toured schools and I was awarded £300 from 02 to create after I won an Anti-Bullying award for it. After the success of the project, I was later awarded another £2,500 for a new play that was a sinister twist on the fairy tale Cinderella, which also explored mental health issues. This was staged about 2 years ago at a 600 seat venue. In recent years, I have wrote 4 more plays, which have collectively covered my issues, including mental health issues, existentialism and romance. My last play was staged last year at the Woking Youth Arts Centre through the kind support of Peer Productions. O2 Think Big have also offered their support again in ThreeWay, which is brilliant and we are very excited about it. 

This isn't our only funding option though, we will also have very exciting funding ideas in the coming weeks. Keep a look out!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing is immensely useful for us to get the word out, if you can share it, then please do. We really appreciate it!

Tell everyone you can, word of mouth is a great way for us to gain more supporters. 

We could also really use your support to help us fundraise too, any assistance with events would be brilliant!

We could also really use your support to help us fundraise too, any assistance with events would be brilliant!

story:
The Dream to perform as a soloist

I have been a student of dance since the age of 3. Being a chubby kid, my parents sent me to dance classes to get in shape. Little did anyone know that my passion for dance would blossom to the extent that I wanted to debut as a solo performer at age 13.  Due to monetary restrictions it never happened then. I was heartbroken and moved away from dance. About 5 yrs ago I rediscovered Bharatanatyam and started pursuing dance as a hobby with Guru, while working towards a PhD degree in biological sciences as an international student. I reconnected with dance differently this time around. Instead of it being a cardio exercise, it became food for my soul - wherein my body, mind and spirit merged to create a most meditative experience. While I struggled through student life with bills, visas, unfamiliar environments, dance class tuition, making time for practice, my weight, stamina... everything an international student struggles with living in a foreign country - I continued to dance. 

Now, after 17 yrs I am revisiting my desire to debut as a solo Bharatanatyam dancer. Challenges remain and they are mostly monetary as I am a one-man army trying to support myself through this process without any backing. I had to let go of my dream to perform as a soloist about 2 decades ago because of pecuniary issues. That's why this time around I need your support to accomplish this feat! 

My solo dance performance, scheduled for Labor Day weekend, is of exemplary standards involving renowned musicians flying from different parts of Southern India to Los Angeles, donning traditional temple costume and jewelry, learning intense complex choreography and classical Carnatic music - all of which contributes towards making the dancer fit for international standards. Your contribution will help me mold myself physically, mentally and spiritually as a world-class performer of this ancient Indian art form.

You can follow my progress through this journey on: http://movingthroughdance.blogspot.com/


What will the funding be used for

This is a non-ticketed show, the major costs in this production including the theater rental, training fees, musicians from India, lighting and videography cannot be covered by ticket sales. The significant expenditures are:

  • Theater rental (including theater crew) for rehearsals and show.
  • Artistic support (special orchestra and lighting director from India, teacher, backstage) for rehearsals and show.
  • Choreography and training.
  • Videography and Photography.
  • Traditional Bharatanatyam costume and temple jewelry.
  • Brochures and invitations.
  • Indiegogo, paypal and credit card transaction fees (~8% of the funds raised).

If 300 of you donate me $108 or 108 of you donate me $300, I can very easily reach my goal. So please help! Every penny counts!!! 



The Impact

Your contribution will have a profound impact on the life of a budding artist. The traditional solo performance is a first step towards a life-long commitment to dancing professionally. Currently I lead a cerebral life and this dance journey is an opportunity for me to develop a life an practice that incorporates arts and be in touch with my body.

I have previously danced in several dance productions as one of the background dancers. This performance is a first step in establishing myself as a solo performing artist. Let alone brushing off a two decade old dream, at 31 I am tackling an accomplishment normally allotted to girls in their pubescent prime. In other words, most often than not, dancers who have started as toddlers will undertake this journey by the time they are a teenager. 31 is indeed a young age yet within the cultural confines of my background, a debut solo performance at this age is certainly a most unexpected undertaking.


What are the potential Risks & Challenges

I believe that no risk equates to no gain. The biggest risk I run is not having enough funds and forgo this project. I have minimal support from other resources which is why it became impertinent to reach out to you. 

Other risks and challenges are minimal and pertains mostly to my  personal physique. However, I have been training hard for a couple of years for this program and my personal practice will increase exponentially over the next few months. 


Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you can't contribute but are willing to help in other ways.
You can help by getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign by:
  • Using the Indiegogo  share tools
  • Social media: Sharing the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and others 
  • Word of mouth.
Read more about this journey on http://movingthroughdance.blogspot.com/
story_txt:
The Dream to perform as a soloist

I have been a student of dance since the age of 3. Being a chubby kid, my parents sent me to dance classes to get in shape. Little did anyone know that my passion for dance would blossom to the extent that I wanted to debut as a solo performer at age 13.  Due to monetary restrictions it never happened then. I was heartbroken and moved away from dance. About 5 yrs ago I rediscovered Bharatanatyam and started pursuing dance as a hobby with Guru, while working towards a PhD degree in biological sciences as an international student. I reconnected with dance differently this time around. Instead of it being a cardio exercise, it became food for my soul - wherein my body, mind and spirit merged to create a most meditative experience. While I struggled through student life with bills, visas, unfamiliar environments, dance class tuition, making time for practice, my weight, stamina... everything an international student struggles with living in a foreign country - I continued to dance. 

Now, after 17 yrs I am revisiting my desire to debut as a solo Bharatanatyam dancer. Challenges remain and they are mostly monetary as I am a one-man army trying to support myself through this process without any backing. I had to let go of my dream to perform as a soloist about 2 decades ago because of pecuniary issues. That's why this time around I need your support to accomplish this feat! 
My solo dance performance, scheduled for Labor Day weekend, is of exemplary standards involving renowned musicians flying from different parts of Southern India to Los Angeles, donning traditional temple costume and jewelry, learning intense complex choreography and classical Carnatic music - all of which contributes towards making the dancer fit for international standards. Your contribution will help me mold myself physically, mentally and spiritually as a world-class performer of this ancient Indian art form.
You can follow my progress through this journey on: http://movingthroughdance.blogspot.com/


   What will the funding be used for This is a non-ticketed show, the major costs in this production including the theater rental, training fees, musicians from India, lighting and videography cannot be covered by ticket sales. The significant expenditures are:  Theater rental (including theater crew) for rehearsals and show. Artistic support (special orchestra and lighting director from India, teacher, backstage) for rehearsals and show. Choreography and training.
Videography and Photography.
Traditional Bharatanatyam costume and temple jewelry.
Brochures and invitations.
Indiegogo, paypal and credit card transaction fees (~8% of the funds raised). 

If 300 of you donate me $108 or 108 of you donate me $300, I can very easily reach my goal. So please help! Every penny counts!!! 

   The Impact Your contribution will have a profound impact on the life of a budding artist. The traditional solo performance is a first step towards a life-long commitment to dancing professionally. Currently I lead a cerebral life and this dance journey is an opportunity for me to develop a life an practice that incorporates arts and be in touch with my body.
I have previously danced in several dance productions as one of the background dancers. This performance is a first step in establishing myself as a solo performing artist. Let alone brushing off a two decade old dream, at 31 I am tackling an accomplishment normally allotted to girls in their pubescent prime. In other words, most often than not, dancers who have started as toddlers will undertake this journey by the time they are a teenager. 31 is indeed a young age yet within the cultural confines of my background, a debut solo performance at this age is certainly a most unexpected undertaking.

What are the potential Risks & Challenges
 I believe that no risk equates to no gain. The biggest risk I run is not having enough funds and forgo this project. I have minimal support from other resources which is why it became impertinent to reach out to you. 
Other risks and challenges are minimal and pertains mostly to my  personal physique. However, I have been training hard for a couple of years for this program and my personal practice will increase exponentially over the next few months. 




    Other Ways You Can Help
I understand if you can't contribute but are willing to help in other ways.
You can help by getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign by:


Using the Indiegogo  share tools
Social media: Sharing the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and others 

Word of mouth.


Read more about this journey on http://movingthroughdance.blogspot.com/

story:
A Playwright's Note

My name is Justin Rielly, and I'm the founder of Aspie Works, a multi-disciplinary label whose initial dedication was to explore the meaning of the human condition through the arts.  I'm also a playwright and Artist in Residence at the MuCCC, and this March will present the full production of my latest play Ghost Light.  In the four years I've been a theater artist in Rochester, this is easily the most ambitious project I have ever brought to the stage.  The development of Ghost Light from idea to a fully realized stage show has been nearly three years in the making, with many changes to the script and overall story.  A workshop reading in June 2015 led to those changes, with any murky or unnecessary details dropped in favor of a stripped-down but deeply thoughtful look at grief, at letting go, and the meaning of existence.  I have described Ghost Light as a meditation on stage, with moments of humor, heartbreak and levity. 

The cast and crew of Ghost Light are looking for your support to help us bring this show to life in the most maximum way possible.  

The Plot

Max Campbell is a long-time theater director in Rochester, but his days of being a king of the theater scene are running out.  He is in mourning after an accident in his latest production claims the life of an actress named Lenny - who has now become the theater's resident ghost. 

Then Max gets a welcome visit from David Pringle, a successful actor who has left New York City to come back to Rochester.  The reason why is soon discovered: Max has put his property up, and David is taking him up on the offer.  Throw in David's French-born ghost hunting reality star girlfriend into the mix, and when Lenny discovers the plan, emotional chaos will explode...

The Brief History

Ghost Light was first presented as a workshop at the MuCCC in June 2015, with the plan to stage it the following spring.  The initial script took two years to complete, with a different story than the plot that will be presented in the upcoming run.  After several draft rewrites (with consulting from acclaimed Rochester playwright Maria Brandt), the show was ready to be presented to the stage.  After an extensive period of auditions, by early January 2016, the show's cast of four performers and crew were confirmed. 

Ghost Light will be presented at the MuCCC (142 Atlantic Avenue, Rochester) from March 3 to 5, 2016; evening performances are scheduled for 7:30pm, with the Saturday matinee at 2:00pm. 

The Team

Jacqueline Moe is directing Ghost Light, and comes to the production with a wide-ranging experience of creating and performing Rochester theater.  Along with her work as founder of Deadly Dames Burlesque, she is an Artist-in-Residence at the MuCCC and has also participated in several Aspie Works productions - including stagings of Shakespeare's The Rape of Lucrece and Love in the Style of Will. 

The ensemble cast features four highly-respected Rochester actors: Stephen Cena leads as the grieving director Max Campbell, Colleen DiVincenzo as the driven ghost Lenny, James Lockhart as the returning actor David Pringle, and Laura Pratt as the perky but ambitious ghost hunter Mireille Girard. 

Other key members of the crew: 

  • Stage Manager: Katie Guy
  • Lighting Designer: Chris Nimick
  • Poster Designer: Louie Podlaski
  • Creative Consultant: Maria Brandt

The Breakdown

Putting on independent theater in Rochester is not easy, especially with the need to pay to put your show on - and to make sure your show has every base covered. Any donations given will help cover costs for the production, from design to promotion. This is a basic breakdown of where the money will go towards: 

BUDGET

  • Performance space cost: $750
  • Lighting design/cost: $150
  • Stage management: $100
  • Costumes: $300
  • Props: $200
  • Promotion (posters/ads): $300
  • Miscellaneous expenses: $200
  • Total: $2,000
With the MuCCC staging Ghost Light and sponsoring this campaign, any donation you give is tax-deductible - and will also help the MuCCC continue its mission of being a highly-acclaimed, respected venue for artists and groups to present their artistic works from theater and dance to music and art. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to financially support the show, you can still let people know what Ghost Light is all about.  This campaign will be presented via Aspie Works' Facebook and Twitter pages, as well as AspieWorks.com.  You can also purchase tickets at muccc.org when they become available. 

Thank you for your support!

story:
Did you know that ...


Who We Are:

The Women’s Voices Theater Group was created solely to bring awareness to these types of issues. We are a collaborative group of women using the stage as a platform to bring awareness to violence against women and give a voice to those in need.

What We Do: 

Women's Voices Theater Group producers Lindsay Lucas-Bartlett, Nino D. Gordeli and Tori-Ann Hampton are honored to join V-Day's One Billion Rising with a theater production of  Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues, not only to raise awareness to the devastating number of human trafficking victims, but also to raise funds for Bishop Outreach Human Trafficking Rescue, a non-profit organization that helps rescue and rehabilitate women who have been subjected to sex trafficking.

Money raised through this production will be used to aid in the efforts of rescuing and rehabilitating victims of sex trafficking. 
Cast:

This year we are excited to welcome to our ranks a fantastic lineup of women. To name only a few, we are proud to work with Grace and Frankie's Suzanne Ford, Home and Away's Esther Anderson, Siberia's Sabina Akhmedova, Swans Crossing's Stacey Moseley, as well as Harriet Wallace, Genevieve Kennedy and Deanna Noe, among others.

 

Director:

Nino D. Gordeli primarily works in film but her passion for theater and the cause brought her back to the stage. 

 "It feels like coming home because theater is where I started," says Nino.

She has directed/produced a number of documentaries, shorts, TV Shows, theater productions and her latest feature as writer/producer is in post production under working title "Titus".

"Vagina Monologues is personal, every monologue, regardless of the story behind.   I am every woman, this is my story, and I'd like to share it with you!"

 

What We Need:

The producers, the director and the cast are dedicating their time and talent for free, but we still need money for the production expenses, like rehearsal space, theater rental, tech personnel, and printing promotional materials etc... 


What You Get:

Thanks to our great sponsors we have amazing incentives for you: 
- hand crafted jewelry from GiftinForFifteen and Bornnomadic
- gift cards from LA's local restaurants
- gift bags that contain VDAY and WV Theater Group merchandise
- tickets to the show, signed goodies from the cast,
- and lots and lots of cyber gratitude, love and fantastic karma as well as the knowledge you are helping a truly wonderful cause. 

The Impact: 

Every dollar that goes into Bishop Outreach is used to facilitate the rescue of girls and women who have been abducted and sold into the sex and labor slavery. The average cost of one rescue operation (not a single victim) but a rescue operation can cost as much as $12,000 or more. These funds will save lives. 

Risks and Challenges we face:

We are a small theater group trying to raise awareness and action for an epidemic hitting our very own backyard with a tenacity and force that's appalling. And it's happening in plain sight! Our theater group wants to bring these issues to the forefront of the residents of Los Angeles and get people involved with speaking up and against sex trafficking. Your voice can help save someone's life!

To do that, we need help getting the word out. As we are newly formed, it's difficult to be heard, but we know we have assembled the perfect group to make some noise. That being said, we need help with marketing. We need help spreading the word and that's where you all come in! Through your donation, you will be raising your voice against sex trafficking! Let's unite, donate today, see the show (if you're in LA), and help us out with your social media outlets.


Other Ways You Can Help: 

You can donate as little as $5, but if you can't, here's what you can do:

1. Donate your Time! Just email us at wvtheatergroup@gmail.com and let's see how we can work together. 

2. Like our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter and Instagram @wvtheatergroup, and add our google + page to your circle.  

3. Spread the word about this production! Share our tweets, IG and Facebook posts. Use hashtags #wvtheatergroup and #1billionrising and let's make some ruckus about this epidemic! The revolution is now!
