Please JUST SHOUT IT OUT! and use the Indiegogo share tools. At the end of the project our contributors will be the first to see an excerpt of our performances, we will share the video through youtube/vimeo.


Contribution of $10 will receive a special designed THANK YOU card by email. 
Contributions of $25  a set of 3 GraphicArtPostcards from shots taken during one of our performances printed on handmade paper and a SHOUT OUT on our Facebook page.
Contribution of $55 our featured perk, a special fashionable high quality organic cotton t-shirt that will be send to your doorsteps packed in handmade recyclable package. Your name will be mentioned on our FB page with a SHOUT OUT. The T-shirt is designed by us and manufactured by Shree Kailash Apparels in Tamil Nadu state, a company specialised in manufacturing for large charitable foundations. Although they accept only big orders they were very kind to support us with our project.

GREETINGS! NAMASTE!

story:
My Story:

I began dancing at a very young age. At the time, it was extracurricular. As I dove further into my training, it became something so much more. I was intrigued by the fact that I could express myself through movement. Now I’m a professional dance-artist, teacher and award-winning choreographer based in Toronto. In 2009, I successfully completed Ryerson University’s Theatre Performance Dance Program and graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts. I also hold qualifications under Dance Masters of America, the Royal Academy of Dance and the Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing. Over the past 6 years I’ve dedicated myself to training and performing with numerous professional dance and circus companies across Canada and Europe. In addition, I have focused most of my time teaching, coaching and choreographing for competitive and pre-professional students ages 5-19.

Accomplishments include choreographing numerous overall high scoring routines, teacher recognition and choreography awards. Furthermore, students have gone on to attend highly acclaimed summer intensives and schools all over the world, including York and Ryerson Universities (Toronto), Simon Fraser University (Vancouver) and  international schools such as the Royal Ballet School (London), The Paris Opera Ballet School (Paris), The School of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater (New York), San Francisco Ballet School (San Francisco), and the American Ballet Theatre (New York).  I admire our art form greatly, primarily because of the endless possibilities for continued growth and the knowledge we may acquire, then share. My passion is fueled by my desire to encourage and provoke momentum to future dancers. I admire their vulnerability and trust, and having the privilege to work with young artists is an honour. My intention is to acquire innovative knowledge and first hand experience that will further inspire and promote development amongst young artists!

What I need your help with: 

This year, I was selected as 1 of 11 dancers worldwide for a place at the London Contemporary Dance School in England, to study towards my Masters Degree, beginning September 2015. In addition to weekly training, rehearsals and research, the program involves touring internationally with the EDge Company. The LCDS is a world-leading dance conservatoire leading in the vocational training and education of dance-artists in the UK and internationally. Admission to this program is highly competitive and an incredible honour! 

In addition to completing my Masters Degree, attending this program will provide me the opportunity to further my expertise as a dance educator by developing new movement vocabularies, and it will broaden my skills as a dance-artist by offering me new performance and touring opportunities. I will explore and research choreographic processes and assimilate a body of methods and material, which will aid in my ability to communicate movement and creative tasks to the next generation of dancers. My experience in this program will bring value to young students looking to develop and pursue a career in the arts. Upon my return, I wish to share a world of influence with future dance artists, so that they may continue to inspire and awaken the hearts of others. 

The breakdown:

All proceeds from this campaign will help cover the cost of tuition.

TOTAL COST

£14,300 = $28,500 CAD


All additional costs:

Rent

Electricity & utilities

Internet

Phone

Transportation

Food & other essential living expenses

Along with my Visa application fees, Immigration Health Surcharge fee and other necessary documentation required to enter the UK for the year, will be coming from my personal savings. An additional estimated cost of: $23,000 CAD

[Indiegogo takes 9% of my total earnings if I do not reach my goal, and only 4% if I reach the grand total]

I NEED YOUR HELP!

Every donation makes a difference! No contribution is too small. You know how easy it is to spend $10 on coffee for you and a friend? Think of this as a couple of virtual coffee dates. Every dollar helps me get closer to my goal. If you’d like to support me but are not able to donate financially, there are other ways you to can help. PLEASE SHARE! Spread the word about my campaign with family, friends and colleagues on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or any other forms of social media. I will be eternally grateful for any contribution, and your continued support on my journey.

                             

Thank you for taking the time to learn a little bit about my upcoming journey. Your love and support is inspiring!

The LCDS is a world-leading dance
conservatoire leading 

in the vocational training and education of dance-artists in the UK and
internationally. Admission to this program is highly competitive and an incredible
honour! 

In addition to completing my Masters
Degree, attending this program will provide me the opportunity to further my
expertise as a dance educator by developing new movement vocabularies, and it
will broaden my skills as a dance-artist by offering me new performance and
touring opportunities. I will explore and research
choreographic processes and assimilate a body of methods and material, which
will aid in my ability to communicate movement and creative tasks to the next
generation of dancers. My experience in this program will bring value to young students looking to develop and pursue a career in the arts. Upon my return, I wish to share a world of influence with future dance artists, so that they may continue to inspire and awaken the hearts of others. The breakdown: 

All
proceeds from this campaign will help cover the cost of tuition.


TOTAL COST

 £14,300 = $28,500 CAD 

All additional costs:
Rent
Electricity
& utilities
Internet

Phone 
Transportation
Food
& other essential living expenses 
Along with my Visa
application fees, Immigration Health Surcharge fee and other necessary
documentation required to enter the UK for the year, will be coming from my
personal savings. An additional estimated cost of: $23,000 CAD 
[Indiegogo takes 9% of my total earnings if I do
not reach my goal, and only 4% if I reach the grand total]


I NEED YOUR HELP! 
Every donation makes a difference! No contribution is too small. You know how easy it
is to spend $10 on coffee for you and a friend? Think of this as a couple of virtual coffee dates. Every dollar helps me get closer to my goal.
If you’d like to support me but are not able to donate financially, there are
other ways you to can help. PLEASE SHARE! Spread the word about my campaign with family, friends and colleagues on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or
any other forms of social media. I will be eternally grateful for any
contribution, and your continued support on my journey.
                              Thank
you for taking the time to learn a little bit about my upcoming journey. Your
love and support is inspiring!

story:
SO WHO ARE WE?

DEELEN with TROUBLE is a Toronto based production company founded by Courtney Deelen and Micheal T Burgess, a husband & wife filmmaking team. Our mandate has always been to create entertaining, thought provoking projects with heart. We strive to connect with our audiences through stories while also bringing awareness and giving back to charities that are near and dear to our hearts.

 

WHERE IS YOUR MONEY GOING?

Rabbit Hole is our first live theatre show and there are MANY costs that go into bringing a story to life. Your donations will go towards the production costs of this play; our theatre rental, our set, the rights and insurance.

Our cast will be sharing the box office profits, once these costs have been covered.

We also want to give a generous donation to Bereaved Families of Ontario. Therefore, the more we make through our campaign, the more we can give back to this amazing foundation.

 

THE IMPACT

Your donation will help in MANY ways.

As this is DEELEN with TROUBLE's first live theatre performance, we want to set the bar high.  We aim to give our audiences, an experience that will leave them wanting more. We have an amazing cast and we want the production values to match their performances.  We want our audience's to know and trust that each and every show produced by DwT will be of the highest calibre.

Our company mandate is to give back to our local community. We are partnering with local restaurants to bring you exclusive menus to enjoy before the show. All within walking distance to the theatre. We will also be featuring Frisky Beaver an award winning Southern Ontario wine each night, with perks to join us on our exclusive opening & closing nights.

But the most important part of this particular production is to raise awareness for Bereaved Families of Ontario. A non-profit organization, run by volunteers that supports families who have lost loved ones and who are looking for a safe, supportive place to grieve.

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

This one's quite simple.... If we don't cover the production costs, we can't mount the show. We won't be able to share this incredible story and we won't be able to make a substantial donation to this incredibly deserving, non-profit organization.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We absolutely understand if you can't contribute financially, but that isn't the only way to show your support.

Please spread the word. Share our campaign, come see the show, follow us on social media. Sharing the campaign, also spreads the word about child loss and Bereaved Families of Ontario, any awareness is wonderful.

Please check out our website and follow our blog: www.deelenwithtrouble.com/news  for more information about how to keep up with DEELEN with TROUBLE's next projects.

Share your stories with us! We would love to hear your feedback.

We truly appreciate your support and we hope to see you at the theatre!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Collin Sloan and I am a high school senior from Palm Coast, Florida who recently started his own theatre company, The Spotlight Performers. Last year, we successfully put on the rock musical, Spring Awakening and this year we are attempting to put on the Classic Rock jukebox musical, Rock of Ages to continue providing rock styled musicals to the local community. This campaign is important as without it, we would have no summer show this year. Our theatre company focuses on introducing immersive theatre to audiences around, breaking the typical idea of a traditional seated theatrical performance. Shown through last year's Spring Awakening, the entire show was put on around the audience with actors interacting and often entering/exiting through a center aisle created straight through the audience.

Spring Awakening (Gerald Kitt, Blair Duncan, Dylan Lev, Kianna Longhway, Collin Sloan, Cassidy Van Brink, John Zamborsky, Max Wolf, Anna Viscardi, Dylan Molitor, Katie Thompson)

Mama Who Bore Me reprise (Kianna Longhway, Blair Duncan, Cassidy Van Brink, Katie Thompson, Anna Viscardi)

​

Those You've Known (Cassidy Van Brink, Collin Sloan, Gerald Kitt)

 

We plan to follow suit with this established tradition with Rock of Ages by performing in a warehouse with the inside transformed into the musical's hotspot location: The Bourbon Room, located on the Sunset Strip in Los Angeles, CA. Audience members will be sat at bar style tables or at the actual bar where actors will wait them while performing and even dancing on top of the tables, bar and anywhere they can head bang around. Our goal for this production is to make the audience feel as if they are in an LA bar during the rock and roll era that is the 1980's.

What We Need & What You Get

For this entire production to get put together, we need a whopping $10,000 to cover everything and anything. This seems like a large amount, but it covers set costs, costume/prop costs, warehouse rental, rights rental, and lighting/sound equipment rental. All of this equates to about $10,000 and it's something we hope to achieve. To give back for donations, we implemented perks to give back for your donation! The more you donate, the more you get back with your donation. This production needs all the support it can get, so we want to make it worth your time and effort for helping us reach the end goal.

The Show

Rock of Ages is a rock/jukebox musical, with a book by Chris D'Arienzo, built around classic rock songs from the 1980s, especially from the famous glam metal bands of that decade. The musical features songs from Styx, Journey, Bon Jovi, Pat Benatar, Twisted Sister,Steve Perry, Poison and Europe among other well-known rock bands. 

A Quick Synopsis, if you will:

It’s the tail end of the big, bad 1980s in Hollywood, and the party has been raging hard. Aqua Net, Lycra, lace and liquor flow freely at one of the Sunset Strips last legendary venues, a place where sex machine Stacee Jaxx takes the stage and scantily clad groupies line up to turn their fantasies into reality. Amidst the madness, aspiring rock star (and resident toilet cleaner) Drew longs to take the stage as the next big thing (and longs for small-town girl Sherri, fresh off the bus from Kansas with stars in her eyes). But the rock and roll fairy-tale is about to end when German developers sweep into town with plans to turn the fabled Strip into just another capitalist strip mall. Can Drew, Sherri, and the gang save the strip–and themselves–before it's too late? Only the music of hit bands Styx, Journey, Bon Jovi, Whitesnake and more hold the answer.

The show was nominated for five Tony Awards: Best Musical, Best Direction of a Musical, Best Costume Design, and Best Sound Design.

Risks & Challenges

Producing a musical is financially difficult.  There are certain financial obstacles that reveal themselves, above and beyond that of conventional theatre, let alone immersive theatre. SPACE, SET MATERIALS, MUSICIANS, COSTUMES, PROPS, SCENIC ELEMENTS, and SOUND AND LIGHTING EQUIPMENT require a certain budget. We need your help in making this dream a reality for the incredible artists and audiences who might not always have an opportunity to create stimulating and challenging work or attend it.

 

But Why?

While it may not seem like it, doing these productions during the summer give students in the area along with adults and community members a chance to work together and create art in ways they wouldn't be able to on any other occasion. While doing this production, cast and crew members will learn and strengthen acting techniques, team building skills, dance coordination, and vocal technique. Members will also learn what it takes to make a production from start to finish through heavy involvement in every step of the process that the production must go through. When doing productions like these, everyone is given a chance to participate whether it be onstage, backstage, during the development process, and even when helping build the set from the ground up.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have money together to contribute yourself? Here are some things you can do!

  • Share the event on any and all forms of social media you have! (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Pinterest, Myspace, etc. Whatever you can!)
  • Indiegogo has some really great features that you can use to easily share this around anywhere! Even spreading it by word of mouth to people you think would be up for donating would be a huge help!

story:
What Shall We Do With the Cello?

Something is wrong, the rain just won't stop. In a waiting room: the man with the newspaper, the lady with the veil, the old man with the stick. In a corner, the man with the cello is ceaselessly playing his instrument. Very quickly, the repetitive and obsessing tune drives them mad. They try, taking turns, to convince him to stop, but the man with the cello won't. He is playing, more and more passionately, alone against everybody... The others will have to organize themselves against this unexpected musical aggression...

From 8-12 February, Atelier Theatre Studio will present the UK premiere of 'What Shall We Do With the Cello?' at VAULT Festival 2017. This is a brilliant play for our times, written by a major European playwright, Matei Visniec, who sought asylum in France from Romania in 1987. Banned in Romania until after the fall of Ceausescu, this razorsharp and very funny play on intolerance and the terrible consequences of living without thinking was written from a place of deep experience.

Writer Matei Visniec


This, the UK premiere, is directed by Vasile Nedelcu, whose first production of 'What Shall we do with the Cello?' in Romania in 1998 sparked writer Matei Visniec to say the performance made him realise how much he had written the play in response to the fear and violence of the time.

The live cello performance features the music of leading avant garde composer Iancu Dumitrescu: “It’s hard to imagine a more imaginative, creative, colourful, and for that matter, better composition than Dumitrescu’s Medium III”. Dean Suzuki, “Option”, Los Angeles

What Others Say About Our Work

From Vasile Nedelcu's 1998 production of the play:

"Full of spirit, with a special type of humour, thoughtful and buffoon at the same time, a production that makes us laugh, yet stirring in us, almost secretly, a wave of anxiety.”  Cristina Dumitrescu , Adevarul

”A wonderful production with powerful, inciting theatrical images that he has brought about through fantasy, humour, and, last but not least, through an original and coherent style.” Natalia Stancu, Curierul National

What We Need & What You Get

The creative team are preparing for the show, the cast is on board and rehearsals start early January.  Cristina Catalina and Flora Smith are producing, and with the generous help of the Romanian Cultural Institute we have a chunk of the budget in place.  But in order to really get this off the ground - set, costume, lights, design, choreography, cast fees and travel, insurance and hopefully bringing Matei Visniec over to London, we need to raise £3,500. 

If we don't reach our goal, the producers will agree to work in kind - in fact, not only is Flora already committed to doing so, but she is also donating the first £500! (straight into the kitty, to save on indigogo fees...).  The cast and other creatives have agreed already very small fees as the baseline (we are run our productions on the principle of "open book accounting for theatre" and profit share), and the designer will be ever more usefully inventive within a lower budget. And the writer will have to Skype in one evening to see rehearsals ... But wifi is not great under the Waterloo tunnels, so we hope it won't come to that!

To thank you for your donations, we've got tasty Romanian treats on offer, postcards from the creative team thanking you, tunes emailed to you, perhaps from our cellist or perhaps sung by our very own lark, Simona Armstrong, finalist of Andrew Lloyd Webber's BBC series "How Do You Solve a Problem like Maria?", and playing THE LADY WITH THE VEIL in our show... and more! 

Simona Armstrong

The Impact

Remember when Nigel Farage said “he thought people would be concerned if a group of Romanians moved in next door”?  Well if we reach our £3,500 target the producers will personally send him a ticket to the first night and graciously invite him to dinner with the (largely Romanian!) cast and crew. 

Aside from Mr Farage and his views, we hope to spark debate and connection in our audiences, widen the repertoire of European scripts on the British stage, and hopefully plant the seed for a tour. What we also really want though, is to give you a great, unforgettable night!

Risks & Challenges

Even with your donations, we're still relying on box office sales going well, and we have to cover certain costs in advance of receiving any money. So it's a little scary until we reach the target....

Finances aside, our team of both cast and creatives are all experienced, passionate professionals, whose experiences range from planning and running a multi-disciplinary Fun Palace festival across several indoor and outdoor spaces at the Lyric Hammersmith; lecturing at Central St Martin's and designing for feature films, operas, and immersive events; acting in HBO dramas and on the stage of the Vienna English Theatre; and fostering projects and partnerships that promote life-long learning, expression and international collaboration. So the production your money will support is in good hands!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please book your tickets early, get the word out and share our campaign, and news about the show. 

Tickets are on sale at http://www.vaultfestival.com/event/what-shall-w...

and our social media links are:

www.facebook.com/events/806239486184016/

https://m.facebook.com/ateliertheatrestudio/

@VAULTFestival

#VAULT2017

And if you can, do help us to get there, be it £5 or £500. See you at the show, and thank you!

Va asteptam la spectacol si va multumim pentru sprijin!

story: It's a musical
story_txt: It's a musical

story:
A bit about us...

Bread & Goose make theatre for curious audiences. We aim to create visually-striking and narratively driven theatre with a social conscience. We are excited by untold stories and under-represented groups, and we seek to present new perspectives and challenging points of view to our audience, allowing space for response and dialogue. The team for this production are: Alison Neighbour, Kate Lovell, Jon Mcleod, Jo Shapland, Rhiannon White, Lucy Nicholls, and Nia Skyrme.

RETURN

RETURN is our latest project. We are working on a windswept beach in South Wales to create a new theatre production that explores the untold stories of military wives - their hopes, their dreams, their joys and their sorrows. We are exploring what it means to perpetually wait, and how ancient myth meets modern truth in the stories of Penelope in  Homer's Odyssey, and modern day military wives living in South Wales. The site and weather will be part of the production, and we're researching ways that we can work with, rather than against, the weather in this wild location where the geology and elements echo the story and emotions we are exploring.

The production is in the early stages of development, and the first stage of work was supported by National Theatre Wales' start up scheme "Waleslab". The video you can see up there is the documentation of what we made then. The next stage will involve the creative team revisiting the site for a further week of research and development in October. During that week here's what we'll be getting up to:

*Mapping audience journeys through the site. What will the production feel like for an audience? Where will we take them? What will happen? We can only figure this out by being onsite with the full creative team, allowing scenography, sound, narrative, and dance to interweave and respond to the weather and the landscape.

*Testing our sound sensors! We've got some amazing sensors that we plan to use to create sound activated by the weather, and we need to test them with the wind, sun and rain on the site.

*Meeting local military wives and running introductory workshops - welcoming new voices to the project and listening to their stories. If all goes well, they will have the opportunity to participate in the final production and receive professional training in performance and backstage roles.

*Sharing our work so far - on the last day we'll have a public sharing so everyone can see what we've made. We're working on a public beach, so being open about the work is really important to us, and we want to make close connections with the local community.

Why is this important?

This kind of research and development work is super important as it allows us to lay the groundwork for a fantastic and inclusive piece of theatre that's properly researched and provides an engaging experience for audiences and a valuable learning opportunity for professional artists and community participants.

Specifically, your contribution will go towards funding a Producer and  a Participation Officer for the project. These people will work with us to develop relationships with the local military and civilian communities, so we can offer workshops to women on military bases who don't have easy access to arts or other activity provision. They will support the creative team by sorting out licensing, permissions, publicity, and engagement, and they are the backbone of the entire project.

 

What We Need 

As many of you will know, arts funding has been cut massively over the past few years, and competition is intense. Even with Arts Council funding, we still need to raise 25% of our total budget from other sources. OK, we thought, let's ask our friends and audiences if they can help. We need to raise £1000 to cover the cost of a Producer and a Participation Officer for 1 week each. This will help us reach our 25% target for the Arts Council, and give this project a real boost, allowing us to do the community outreach work that's at the heart of this project and the story we want to tell. At the end of our R&D week, we'll be in a really good place to apply for production funds from some of the big trusts and foundations - we just need a little kickstart with the fundraising from our supporters.

Whatever you can give, be it £1 or £100, we'll be incredibly grateful, and your contribution will really count towards the production. 

Just so you know, we're applying to Arts Council Wales to cover the main expenditure on the project - a £4000 grant from ACW will cover our creative team fees (director, designer, writer, choreographer and composer); fees for 3 performers to join us for 2 days; a production manager to oversee the practical stuff and keep us safe; a license to work on the site; and our transport to and from the site. We're also really pleased that National Theatre Wales have given us the money for our sound sensors, and we're very grateful to our wonderful mentors in the industry and Vale of Glamorgan council for giving up their time for free in support of this project.

We believe everyone should get paid fairly, and whilst wages in the arts will never be high, we always pay at least ITC minimum. Everyone working on this project will receive £500 for the equivalent of a weeks work.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone can help financially - many of you will be fundraising for your own projects, or might prefer to give to charity, or you just simply can't afford to be giving cash to everyone who asks. If that's you, then we'd be super grateful if you could share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in either supporting us, or finding out about the project. We'd also be really happy if you would like to join our mailing list if you haven't already, and come and see the show when it's ready. If you're local to Dunraven, please come and say hello when we're on the beach - we'd love to see you! And if you live on the Beachley or St Athan Barracks, we'd especially love to hear from you.

We'll be posting updates here and on our website once our fundraising is done and we have our dates finalised.

What do you get in exchange?

We thought it kinda defeats the object of fundraising if we spend all the money on sending out gifts, and we're sure you'd rather we spent it on the actual thing we're fundraising for, so we've decided the best way to say thank you is to include you in the process of making the show - after all, you've helped pay for it! So for everyone who contributes (unless you'd rather opt out), we'll send you updates and little video snippets of our work throughout the process of research and development, and invite you to comment and share your thoughts. We really value audience feedback, so don't be shy about telling us what you really think! We'll also be offering discounted tickets for the finished production to all of our supporters once we're at that stage, and we'll be pleased to invite you along to special aftershow events too.

Thank you so much for reading this far. Please share our campaign with your networks, it would mean a lot to us.

Bread & Goose

story_txt:
A bit about us...
Bread & Goose make theatre for curious audiences. We aim to create visually-striking and narratively driven theatre with a social conscience. We are excited by untold stories and under-represented groups, and we seek to present new perspectives and challenging points of view to our audience, allowing space for response and dialogue. The team for this production are: Alison Neighbour, Kate Lovell, Jon Mcleod, Jo Shapland, Rhiannon White, Lucy Nicholls, and Nia Skyrme.
RETURN
RETURN is our latest project. We are working on a windswept beach in South Wales to create a new theatre production that explores the untold stories of military wives - their hopes, their dreams, their joys and their sorrows. We are exploring what it means to perpetually wait, and how ancient myth meets modern truth in the stories of Penelope in  Homer's Odyssey, and modern day military wives living in South Wales. The site and weather will be part of the production, and we're researching ways that we can work with, rather than against, the weather in this wild location where the geology and elements echo the story and emotions we are exploring.
The production is in the early stages of development, and the first stage of work was supported by National Theatre Wales' start up scheme "Waleslab". The video you can see up there is the documentation of what we made then. The next stage will involve the creative team revisiting the site for a further week of research and development in October. During that week here's what we'll be getting up to:
*Mapping audience journeys through the site. What will the production feel like for an audience? Where will we take them? What will happen? We can only figure this out by being onsite with the full creative team, allowing scenography, sound, narrative, and dance to interweave and respond to the weather and the landscape.
*Testing our sound sensors! We've got some amazing sensors that we plan to use to create sound activated by the weather, and we need to test them with the wind, sun and rain on the site.
*Meeting local military wives and running introductory workshops - welcoming new voices to the project and listening to their stories. If all goes well, they will have the opportunity to participate in the final production and receive professional training in performance and backstage roles.
*Sharing our work so far - on the last day we'll have a public sharing so everyone can see what we've made. We're working on a public beach, so being open about the work is really important to us, and we want to make close connections with the local community.
Why is this important?
This kind of research and development work is super important as it allows us to lay the groundwork for a fantastic and inclusive piece of theatre that's properly researched and provides an engaging experience for audiences and a valuable learning opportunity for professional artists and community participants.

These people will work with us to develop relationships with the local military and civilian communities, so we can offer workshops to women on military bases who don't have easy access to arts or other activity provision. They will support the creative team by sorting out licensing, permissions, publicity, and engagement, and they are the backbone of the entire project.

Even with Arts Council funding, we still need to raise 25% of our total budget from other sources. OK, we thought, let's ask our friends and audiences if they can help. At the end of our R&D week, we'll be in a really good place to apply for production funds from some of the big trusts and foundations - we just need a little kickstart with the fundraising from our supporters.
Whatever you can give, be it £1 or £100, we'll be incredibly grateful, and your contribution will really count towards the production. 
Just so you know, we're applying to Arts Council Wales to cover the main expenditure on the project - a £4000 grant from ACW will cover our creative team fees (director, designer, writer, choreographer and composer); fees for 3 performers to join us for 2 days; a production manager to oversee the practical stuff and keep us safe; a license to work on the site; and our transport to and from the site. We're also really pleased that National Theatre Wales have given us the money for our sound sensors, and we're very grateful to our wonderful mentors in the industry and Vale of Glamorgan council for giving up their time for free in support of this project.
We believe everyone should get paid fairly, and whilst wages in the arts will never be high, we always pay at least ITC minimum. Everyone working on this project will receive £500 for the equivalent of a weeks work.

story:
SPELLBINDERS WAS CREATED TO INSPIRE ARTS AND EDUCATION.
IT'S MIND-BOGGLING AND IT'S FREE.

This year, world champions of magic drew over 3,500 people into local libraries and the Performing Arts Center, and it was all FREE. Please help us make the magic happen again next year.

CLAIM YOUR PERKS FOR DONATING TODAY, INCLUDING ONCE IN A LIFETIME EXPERIENCES!

Our collectible Posters, Coffee Mugs, and T-Shirts are extremely cool and broadcast to the world that you're one of us.  If you're even more obsessed with magic consider one of our unbelievable perks like-- The Ultimate David Copperfield Experience, lunch at the Magic Castle with Julie McCullough, Private Instruction with Jonathan Pendragon, Career Consult with Rick Marcelli,  as well as books, tricks, props and one-of-a-kind collectible magic ephemera.

You can even get into the World's Greatest Insider Magic Event, next October: the Thin Air Summit, featuring a cornucopia of the greatest Gold Medal-winning World Class magicians ever assembled in one spot. We're adding more perks all the time, so come back often. Scroll down to check out the perks on this page that were too weird to mention upfront!

LIMITED EDITION SPELLBINDERS GLOW IN THE DARK POSTER

OFFICIAL SPELLBINDERS T-SHIRT (Front)

OFFICIAL SPELLBINDERS T-SHIRT (Back)

SPELLBINDERS COFFEE MUG



F.A.Q.

Q: When do I get my perks?

A: All perks will be sent within 6 - 8 weeks after the campaign ends.


Q: Is my donation tax-deductible?

A: Education Renaissance of Nevada Initiative is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.  All donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law.  You should consult with your C.P.A. or tax preparer.  Tax ID: 46-1195169.  (A list of the fair market value of each perk can be requested by e-mail from info@thinairsummit.info.)


Q: What about my t-shirt?  How do I make sure I get the right size?

A:  We’ll be contacting you to find out your exact size (and we’ll even include a sizing chart so you can be sure of getting exactly what you want.)


Q:  What about my lunch with Lance Burton in Las Vegas or Julie McCullough at the Magic Castle in Hollywood?  Are you flying me out?

A:  No.  None of the perks include travel or accommodations.  Isn’t it enough that these cool people are making themselves available for you?  Now you just have to get there to experience the awesomeness.  If that means a crazy road trip where your car breaks down in the middle of nowhere and you have to hitchhike and you get picked up by a Scary Stranger who turns out to be the love of your life and you live happily ever after and never even make it to redeem your perk-- you’re welcome.  If, on the other hand, the Scary Stranger chops you up like salami, you can rest assured that Matt Damon will probably play you in the inevitable movie version that will follow.  (And in the film you probably get rescued at the last minute and still make it to the assigned perk where you meet the celeb who will probably be played by Scarlett Johansson.)


Q: So can I order anything on the menu for lunch or dinner?

A:  Yes, with the exception of booze.  Our non-profit can’t pay for any purchases of alcohol.  (Look on the bright side-- you’ll be the Designated Driver.)


Q:  I’m confused about this Brain Stimulator.  Will it actually make me smarter?

A:  Hard to say.  Kind of depends on how smart you are now.  Would you be interested in some magic beans?  Now those babies really work.

BRAIN STIMULATOR

story:
What Is This All About?

I'm Malinda Logan - actress, director, producer, philanthropist and humanitarian. Ever since high school when I first read My Sister, My Sister, I felt so connected to the main character Sue Belle's plight and her strength to conquer her demons. As I grew older, I noticed every family has demons that they turn into skeletons - no matter what social, cultural or economic class you were lucky enough to be born into.

My Sister, My Sister delves into the life and mind of an African-American girl growing up in a lower working class and extremely volatile household in the 1950s. She must cope with an over-religious but loving mother, an alcoholic but well-meaning father, and a promiscuous but overlooked older sister.

Dealing with complex issues of mental illness, religious conviction, and racial identity, My Sister My Sister reminds us that African-Americans developed coping mechanisms in a world that was not designed for them to flourish. Directly tied with situations that are prevalent in the black community today, reviving this award-winning production will stimulate the parallel between decades of stagnant cultural norms and social deficits across all human families.

Contribute to a story that needs to be told.

Why My Sister, Why Now?

I am an African-American woman who grew up with a small family in New Orleans Louisiana, playing next to statues of Jim Crow, allowing Caucasian boys and girls to feel my skin because they “just don’t know,” and being chastised and ignored within black and white communities because of the darkness of my skin tone.

I have cried myself to sleep at night because I've needed to comfort friends, foes and those I barely knew over matters of abuse, mental anguish, rape, economic injustice and hardship. I've learned that these struggles have no boundaries and neither does our love and support.  I am now a NYC-based artist, actor, fundraiser, philanthropist, multi-degree and ivy-league graduate. My proudest moment was when I became a humanitarian.

Since the onset of the Black Lives Matter movement, the fighting against and within the black community at large grew stronger. I believe it’s been allowed to fester because people don’t understand their history and can’t empathize with struggles being passed down from generations. Even though this play was written in the 1970s and is set in the 1950s, it's still very relevant to today.

This play will give audiences a look into how people are reacting - to many wounds that were never healed – in and out of the black community.

What Do You Need & What Will I Get?

It takes a lot to revive an award-winning production- to do it justice- on the part of the playwright, the actors, and the creative team and crew. We need to design sets, rent costumes, secure licenses, pay for insurance, rent the theater, and so much more! From the director to the assistants - everyone will provide an enormous amount of talent and work, and they need to get paid for their valuable expertise. The more funds we can raise, the more money will be reinvested into a quality show! The expense breakdown is pictured below. 

 

This production is partially funded by The Puffin Foundation. However, we need your support to see it to fruition. There are plenty of perks including shout outs, tickets, VIP invitations, and more!

Why Should I Care? Who Is Involved?

We are serving the community with a human experience that enlightens, questions, resurrects and resolves.  Talented actors, crew and creators will be given a creative outlet to share their energy with the public, with agents, managers and producers. Ray Aranha's surviving family will be invited to experience his work and thoughts one more time. 

This revival from the 1974 Broadway run will enrich lives in the audience, on the stage, and behind the scenes.

Playwright

Ray Aranha (Playwright. 1939-2011) was an actor, playwright, stage director and drama teacher. In 1974, he won a Drama Desk Award for Outstanding New Playwright for My Sister, My Sister. He also wrote and toured in a one-man show, I Am Black, and later originated the role of Jim Bono in Fences on Broadway, on tour and in Los Angeles. Additional regional and Broadway credits include Macbeth, Othello, Master Harold and the Boys, and Parade - the Tony Award-winning Broadway Musical/Drama - where he originated the role of Newt Lee. 

In addition to stage work, Ray appeared in various film and television roles. He co-starred in ABC's series Married People and The Heights. He's also appeared on The Cosby Show, Are You Afraid of the Dark?, New York Undercover, and Law & Order, and in films like Dead Man Walking, Deconstructing Harry, and Maid in Manhattan.

Ray won numerous awards including the Audelco Pioneer Award. He also founded the community theater Prometheus' Fire in 2003. Dedicated to producing new plays, Ray said that Prometheus' Fire was "inspired by the spirit of Prometheus, who defied the rules and powers of the gods and gave the fire of creation to mankind." 

Executive Producer

 

Malinda Logan (A.D. and Sue Belle) is the Executive Producer of My Sister, My Sister. She also plays Sue Belle in the production. As a creator, she produced a film and directed staged plays. Her short film Open House was a semi-finalist in the July 2017 Hollywood International Film Festival, and she's in development of two other short films - a light comedy about the variance of height and a narrative based on her ancestor - Marie Laveau, the Voodoo Priestess of NOLA. She also directs fun, light-hearted theater plays.

Malinda is a trained actress - received a BFA in Acting from Ithaca College (studied in NY and London); attended American Academy of Dramatic Arts (Los Angeles) for Camera Acting for Film and Television; and taken improv and character courses at Upright Citizens Brigade . 

She’s performed in numerous theater and film productions like The House of Blue Leaves, Trojan Women, Quilt A Musical Celebration and Sexual Dependency. This is Malinda's first production as Artistic Director and Executive Producer. Check out her website or follow her on IG. www.malindalogan.com     

Director

Arthur French (Director) is an actor and director whose career has spanned more than 50 years. As a director, he has worked with HB Studio, the New Federal Theatre, the Classical Theatre of Harlem, African Arts Theater Company, and The Morningside Players. He has directed Fences, One Last Look, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, and A Raisin in the Sun. 

He acted in numerous film, tv and theatre productions - on and off Broadway. Arthur was a supporting character in the 1976 comedy film Car Wash and in films such as Crooklyn and Red Hook Summer. His Off-Broadway acting credits include Driving Miss Daisy, Two Trains Running, Julius Caesar. He's been in 8+ Broadway shows and his last Broadway production was the 2013 Tony Award nominated revival of The Trip to Bountiful with Cicely Tyson, Vanessa Williams and Cuba Gooding Jr. Arthur is also a founding member of The Negro Ensemble Company.

He has won several awards in both acting and directing including five AUDELCO Awards for Excellence in Black Theatre, OBIE Award for Sustained Excellence of Performance, Lucille Lortel Award for Two Trains Running, a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Coalition of Theaters of Color and the Paul Robeson Citation from AEA.

Associate Producer

Sean C. Turner (AP) built his empire from the world of stand-up comedy. He has toured nationally and appeared on Comic View. Since then he has creatively mastered his presence in the theater world. He was part of the Audelco winning (Best Revival 2015) cast of Fences playing Bono. He appeared alongside Malinda Logan and under the direction of Arthur French in the HB Studio production One Two andThen Three. He was also in The Heights Players production of Ruined by 2-time Pulitzer Prize Winner Lynn Nottage.

Look out for the updates as more of the creative team and cast are hired!

What Can I Do? How Can I Help, Other Than Donate?

Any donation amount will make such a huge impact! You can also help by spreading the word, coming to see our show, leaving a nice comment!

  • Share this campaign using the Indiegogo icons above!
  • Email your friends, family, co-workers!
  • Come to see the play! Ticket details coming soon! 
  • Leave a nice comment using the icons above!
  • Share on social media: Twitter, Facebook, Instagram!
  • Use hashtag #mysistermysister
  • Tag @malindaluv on instagram or twitter

You've done so much already by reading through this campaign and expressing your interest. THANK YOU for supporting the arts!

 

THANK YOU

She also directs fun, light-hearted theater plays.

She’s performed in numerous theater and film productions like The House of Blue Leaves, Trojan Women, Quilt A Musical Celebration and Sexual Dependency. This is Malinda's first production as Artistic Director and Executive Producer. Check out her website or follow her on IG. www.malindalogan.com     
Director

Arthur French (Director) is an actor and director whose career has spanned more than 50 years. As a director, he has worked with HB Studio, the New Federal Theatre, the Classical Theatre of Harlem, African Arts Theater Company, and The Morningside Players. He has directed Fences, One Last Look, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, and A Raisin in the Sun. 
He acted in numerous film, tv and theatre productions - on and off Broadway. Arthur was a supporting character in the 1976 comedy film Car Wash and in films such as Crooklyn and Red Hook Summer. His Off-Broadway acting credits include Driving Miss Daisy, Two Trains Running, Julius Caesar. He's been in 8+ Broadway shows and his last Broadway production was the 2013 Tony Award nominated revival of The Trip to Bountiful with Cicely Tyson, Vanessa Williams and Cuba Gooding Jr. Arthur is also a founding member of The Negro Ensemble Company.
He has won several awards in both acting and directing including five AUDELCO Awards for Excellence in Black Theatre, OBIE Award for Sustained Excellence of Performance, Lucille Lortel Award for Two Trains Running, a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Coalition of Theaters of Color and the Paul Robeson Citation from AEA.
Associate Producer

Sean C. Turner (AP) built his empire from the world of stand-up comedy. He has toured nationally and appeared on Comic View. Since then he has creatively mastered his presence in the theater world. He was part of the Audelco winning (Best Revival 2015) cast of Fences playing Bono. He appeared alongside Malinda Logan and under the direction of Arthur French in the HB Studio production One Two andThen Three. He was also in The Heights Players production of Ruined by 2-time Pulitzer Prize Winner Lynn Nottage.
Look out for the updates as more of the creative team and cast are hired!

What Can I Do? How Can I Help, Other Than Donate?
Any donation amount will make such a huge impact! You can also help by spreading the word, coming to see our show, leaving a nice comment!

Share this campaign using the Indiegogo icons above!
Email your friends, family, co-workers!
Come to see the play! Ticket details coming soon! 
Leave a nice comment using the icons above!
Share on social media: Twitter, Facebook, Instagram!
Use hashtag #mysistermysister
Tag @malindaluv on instagram or twitter


You've done so much already by reading through this campaign and expressing your interest. THANK YOU for supporting the arts!
 
THANK YOU

story:
About Richard III in Japan

Richard III is one of Shakespeare’s most recognizable “anti-heroes,” scheming and manipulating his way into power at the expense of enemies and loved ones alike. This production is set against the backdrop of Japan’s Genpei War, circa 1185, and focuses exclusively on Richard’s story arc. The production features a dual chorus conceit: one vocal chorus performs Shakespeare’s words into microphones, while a second physical chorus is devoted to bunraku puppetry. All actors involved will also create live foley.

At Lean and Hungry Theater, we believe that narratives like Richard III transcend time and place. Our job, as storytellers, is to present that narrative in ways that speak to our wide-ranging and diverse audience.

The team:

Adapter/Director: Kevin Finkelstein
Assistant Director/Dramaturg: Jessica Clark
Puppetry Consultant: Martin Holman
Lighting Designer: Katie McCreary

Vocal Chorus: Jon Jon Johnson, KyoSin Kang, Momo Nakamura, Andrew Quilpa, Elizabeth Ung, Mary Yee

Physical Chorus: Claire Derriennic, David Johnson, Micaela Mannix, Peter Mikhail, Eirin Stevenson

Where Your Money Goes

Richard III is Lean and Hungry's most ambitious performance to date. Your generous donation will allow us to achieve the following:

  • Productions are always free of charge to children 12 and under.
  • We are working with Martin Holman, the Director of the Bunraku Bay Puppet Theater, the only company in America to exclusively perform bunraku. Martin will train our dual choruses (14 actors!) in the art and design of bunraku puppetry.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution to Richard III, there are still ways you can help us:

  • Help spread the word! 
  • Follow and engage with us on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Sign up to be a volunteer usher by sending an email to leanandhungrytheater@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

This is the debut work of The Cartographers. It is a lean, whirlwind of a story, likely unlike most things you've ever seen in a theatre before. The tragic, heartening, poetic, and wonder-filled world of Raymondo is shared by one actor and many cassette tapes in a short but powerful hour of performance. It is fast and fun and will hopefully leave you feeling nostalgic and cozy inside for days after the show.

We chose this play because of Annie Siddons' extraordinary words and also for the opportunity it offers to share work in a nontraditional way. Rather than touring theaters around the country, we plan to bring this to smaller community-centric venues where art is less often encountered. Currently we're targeting Chicago, Boston, New York, and Houston, but Denver, Milwaukee, and several other cities are in our sites as well. Our window of performance is January - April 2019.

The Cartographers is the brainchild of Hal Cosentino and Jeremy Ohringer. Hal is an actor and playwright who has developed work at The New Colony and The Neo-Futurists in Chicago and at New Georges and Mom’s Insurance in NYC. Jeremy Ohringer is a director and playwright currently finishing his MFA at Boston University. His recent work includes Melancholy Play (a chamber musical), Mother Courage and Her Children, and adaptations of Three Sisters, The Iliad, The Odyssey, and Lord of The Flies.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're approaching this process economically and as we have no existing donor base to turn to, we want to make this happen (relatively) inexpensively. To travel and tell this story, we're seeking funds for the following:

  • Production costs (sound materials, costumes, production expendables, properties, etc)
  • Artist pay (our playwright, our actor, our composer, our photographer, our director, etc)
  • Travel costs (flights, transport in cities, accommodations, food and drink, etc)
  • Administrative expenses (marketing costs, platform fees, PR materials, grant fees, etc)

We're asking for your help in making this happen, and want you to feel like you're joining us on the adventure. Contributors will not only receive fabulous perks like cassette tape art, custom postcards from the road, and even their own "Cape of OK!", but they'll also become part of the journey. We'll keep backers updated at every step along the way: when we're starting rehearsals, when we're coming to a new city, and when we begin sharing this beautiful story.

The Impact

We believe this production will not only be a way to bring people to intimate spaces and build community, but this will also be an opportunity to introduce audiences to new types of stories and people and ways of making theatre. We hope to meet audiences where they live and use theatre as it's best meant to be used--as a tool that inspires empathy, that reminds us to always consider the depths and personhood of those around us, and that leaves you with new thoughts about the world that make you giggle and ponder for weeks and months and years.

For us, the mission to bring work to radically diverse audiences across the country is vital for our personal success but also for the furthering of the cause of modern American theatre. This is a wonderful story to advance that effort, and we hope it is something you can be part of.

story:
Drum Roll Please...

 

 

A Little Bit of Where?

We are a new theatre company built by two emerging theatre practitioners who are very dedicated to the art of musical theatre and bringing people joy with it. We are bringing our first musical, called A Little Bit of Life (or ALBOL for short) to stages of London. We have performed this musical once during our university years and back then it was a huge success. We believe that this story is still relevant now and we want to do the best we can to bring it to our audience. 

 

Financialities

A £1000 that we're raising isn't a big number in the world of musical theatre but we know that being smart this will be enough to cover the costs of this production. We've already found a very good venue and tech support but know we need more funds for:

  • Props, to have something for our actors to play with.
  • Set design, so our stage can look fabulous.
  • Costumes, so our actors can look en fleek.
  • Pay our actors for all the amazing effort that they're putting in.

(The actors will be our priority in raising funds. We want to be sure that they are properly rewarded for their amazing work - you can see their beautiful faces at www.glittertheatrical.co.uk/albol)

 

Yeah, but why...?

The whole reason why we're doing this is because we want to use the power of theatre to bring a bit more positivity around to the world. It is not a mystery that we have a lot to worry about nowadays and there are so many theatre pieces produced that want to express it.What we want to offer is a glimpse of light and try to get our audience to take a look from a different perspective on the world.

 

Track Record - Better Than A Train

In the past we performed this show at our university and at the time it was a huge success with the audience and got nominated for our student union's award for the best show of the year.  We have a unique vision, intuition and  enthusiasm as well as experience and professionalism to make it all work. With a little help we can deliver a fabulous show to watch.

The Risky Business

There always are risks with artistic productions. In our heads it all sounds amazing and although we already have had some positive feedback there is always a chance that people won't be interested in seeing it this time. Perhaps it's an objection to the majesty of Madonna or a problem with high levels of cheese...who knows!

We believe that this is unlikely as we will all put our all in and give our best effort to make sure that this will succeed. We can promise not to waste a single penny given to us and be sure that the show is the best it can be so it can attract as wide an audience as possible.

 

Christine, that's all we ask...

Of course we understand that not everyone is able to support us financially but there are other ways you can help. If you share our fundraiser on you social media or tell your friends that can already be a huge contribution. You can (totes should) also come and see the show in December!! Be sure to follow us on social media to stay up to date with all the exiting things we do and spread the word as much as possible.

 

We Love You

Thank you for even considering donating to us and we know that with some help we will be able to inject into our day to day routines a little bit of life!

 

 

We're Uber Social:

Facebook: /GlitterTheatrical

Twitter: @glittertheatre

Instagram: @glittertheatrical

Website: www.glittertheatrical.co.uk

 

We're Questions Enthusiasts

Drop us a line? hello@glittertheatrical.co.uk

story:
About Us.

Arion Productions and Rigmarole Productions are passionate about new writing, with a proven track record of bringing high-quality productions with exceptional casts and production teams. We believe Dark Sublime is a truly beautiful play and our leading lady, Marina Sirtis is so impressed by it, that she will be travelling from her home in LA to perform the leading role in London's West End. 

Why we need your help.

Finding funding for brand new pieces of theatre is hard. We decided to create this campaign as a way to give some incredible perks to those who want to see this out-of-this-world production and by doing so, you will be helping support the show and in return, we want to give you some once in a life-time experiences and exclusive rewards as a supporter of Dark Sublime.

What happens if we don't reach our funding goal?

We are raising investment and the production will go ahead regardless of our fundraising goal. However, this is a way for us to produce a piece that is only limited by our imagination rather than our financial constraints. In short, the more we raise, the more we can do.

Spread the word.

Please do spread the word. We have a Twitter and Instagram account @DarkSublimePlay and we can't wait to welcome you to Dark Sublime at Trafalgar Studios and we hope you take advantage of these extra special support initiatives.

story:
My name is Anthony Robustelli and I’m a musician, composer, producer, author, and historian based in Brooklyn, NY. Over the years I’ve produced numerous projects, toured the world, and collaborated with countless musicians on music that not only entertains, but is socially conscious. Even so, no project has been as important to me as my musical, The So-Called President.

The So-Called President examines the catalyst for the current tone of the country – the occupant of the White House – and tells a timeless story; one of people standing up for the rights they deserve, have come to expect and now realize are not guaranteed. My goal and sincere belief is that The So-Called President can do for modern day American politics what Hamilton did for the birth of the nation – crystallize this moment in time and empower citizens to make their voices heard.

I have started this campaign to raise the funds needed to stage The So-Called President on election night 2018 and for one week thereafter. With your support I will be able to do a week of performances to gain interest of outside producers to stage the musical for an extended run. There are a number of tiers available for contributors, so please give your support to make this show possible.

If we meet our goal, the show will open on election night and run for a week. If we do not meet our financial goal, depending on the amount raised, we will launch the show for election night and work toward a longer run at some point in the future.

Want to help but can’t donate? Get the word out by sharing this page with your friends. You can also get more info by going to thesocalledpresident.us

With gratitude,

Anthony Robustelli

story:
NCT is Moving To Main St: Short Summary

Hello there! We are the cast and crew of National Comedy Theatre Phoenix (NCT).

And after 10 years in the Fiesta District we are pleased to have the opportunity to relocate to the heart of Downtown Mesa at 214 W Main St!

It is an opportunity for NCT to bring the spontaneous and interactive improv that our audiences love to the vibrant and arts and entertainment district of Main St!

We are thrilled to be on the verge of creating a community that will bring even more laughter and creative opportunities to the people of Mesa!

Here’s What We Need Help With

Now, we plan on re-purposing much of our existing theater equipment and structures for our new downtown home.

However, we are in dire need of some theater upgrades to ensure the audience has a great experience for every performance.  

Number one: our new theater will need new chairs for brand new butts! Yessir, it is absolutely vital to keep Arizona’s heinies happy. And those yellow squeaky chairs from our old theater will no longer be with us (please see “old chair bonfire perk”... I’m kidding. That’s not a perk. But that would be cool...)

Number two: we need to upgrade the current electrical situation at the new place, which was most definitely not created with a theater space in mind!  ...While we as performers would get all giddy at the idea of performing with lanterns in hand, the audience however, would be very underwhelmed.

Number three, our final need: Our new space is like one long hall... which makes it pretty weird when the cast needs to change or do the businessy type paper work...

So, we need to build a dividing wall between theater stage and seating area, aka "Where the Magic Happens" and the "Green Room" and "Office" where all the "Non-Magical and Kinda Weird Real World Stuff Happens"

Please note: as many of our fans know, we at NCT lean heavily towards creating a fun “weird” space by reusing and re-purposing found, reclaimed, vintage, and alternative materials. We aim to continue that tradition in our new home at 214 W Main St.  However, we cannot reclaim our old yellow chairs or our current electrical system. Nor can we remove one of our walls and haul it over. (We tried and it fell out of the truck while on the US 60. Again, I’m kidding. Why do I keep doing this?)

This is why we’re reaching out for some loving help from our Arizona family!

Now you’re probably wondering, “OK, so why the heck is this so important to me?”

We shall list the ways!

  • NCT Phoenix is home to the valley and has been supported by local Arizona residents for 10+ years.
  • We provide weekend shows for families and friends to come together and laugh away the day’s pains. (So many, right?)
  • Supporting NCT also supports Arizona’s local economy. We’re like the local farmer’s market that sells laughs. We’re like the local kale grower of laughter. (We can also hook you up with some kale, if you need it.)
  • NCT’s extracurricular program teaches Arizona youngsters from all over the state how to improvise, which studies have shown can help increase cognitive development, improve social skills, and promote one’s ability to problem solve in real-time(1).
  • NCT also teaches teenagers and adults the fundamentals of improv with our high-level improv training courses that have helped people become more confident in their businesses, say “yes” to what life has to bring, and even strengthen relationships with our “improv listening training.”
  • And for many of our fans that come see us every weekend (you know who you are… yes we are talking to you, [Your Name]) NCT is another home. We aim to make this new version of home just as amazing.

What's In It For Me?

Hooo boy! Have we got some Perks for you! Everything from ticket packages to custom haikus to one of a kind VIP experiences! Check 'em out and be assured that we want YOU (the Audience!) to get as much out of your contributions as we do!

I Want To Help, But Things Aren’t “Lining Up” As I Want Them To...

Hey, we tooooootally get it. Life happens, am I right (*elbow nudge, elbow nudge*)...

So here are some other great ways that would mean the world to us:

  • Share this lovely post on Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat, or Twitter. Even MySpace and Craigslist and The New York Times (if they let you).
  • Talk to everyone you know about sharing this post!
  • And finally come see us perform! You still have time to make it out to one of our final performances at 1111 S Longmore AND you can be one of the first folks to laugh it up at one of our very first shows in our new home at 214 W Main St!
 

Source: https://www.cc.gatech.edu/~riedl/pubs/magerko-c...

Please note: as many of our fans know, we at NCT lean heavily towards creating a fun “weird” space by reusing and re-purposing found, reclaimed, vintage, and alternative materials. We aim to continue that tradition in our new home at 214 W Main St.  However, we cannot reclaim our old yellow chairs or our current electrical system. Nor can we remove one of our walls and haul it over. (We tried and it fell out of the truck while on the US 60. Again, I’m kidding. Why do I keep doing this?)
This is why we’re reaching out for some loving help from our Arizona family!
Now you’re probably wondering, “OK, so why the heck is this so important to me?”
We shall list the ways!

NCT Phoenix is home to the valley and has been supported by local Arizona residents for 10+ years.
We provide weekend shows for families and friends to come together and laugh away the day’s pains. (So many, right?)
Supporting NCT also supports Arizona’s local economy. We’re like the local farmer’s market that sells laughs. We’re like the local kale grower of laughter. (We can also hook you up with some kale, if you need it.)
NCT’s extracurricular program teaches Arizona youngsters from all over the state how to improvise, which studies have shown can help increase cognitive development, improve social skills, and promote one’s ability to problem solve in real-time(1).
NCT also teaches teenagers and adults the fundamentals of improv with our high-level improv training courses that have helped people become more confident in their businesses, say “yes” to what life has to bring, and even strengthen relationships with our “improv listening training.”
And for many of our fans that come see us every weekend (you know who you are… yes we are talking to you, [Your Name]) NCT is another home. We aim to make this new version of home just as amazing.

What's In It For Me?
Hooo boy! Have we got some Perks for you! Everything from ticket packages to custom haikus to one of a kind VIP experiences! Check 'em out and be assured that we want YOU (the Audience!) to get as much out of your contributions as we do!
I Want To Help, But Things Aren’t “Lining Up” As I Want Them To...
Hey, we tooooootally get it. Life happens, am I right (*elbow nudge, elbow nudge*)...
So here are some other great ways that would mean the world to us:

Share this lovely post on Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat, or Twitter. Even MySpace and Craigslist and The New York Times (if they let you).
Talk to everyone you know about sharing this post!
And finally come see us perform! You still have time to make it out to one of our final performances at 1111 S Longmore AND you can be one of the first folks to laugh it up at one of our very first shows in our new home at 214 W Main St!
 Source: https://www.cc.gatech.edu/~riedl/pubs/magerko-c...

story:
Overview

Founded in 2018, the Passage Theatre (TPT) is an emerging not-for-profit theatre company based in Chicago. With three successful seasons complete, we are launching our Winter (aka See You On the Other Side) Fundraiser in preparation for programming exciting new shows in 2021.

There are a lot of expenses that go into live performance (venue rental, design elements, insurance, administrative overhead, etc.), but at TPT our number one priority is our collaborators. This is reflected not only in how we treat the artists who work with us, but also in our budget--by far the largest line item in our budget for the past two years has been artist stipends. By contributing, you will help us support Chicago theatre artists, create a more equitable and accessible artistic community, and keep producing astonishing live performances. TPT is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, and all donations are tax-deductible.

Read on for more information about TPT, our history of producing original theatrical works, how we have used 2020 to improve our company, and where your money goes.

Plus, check out the perks for various levels of donation! You can earn a custom haiku, meme, or piece of embroidery, and even unlock a virtual hangout with our new Co-Artistic Directors!

 

Our Mission

Our mission, newly revised and expanded, is as follows:

With our artists, our audiences, and the stories we tell, The Passage Theatre seeks to create art that looks into the void with hope instead of dread.

We tell stories with truth and simplicity.
We create thought-provoking, minimalistic, ensemble-based theatre that is specific to its medium. Our work is driven by curiosity and the conviction that whimsy and humor are powerful ways to explore the universe.
 
We focus on humanity. 
We are a community-oriented company with faith in collaboration and transparency. We prioritize paying artists over buying things and believe human ingenuity is more essential than production budget in creating the spectacular. 

We believe in hope and innovation.
We value creativity over tradition, both artistically and institutionally. We continuously endeavor to establish and invent more equitable practices at all levels of our organization. Through these practices, we hope to advance our industry’s greater movement toward a more accessible Chicago theatre.


Track Record

To date we have produced three live productions and one virtual staged reading.


In November of 2018, TPT made its debut with the "gorgeous, melancholy saga" Spirits to Enforce by Mickle Maher (Chicago Reader). Directed by company member Will Quam, the show was a "tight, excellent production with a lot of HEART and bursting with talent from all ends" (PerformInk). "Skillfully crafted and beautifully acted ... the perfect inaugural production," Spirits to Enforce was included in Picture This Post's round up of Best Plays in Chicago.

Our second production, The Lessons, was an immersive collection of devised monologues written by the ensemble. Chicago Theatre Triathlon  called it a "feat of fiery talent" with "wildly imaginative direction" by Abigail Phelps. Structured like a living museum exhibit, each performance also featured the work of a different visual artist.



Our most recent production was the world premiere of Happy Birthday Mars Rover by Preston Choi, a kaleidoscope of scenes from the beginning of life on Earth to the extinction of humanity. Critics and audiences raved about this "Incredibly imaginative! Supremely rewarding" and "hilarious" production, "a beacon of hope for the future of playwriting and our humanity" (Around the Town Chicago, Rachel Weinberg Reviews, Chicago Theatre Triathlon).

The show was listed as a "Favorites Under the Radar" by Michael and Mona Heath and in Chicago Theatre Triathlon's "20 Must-See Moments in Chicago Theatre 2019." And the feedback we are perhaps the most proud of: Ada Grey, a 15 year old who has been reviewing plays for a decade, said, "It was an absolutely transformative piece of work and I definitely recommend seeing it. I loved it."


What We've Been Up To in 2020

When COVID-19 hit, we pivoted our spring 2020 production of All-One! The Dr. Bronner's Play to a virtual reading. Playwright Beth Hyland and the ensemble adapted the script to the new format, and the performance was very well received, even breaking our ticket sales goal! Chicago Theatre Triathlon called it "just what the doctor ordered ... a refreshing dose of comedy and clarity in the midst of a pandemic." 

Recognizing that theatre artists would be hard hit by the pandemic, we not only paid all the artists their original stipends, but used 50% of all proceeds from the virtual reading to boost those stipends further.

As for the rest of the year, we decided to postpone our fall reading series, The Current, so that we could honor our commitment to the selected playwrights and produce live readings of their plays. This will be our first project when we return.

Over the summer, we took the pause in programming to reflect on how to emerge post-pandemic as a stronger, more equitable company. Inspired in part by the words of We See You White American Theatre, we:

  • Revised our mission to affirm our commitment to artists and equitable practices
  • Shifted to a more accessible and intentional producing model
  • Increased transparency both internally and externally
  • Expanded our staff, company, and board
  • Reduced our board dues to $1 per year to remove financial barriers to board membership

Our work is not done, and we welcome feedback and suggestions, now and always. Learn more at www.thepassagetheatre.com.

 

What We're Raising Funds For

We have been able to adapt and refocus our energies during the pandemic, but we need your help to emerge from this challenging year strong and ready to continue sharing great art with you.

While some things are still uncertain, here's what we know for sure:

  • Our first project when we return will be The Current, a developmental reading series featuring four powerful new plays by an amazing slate of Chicago playwrights. Stay tuned for the announcement!

  • With our new staff and company members, we will select plays for full productions that fit both our aesthetic goals and our commitment to equity, diversity, and accessibility. In addition to supporting our company members, we will seek out artists we have never worked with before to find the best team to tell each specific story.

  • We will continue to prioritize artists in our budget. Recognizing the chronic underpayment of theatre artists, we have increased our artist stipends every year since our founding. In 2019, 40% of our total budget went toward paying our collaborators, and in 2020 we are projecting that number will reach 50-60%.

TPT has a Silver Seal of Transparency on Guidestar, where you can find our 2019 Form 990.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand the pandemic has brought on financial struggle for many people, especially artists and other independent contractors. If you are looking for other ways you can support TPT beyond the financial, here are some ideas!

  • Boost the signal by sharing this campaign with your friends and family (bonus points for including a caption about why you want to support TPT!)
  • Follow us on Facebook and Instagram, and sign up for our email list
  • Keep an eye out for updates about our programming and spread the word
  • Reach out to us at info@thepassagetheatre.com to inquire about volunteering opportunities
  • Designate The Passage Theatre Company as your chosen charity on Amazon Smile

story:
NEXT LEVEL: AN OVERVIEW

 

WHAT IS “NEXT LEVEL?”

Next Level is a new youth performing arts program created to provide professional level training from a team of experienced performers and performing arts educators of various disciplines. Students will come from all over the state of Ohio and vary in age.

 

MISSION STATEMENT:

Next Level is committed to providing quality performing arts training that not only embraces self-love and awareness, but explores the nuances of team-work and developing the mental discipline of becoming a performer. We are committed to doing this while simultaneously maintaining an inclusive, diverse, and safe space for all.

 

OBJECTIVES:

To provide the community with access to a variety of professional training in multiple performing arts disciplines. These disciplines include, but are not limited to, music, dance, theatre, and stage performance. 

Ultimately, it is our goal that our organization is known as a safe place for the youth to hone their performing arts skills, while also remaining a positive source that fortifies community performance.

 

WHAT NEXT LEVEL OFFERS:

  • Show Choir Program
  • Recreational Classes  
  • Master classes/Workshops 
  • Private Lessons 

 

WHAT WE NEED: 

Includes but is not limited to:

  • Arrangers
  • Bus Rental
  • Clinicians
  • COVID related safety items
  • Hotels
  • Licensing 
  • Musicians 
  • Registration Fees 
  • Rehearsal and Performance Space Rental
  • Seamstress
  • Scholarships

 

WHAT YOU GET:

  • The opportunity to change a young person's life through the arts!
  • Personalized cards from Next Level students and staff 
  • Next Level mailing with  student progress rehearsal and performance updates 
  • Access to donor exclusive classes
  • Discounts to select public performances (covid-19 permitting)

 

THE IMPACT

Accountability - Students are taught that they are a part of a team. They are expected to practice their skills both in rehearsal and at home, as not doing so impacts the group overall.

Time Management - Students are treated as professionals and are taught to be respectful and mindful of time. 

Physical Strength and Health - Dance and performance movement encourages students to lead a healthier, more active lifestyle.

Mental Focus - Students learn the power of focused and positive thinking, which is something they can apply to all other aspects of their lives.

Education - Teaching not only the physical technique behind performing, but the history, vocabulary and the impact that performing has had in society.

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

The biggest challenge we will face will be Covid-19. Traditionally learning is done in person but with the virus many aspects of the performing will be forced to adjust. This means we may be forced to develop new practices, techniques and develop entirely new ways of educating our students. 

Historically there have been many arguments that the performing arts are not an essential or necessary program for youth. Even though we know the value of the performing arts, that may present difficulty in receiving funding. 

 

OTHERS WAYS THAT YOU CAN HELP

If you can not donate, we would love for your help sharing our social media post as well as this page. Please feel free to be added to the Next Level mailing list for performance updates!
