story:
THE SHOW

Based on Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night”, Viola is an exciting new aerial theatre work exploring our heroine’s strengthening, fracturing and evolving psyche, using aerial and acrobatic movement to challenge and expand our understandings of gender performance and mental health. We had a fantastic premiere at the Scottish Mental Health Arts and Film Festival 2019 and are now seeking £3500 to help us cover transportation, artist accommodation and fees for our upcoming tour of Lowland Scotland and London.

Stretch Goal: We have had additional requests to perform Viola at the Mareel Theatre in the Shetland Isles, at the Comar Theatre on the Isle of Mull, and in Elgin in northeast Scotland! For these more remote venues we require an additional £5000. Help us get genderbending circus to the far corners to Scotland! 

ORIGINS OF VIOLA

Charlotte McKechnie (Creator/Director/Producer): I created Viola whilst studying the play as an actor - I was particularly struck by Viola’s sudden, unexplained silence in the finale when Duke Orsino commands her to return to her women’s clothing.  In many ways, the character of Viola fits Shakespeare’s heroine mould: noble-born, loquacious, quick-witted. But she also offers us a deeper glimpse into the darker side of Shakespeare’s work: the isolation, grief, and mental fracturing of an artist who suffered such extreme personal trauma in parallel with his meteoric success.

Choreography, dance and aerial became the perfect mediums to explore with the body what could not be expressed verbally, and they opened avenues to challenge our understandings of masculine or feminine movement and of how a ‘healthy’ or ‘anxious’ mind behaves. After recrafting a new script and storyboard, I formed a team of fellow Glasgow-based artists - Adam Wright (Choreographer, Performer). Rufus Huggan (Cellist), Zak Hassan (Violinist) – to bring the work to life. With a development period at the fantastic Aerial Edge circus school in Glasgow, we premiered Viola in the Scottish Mental Health Arts and Film festival to rave reviews (you can read one here!) and glowing audience feedback.

NEXT STEPS

We are now bringing Viola to venues in Glasgow, Edinburgh and the Scottish Borders (with “stretch” goals of the Shetland Isles and Elgin!) and then London. Along the way we are reaching out to schools by our venues to offer free school workshops that teach dance, circus and theatre skills and bring exposure to the arts to children with no other access.

9th October – Mac Arts, Galashiels

10th October – Platform Theatre, Glasgow

11th October – Assembly Roxy, Edinburgh

Further afield - Stretch performances at Elgin Town Hall and Mareel, Shetland!

15th February 2020 – Jacksons Lane, London

WHAT WE NEED

We have already raised £6000 from generous funding from Split Infinitive, Hope Scott Trust, Cross Trust, Labyrinth Foundation, the Eglinton Arms Hotel, the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland Diversity Fund, and supporters who attended our Spring Fundraising Dinner!

We need another £3500 to pay for transportation of our rig and artists, accommodation during the tour, promotional video and completing our artists fees.  Every pound raised will be crucially helpful in getting our show on the road and ensuring that we are able to pay and house ourselves.

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT

- Seeing LGBTQ perspectives at the centre of a narrative and discovering new ways of thinking about ourselves and our movement

- Offering new ways to understand Shakespeare: We don’t “dilute” Shakespeare- we have chosen key sections of the text and use the music and movement to make it accessible and enjoyable to everyone, regardless of previous enthusiasm for The Bard (I am a big fan - I realise not everyone is: but you might be after Viola!)

Most importantly, the Viola/Cesario story, though made singular in our story by exploring the genderqueer nuances of their identity, touches upon universal questions and fears: Who Am I? How do I engage with the world around me? Will people accept me? Everyone can - in their own way- relate to the idea of identity and roles in our community being tenuous or broken.

Our Viola story seeks to humanise the struggle to belong and to accept ourselves, coming to terms with the “Poor monster” inside us all. 

WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

As budgets continue to shrink, arts funding has never been harder: in previous centuries, creation has been facilitated by monarchs or religious institutions. In 2019, it increasingly falls upon the artist to self-fund despite high artistic quality and experience. 

In this climate, being funded by five separate competitive funds is unusual and testifies to the belief committees have had in what Viola can offer. But it still is not enough to cover the full cost of this rewarding yet financially costly artform 

We will still go on the road even if we fail to meet our goal, but we will not be able to reach as many schools and would not be compensated for the hundreds of hours that have gone into creating the show. But the show is here; we know how much audiences love it and are determined to share this story and the joy of physical theatre and music with as many people as we can!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If financially contributing just isn’t something you can do right now, we understand! (We’re starving artists - we really understand) BUT you can still hugely help us by spreading the word about this campaign and our show:

1) Share this campaign with friends, family and co-workers

2) Like our social media pages and share our posts! Follow us on Instagram (@CirqueViola) and on Facebook (@CirqueViola) - each new follower and post engagement helps new audiences find us!

3) Finally, come to our shows! Tell your friends, family, bitter enemies about the wonder of this exciting, challenging new work.   

 

WHO WE ARE

Charlotte McKechnie – Creator, Director, Producer

I am a Scottish theatre maker, producer and soprano based in Glasgow. Originally studying History & Literature at Harvard University and training as a soprano at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, as a creative entrepreneur I now focus on illuminating unheard stories and perspectives with emphasis on female-identifying creators and narratives. After working in the States as a producer & director (including productions at American Repertory Theatre and National Opera Center and Managing Directing Juventas New Music), I came back to Scotland and formed New Voices Theatre (originally Opera Eos) to stage female-written historic and contemporary opera and theatre works that have been lost or ignored. Viola is an exciting new branch for the company into physical theatre. 

Fun fact: I met Adam while he was throwing me off a flying trapeze board. It was not friendship at first throw. 

Adam Wright – Choreographer, Performer 

I am a circus artist from Glasgow and a graduate of the National Centre for Circus Arts in London, where I specialised in corde lisse (or ‘rope’!). I continue to perform internationally and teach throughout the UK and Europe while moving back to Scotland, so I share what I learned and grow circus in my hometown. In my choreography, I’m particularly interested in analysing, blending and breaking the boundaries of gender, sexuality, dance, theatre and circus.

Fun fact: I do not remember throwing Charlotte off the board. 

And meet our amazing musicians!! -

Zak Hassan - Violinist

Zak is an Irish/Iranian Violinist currently in his second year at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, studying with Tamás Fejes. He grew up in Northern Ireland and began taking lessons at the age of seven. By the age of eleven, Zak was winner of Northern Ireland’s Primary School Musician of the Year and was invited to perform in the House of Commons in London as a result. He made his Concerto debut at the age of sixteen, playing Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto in E minor with his local community orchestra. Since moving to Glasgow, Zak has had the opportunity to play alongside the RSNO and has been involved in performances in venues such as The Glasgow Royal Concert Hall and City Halls.

Rufus Huggan - Cellist

Rufus Huggan is a cellist and composer living in Glasgow. A graduate of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, he has performed for audiences internationally as well as touring extensively across the UK with his dynamic, rhythmic style. 

As a composer, Rufus’ music has been played on television and radio across the world. As a recording artist he has worked with an eclectic selection of musicians and performers, collaborating in a dense mixture of styles and genres.

After recrafting a new script and storyboard, I formed a team of fellow Glasgow-based artists - Adam Wright (Choreographer, Performer). Rufus Huggan (Cellist), Zak Hassan (Violinist) – to bring the work to life. With a development period at the fantastic Aerial Edge circus school in Glasgow, we premiered Viola in the Scottish Mental Health Arts and Film festival to rave reviews (you can read one here!) and glowing audience feedback.NEXT STEPSWe are now bringing Viola to venues in Glasgow, Edinburgh and the Scottish Borders (with “stretch” goals of the Shetland Isles and Elgin!) and then London. Along the way we are reaching out to schools by our venues to offer free school workshops that teach dance, circus and theatre skills and bring exposure to the arts to children with no other access.9th October – Mac Arts, Galashiels10th October – Platform Theatre, Glasgow11th October – Assembly Roxy, EdinburghFurther afield - Stretch performances at Elgin Town Hall and Mareel, Shetland! 15th February 2020 – Jacksons Lane, LondonWHAT WE NEEDWe have already raised £6000 from generous funding from Split Infinitive, Hope Scott Trust, Cross Trust, Labyrinth Foundation, the Eglinton Arms Hotel, the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland Diversity Fund, and supporters who attended our Spring Fundraising Dinner!We need another £3500 to pay for transportation of our rig and artists, accommodation during the tour, promotional video and completing our artists fees.  Every pound raised will be crucially helpful in getting our show on the road and ensuring that we are able to pay and house ourselves.WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT- Seeing LGBTQ perspectives at the centre of a narrative and discovering new ways of thinking about ourselves and our movement- Offering new ways to understand Shakespeare: We don’t “dilute” Shakespeare- we have chosen key sections of the text and use the music and movement to make it accessible and enjoyable to everyone, regardless of previous enthusiasm for The Bard (I am a big fan - I realise not everyone is: but you might be after Viola!)Most importantly, the Viola/Cesario story, though made singular in our story by exploring the genderqueer nuances of their identity, touches upon universal questions and fears: Who Am I? How do I engage with the world around me? Will people accept me? Everyone can - in their own way- relate to the idea of identity and roles in our community being tenuous or broken.Our Viola story seeks to humanise the struggle to belong and to accept ourselves, coming to terms with the “Poor monster” inside us all. WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORTAs budgets continue to shrink, arts funding has never been harder: in previous centuries, creation has been facilitated by monarchs or religious institutions. In 2019, it increasingly falls upon the artist to self-fund despite high artistic quality and experience. In this climate, being funded by five separate competitive funds is unusual and testifies to the belief committees have had in what Viola can offer. But it still is not enough to cover the full cost of this rewarding yet financially costly artform We will still go on the road even if we fail to meet our goal, but we will not be able to reach as many schools and would not be compensated for the hundreds of hours that have gone into creating the show. But the show is here; we know how much audiences love it and are determined to share this story and the joy of physical theatre and music with as many people as we can!OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPIf financially contributing just isn’t something you can do right now, we understand! (We’re starving artists - we really understand) BUT you can still hugely help us by spreading the word about this campaign and our show:1) Share this campaign with friends, family and co-workers2) Like our social media pages and share our posts! Follow us on Instagram (@CirqueViola) and on Facebook (@CirqueViola) - each new follower and post engagement helps new audiences find us!3) Finally, come to our shows! Tell your friends, family, bitter enemies about the wonder of this exciting, challenging new work.    WHO WE ARECharlotte McKechnie – Creator, Director, ProducerI am a Scottish theatre maker, producer and soprano based in Glasgow. Originally studying History & Literature at Harvard University and training as a soprano at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, as a creative entrepreneur I now focus on illuminating unheard stories and perspectives with emphasis on female-identifying creators and narratives. After working in the States as a producer & director (including productions at American Repertory Theatre and National Opera Center and Managing Directing Juventas New Music), I came back to Scotland and formed New Voices Theatre (originally Opera Eos) to stage female-written historic and contemporary opera and theatre works that have been lost or ignored. Viola is an exciting new branch for the company into physical theatre. Fun fact: I met Adam while he was throwing me off a flying trapeze board. It was not friendship at first throw. Adam Wright – Choreographer, Performer I am a circus artist from Glasgow and a graduate of the National Centre for Circus Arts in London, where I specialised in corde lisse (or ‘rope’!). I continue to perform internationally and teach throughout the UK and Europe while moving back to Scotland, so I share what I learned and grow circus in my hometown. In my choreography, I’m particularly interested in analysing, blending and breaking the boundaries of gender, sexuality, dance, theatre and circus.Fun fact: I do not remember throwing Charlotte off the board. And meet our amazing musicians!! -Zak Hassan - ViolinistZak is an Irish/Iranian Violinist currently in his second year at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, studying with Tamás Fejes. He grew up in Northern Ireland and began taking lessons at the age of seven. By the age of eleven, Zak was winner of Northern Ireland’s Primary School Musician of the Year and was invited to perform in the House of Commons in London as a result. He made his Concerto debut at the age of sixteen, playing Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto in E minor with his local community orchestra. Since moving to Glasgow, Zak has had the opportunity to play alongside the RSNO and has been involved in performances in venues such as The Glasgow Royal Concert Hall and City Halls.Rufus Huggan - CellistRufus Huggan is a cellist and composer living in Glasgow. A graduate of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, he has performed for audiences internationally as well as touring extensively across the UK with his dynamic, rhythmic style. As a composer, Rufus’ music has been played on television and radio across the world. As a recording artist he has worked with an eclectic selection of musicians and performers, collaborating in a dense mixture of styles and genres.

story:
What are we doing?

Our junior company, ilYoung 2019, is developing a new production with ten young and emerging artists from Sweden and abroad. We are developing two new works for which the creative process began on the 1st July 2019. We have been working 8 hours a day, 6 days a week totalling 288 studio rehearsal hours. This does not include the many hours that go towards production, mentoring, performances, workshops and tour planning.

 

How and why it all started…

We started ilYoung 7 years ago, creating successful projects every year and offering professional experience to young and emerging artists. We aim to assist these artists in the demanding transition between student and professional by equipping them with the mental, physical and creative tools necessary to dive into their professional careers. 

Every year since 2013, ilYoung has brought together ten young artists from Sweden and abroad to create a new production in a professional environment. This process takes place in residencies across Sweden and the company then tour the new creation nationwide. Throughout the entire process the artists are mentored and supported by professionals who are particularly experienced in working with emerging and young artists. 

 

SUCCESS!

The majority of the involved ilYoung artists have secured professional jobs working with companies such as GöteborgsOperans Danskompani, Royal Swedish Ballet, The Swedish Royal Dramatic theatre (Dramaten), Regionteater Väst and ilDance in Sweden and with companies abroad such as Nationaltheater Mannheim (Germany) Theater Osnabrück (Germany) Black Box Dance company (Denmark) Gwyn Emberton Dance (Wales) Chrysalis London (UK) and CATAPULT Dance (Australia). Additionally, many of these young artists have joined and/or initiated independent projects.

 

Why we need your help to reach our goal of 100,000 SEK

Despite this growing legacy and growing success and as an entirely independent company, ilYoung doesn’t receive regular financial support from any institution or official funding body in Sweden to run this project. As a result, the directors of ilDance, Israel Aloni and Lee Brummer are required to start again from square one, every year.

The project is both invaluable for the contemporary dance field and provides immediate and clear development to young artists. We are extremely passionate to continue creating these opportunities for future generations of dance artists. This is where we need your help.

The money we acquire from this campaign will go towards paying the salaries of the creative team and covering costs of travel and accommodation for the company to tour nationally.  

We have managed to secure 350 000 SEK, constituting the resources to cover 78% of the total of this year’s costs. We need your help to cover the remaining 22% of our costs which total 100 000 SEK. See specification below.  

 

Budget ilYoung 2019 - Specification of costs:

Choreographers/artistic directors (2 people)            120000 SEK 

Choreographers’ assistance/rehearsal directors      44000 SEK

Production coordinator                                                      25000 SEK

Lighting Designer                                                                 30000 SEK 

Sound design                                                                         20000 SEK

Graphic designer                                                                   15000 SEK 

Costumes, props                                                                   12000 SEK 

Lighting equipment                                                               6000 SEK

Promotional materials, printing costs                             6000 SEK

Travel creation process                                                      40000 SEK 

Travel tour                                                                               35000 SEK 

Accommodation creation process                                 34400 SEK

Accommodation tour                                                         32000 SEK

Living expenses (per diem)                                               15000 SEK

Documentation (video & film)                                          15000 SEK 

Insurance                                                                                     600 SEK 

TOTAL COSTS ilYoung 2019                                           450 000 SEK

 

Sources from whom we have already secured the total of 350 000 SEK:

Barbro Osher Pro Suecia Foundation  (USA)

Region Gävleborg  (through Dans Plats Skog) 

Härnösands Folkhögskola

Dans Västernorrland 

Israeli Embassy in Sweden

Gislaved Kommun 

Balettakademien Stockholm 

Balettakademien Gothenburg

Danscentrum Norr

Tickets sales

 

 

Who are we?

Choreographers: Israel Aloni, Lee Brummer

Performers and creative collaborators: 

Inanna Argati (Sweden)

Ella-My Blomdahl (Sweden)

Marni Green (Australia)

Karolina Janhager (Sweden)

Jacinta Jeffries (Australia)

Naomi Kats (Israel)

Valtteri Keinänen (Finland)

Linn Lindström (Sweden)

Rebecca Lång (Sweden)

Kady Mansour (Australia)

Choreographers assistant/ rehearsal director: Lotem Regev

Lighting advisor: Johan Bjellsäter

Sound design: Sascha Budimski

Production coordinator: Anna Henriksson

Graphic Designer: Gordon Beveridge 

Crowdfunding video maker: Harald Nilson 

 

Our tour schedule:

24 Aug, 18.00 - Balettakademien, Scen studio Fyra Stockholm, Sweden 

25 Aug, 13.00 - Balettakademien, Scen studio Fyra Stockholm, Sweden 

26 Aug, 19.00 - Balettakademien Gothenburg, Sweden 

27 Aug, 13.00 - Balettakademien Gothenburg, Sweden 

30 Aug, 13.00 - Glashuset Gislaved, Sweden 

7 Sep, 13.00 - Murberget Länsmuseet Västernorrland, Härnösand, Sweden

8 Sep, 13.00 - Murberget Länsmuseet Västernorrland, Härnösand, Sweden

10 Sep, 19.00 - Konstepidemin, Gröna Rummet, Gothenburg Sweden (part of GIBCA - Gothenburg International Biennale for Contemporary Arts)

11 Sep, 19.00 - Konstepidemin, Gröna Rummet, Gothenburg Sweden (part of GIBCA - Gothenburg International Biennale for Contemporary Arts)

 

Thank you!

Your donation is extremely appreciated. We value your commitment to supporting the arts by supporting the artists involved in ilYoung 2019. We hope to see you at the show and please feel free to share this video and information with your netowork.

You can also find out more information about tickets for the shows HERE.

 

Risks and challenges

We have calculated our risks before starting the process and put the prioritised the experience and development of the young artists above anything else. We now trust in the generosity of our friends, family, colleagues and online community; you!

If we do not make our funding goal, the tour will move forward in a different version than planned and the involved young artists will still receive and benefit from this immersive experience and important process. However, the artists in the creative team will not be paid for the work they have done and are still doing on the creative aspects and behind the scenes production.

story:
Help Us Make Trans Theatre in Atlanta

Written by Sloka Krishnan and directed by Thandi DeShazor, The Grand Transsexual Draweth Nigh is a magical trans Halloween mystery play; a plea for ritual and transcendence; and an exploration of identity, authenticity, assimilation, and the ways in which we are consumed and alienated by our own desires. It follows a young gay trans man of color and three of his friends on the night when they once and for all become the devourers, not the devoured.

Performances will take place on April 25-26 and May 2-3, 2020, at The Bakery, with a developmental staged reading (free and open to the public!) at Out Front Theatre on March 25. We are excited to be producing this play supported in part by a grant from the City of Atlanta Mayor's Office of Cultural Affairs, but the grant will only cover about half our costs. That's where you come in!

Your contribution supports:

  • paid opportunities for local queer and trans artists of color;
  • increased diversity of style and content in the Atlanta theatre scene;
  • a new conversation on identity, authenticity, and assimilation in the contexts of queer and trans subcultures and gendered/racialized hierarchies of desirability; and
  • a sexy and unsettling new theatrical experience!

Together, we can stretch the edges of what Atlanta theatre can be and contribute to the foundation of a vibrant and growing experimental scene—all while centering queer and trans voices of color.

Who We Are

Thandiwe "Thandi" DeShazor (director, co-producer)  is an actor, writer, producer, and director. He is the writer/director of Natural Woman: An Aretha Story, Never Too Much: A Luther Story and Shut Your Mouth: A Little Richard Story. His Atlanta acting credits include Angels in America and The Legend of Georgia McBride. He has appeared in AMC’s "Lodge 49, "Murder Calls," "Fatal Attraction," and "Swamp Murders."

Sloka Krishnan (playwright, co-producer) is an Atlanta-based playwright-lyricist interested in magic; extravagance; ritual; camp; and the disavowal of moral purity and coherent identity. He was a 2017-2018 Horizon Theatre Playwright Apprentice and a 2017 Lambda Literary Fellow in Playwriting. His work has been read and performed in Atlanta by Happy Accident Theatre and Working Title Playwrights; at Horizon's 2018 apprentice showcases; and at the 2019 and 2018 One-Minute Play Festivals at Actor’s Express. Sloka’s writing has been described as subversive, multilayered, and eviscerating (by a boy he once slept with) and as darkly surreal comedy (by a legitimate online publication).

What Your Donation Supports

All performers, designers, and technicians will be paid to participate in the project. This represents over 50% of our budget. Other costs include the $1,700 venue fee; materials (props, scenery, costumes, lighting, sound); marketing (flyers and programs); and rehearsal space. Of course we will be scrappy where we can be! The bulk of your contribution will support paying artists for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Are you connected to a company that might be interested in sponsoring the event? Sponsor benefits include complimentary tickets, program ad space, a vendor table at the show, and more. Contact us and we can talk more! Sponsorship details are also available on our ticket page.
  • Speaking of which, buy tickets! Pre-sale tickets help us gauge how many people will be in attendance and how much ticket income we can count on—all of which will support production costs.
  • Show up and spread the word! We want to sell out, and we want to reach as wide a community as we can. You can RSVP on Facebook and invite others here. When we report back to the City, we want to be able to show that there's a diverse audience for this type of theatre in Atlanta.

story:
READY FOR GREAT MUSIC AND HILARIOUS FUN? YOU'VE COME TO THE RIGHT PLACE.

It's a fabulously fun cabaret show: Luscious! and the Pool Boy: Kicking, Screaming, and Singing! 

That deliriously delightful chanteuse, Luscious, and her piano-playing Pool Boy have their way with the Great American Songbook! On top of the piano or underneath it, champagne-swilling Luscious and her Pool Boy will bring great music to the masses in new and unusual ways. They are ready to foist their wicked, wacky ways on Los Angeles, Palm Springs, and San Francisco. And beyond!

We are Kikélomo Adedeji (Luscious!) and Jake Jensen (Pool Boy) and we are actors, singers, and writers, based in Los Angeles. We started creating content in 2016 and call our production company Heaven on Earth because that’s what movies, TV, and theatre are for us.

We also have our serious side and think writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie said it best:  “… the problem with stereotypes is not that they are untrue, but that they are incomplete.”

Our other Heaven on Earth creations include a TV comedy about a take-no-prisoners narcissistic middle-aged (at least in her own mind) televangelist in Nashville who is married to a closeted Tennessee State senator, a feature film comedy about three estranged adopted adult siblings, each of a different race, who must compete against each other in a triathlon in order to win their late uncle’s fortune, a TV drama about the Four Corners area of the southwest focusing on four intersecting families, and a saga that spans 80 years about a Chinese man who sails to San Francisco in 1920 and becomes a famous chef while juggling the two families he has in Chinatown. View all of our projects at https://www.heavenonearth.productions/

We want to put Heaven on Earth on the map and let people know who we are and why we do what we do. To bring all of these culture-changing projects to the world, we are asking for your support. There are many ways to support us: financial donations, share our crowdfunding campaign with your friends and colleagues, come see our cabaret show when we visit your town, follow us on social media, spread the word and cheer us on! It all helps build audience and connection with the people who value and support what we do and why we do it.

Everyone who supports us at any level will receive our undying appreciation and your name will go on the Heaven on Earth Productions website “Initial Funders Wall” and stay there in perpetuity.

Here's our budget for Luscious! and the Pool Boy: Kicking, Screaming, and Singing!

Performances Planned for January 2020

Budget is based on development starting November 1st through January 31st

Item

 

Dollar Amount

Director

 

$5,000

Accommodation and Travel for performers, musicians, Hair and Make-up Artist

 

$6,500

Music Director

 

$3,000

Musical Arrangements

 

$2,000

story_txt:
READY FOR GREAT MUSIC AND HILARIOUS FUN? YOU'VE COME TO THE RIGHT PLACE.It's a fabulously fun cabaret show: Luscious! and the Pool Boy: Kicking, Screaming, and Singing! That deliriously delightful chanteuse, Luscious, and her piano-playing Pool Boy have their way with the Great American Songbook! On top of the piano or underneath it, champagne-swilling Luscious and her Pool Boy will bring great music to the masses in new and unusual ways. They are ready to foist their wicked, wacky ways on Los Angeles, Palm Springs, and San Francisco. And beyond!We are Kikélomo Adedeji (Luscious!) and Jake Jensen (Pool Boy) and we are actors, singers, and writers, based in Los Angeles. We started creating content in 2016 and call our production company Heaven on Earth because that’s what movies, TV, and theatre are for us.We also have our serious side and think writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie said it best:  “… the problem with stereotypes is not that they are untrue, but that they are incomplete.”Our other Heaven on Earth creations include a TV comedy about a take-no-prisoners narcissistic middle-aged (at least in her own mind) televangelist in Nashville who is married to a closeted Tennessee State senator, a feature film comedy about three estranged adopted adult siblings, each of a different race, who must compete against each other in a triathlon in order to win their late uncle’s fortune, a TV drama about the Four Corners area of the southwest focusing on four intersecting families, and a saga that spans 80 years about a Chinese man who sails to San Francisco in 1920 and becomes a famous chef while juggling the two families he has in Chinatown. View all of our projects at https://www.heavenonearth.productions/We want to put Heaven on Earth on the map and let people know who we are and why we do what we do. To bring all of these culture-changing projects to the world, we are asking for your support. There are many ways to support us: financial donations, share our crowdfunding campaign with your friends and colleagues, come see our cabaret show when we visit your town, follow us on social media, spread the word and cheer us on! It all helps build audience and connection with the people who value and support what we do and why we do it.Everyone who supports us at any level will receive our undying appreciation and your name will go on the Heaven on Earth Productions website “Initial Funders Wall” and stay there in perpetuity.Here's our budget for Luscious! and the Pool Boy: Kicking, Screaming, and Singing!Performances Planned for January 2020Budget is based on development starting November 1st through January 31st

story:
Hello!  We're RedBellyBlack Theatre Company.  Thanks so much for visiting our page.  We won't take up loads of your time: we'll just briefly explain why we need some help.

In July 2016 we performed a show called "A Year From Now" in London, and we had a truly ace team of actors and creative bods working on it.  The show was devised and put together by the group, and everyone committed lots of their valuable time and energy to it.

We've been invited to put the show on again at a festival in January, and we really want to do it, but this time we want to pay the team.  Last time everyone went out on a limb and agreed to a profit share, but we really cannot ask them to work for free again.  It's just not fair.  

The show is a really wonderful bit of physical theatre, and it's based on the lives of real people.  We interviewed twelve people and asked them how they felt about time: "Where do you see yourself a year from now?" and "What do you make time for?" for example.  These real people are all friends, relatives and/or loved ones of someone from our creative team, and their answers are hilarious, moving, disturbing and unforgettable.  They deserve to have their stories told by people who love them.

We've carefully worked out how much we should be paying everyone for the rehearsal period, and we would really love your help to make these wages a reality.  

Here's how it breaks down: we need £120 for insurance (otherwise we can't get the actors into the room to start with), and then £3,080 for the wages.  That pays 5 actors + 1 director + 1 producer £220 per week for 2 weeks of work.  

In an ideal world we would pay everyone £425 a week (Equity Minimum), and we're going to work hard to find that extra money elsewhere.  But raising just over three grand felt like a reasonable amount to ask for in a crowdfunding forum, and we hope that even a small wage will help our team to keep buying groceries and paying bills.

Any donation of any size would be genuinely amazing, but if you're really strapped for cash (which we TOTALLY understand, obviously), then please just share this page with your social media audiences and help us to pay our people.  

Thank you so much.

story:
Hard Core Logo: Live

BFL Theatre is excited to present the Toronto and Eastern Canadian premiere of Hard Core Logo: Live — A Punk-Ass Play. This is a stage version of the cult Canadian film Hard Core Logo (directed by Bruce McDonald, with screenplay by Noel S. Baker from the novel written by Michael Turner). Adapted by Michael Scholar Jr., with brand new music by legendary Vancouver punk star Joe "Shithead" Keithley (D.O.A), the show will take place March 9-26 at Lee's Palace, upstairs in the Dance Cave.

This will not be a “seated-quietly-in-the-dark” affair, by any stretch of the imagination. No way, man! It's a theatre narrative and a punk concert, rolled into one fat joint. You will experience the full theatrical telling of the HCL story — the highs, the lows, and the laughs — while you and your crew let loose to the live punk music.

The manic drumbeats will make your heart palpitate, 
    the screeching guitars will make your body gyrate, 
        the booming bass will make your lungs vibrate 
            and the vocals will have you roaring like a primate…..
                            and wait…..
The booze at the bar will help your liver hydrate.
Gonna be a helluva party, mate!

And… what better venue for this musical mayhem and searing storytelling than the historical and iconic Lee’s Palace? If the walls could only talk of the the legendary musical acts that have been there before! Come scream, sweat, laugh, cry, dance and drink… it's a celebration of Punk Music, Canadian Legend, and Indie Theatre.

For more info on the team and advance ticket sales, visit http://hardcorelogolive.com.

BFL Theatre is an independent, non-profit Toronto theatre company focused on producing socially relevant theatre that mixes live music and drama. The company was founded in 2010 to produce the cult musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch. This production toured Canada and had a hugely successful run at the Drake Underground in 2013.

At BFL Theatre, we not only want to tell the story of HCL, but we also want use it as a vessel to raise awareness around some themes present in the show; namely, the mental health and addiction issues that performance artists in Canada face, particularly when touring. We are teaming up with Toronto’s Centre for Addiction and Mental Health to include pre-show talks with the audience on this topic.

The spirit of punk is alive and well, but we need your help to get “the show on the road”.

Follow us on Twitter & Instagram @BFLTheatre
#HardCoreLogoLive #indieTO #indieunite #canadiancult

Find us on Facebook www.facebook.com/breathefeellove

 

HOW WILL YOUR SUPPORT HELP?

Here is a breakdown of all the different costs for this show, so you can see where your money goes:

Personnel
Playwright & creators: $2000
Director: $1250/week x 4 weeks; $5000
Actors (5): $700/week x 6 weeks: $4,200/actor or $21,000
Stage Manager: $850/week x 6 weeks; $5100
Assistant Director: $1000/week x 4 weeks; $4000
Musical Director: $1000/week x 4 weeks; $4000
Technical Director: $1000/week x 4 weeks; $4000
Production Designer: $3000
Publicist: $3000

Other
Audio, Lighting, Scenic Production: $6000
Venue Rental: $5000
Rehearsal Space: $1600
Artists’ Transportation: $1200

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are huge fans of this show and want to help, there are lots of ways you can show your support...

Do you know some friends or relatives who would love to be a part of this show and campaign? Help us out by forwarding it to those who you think would love to invest.

If you really would like to be a part of this project but can't help financially, there are other ways that you can get involved!

If you would like to volunteer during the run of the show, please contact us. We will have positions available during each performance.

 

PLEASE NOTE: All merchandise perks will be available to pick up at the venue during the run of the show. We will hold them for you at the merch booth! If you are not planning to attend the show, but still want to support us and get perks that include merchandise, please note your mailing address at checkout and we will ship these to you (within Canada) after March 26th, 2017.

The Dance Cave at Lee's Palace is not a barrier-free venue; if you have concerns about accessibility please let us know and we will endeavour to make alternate arrangements for you.

story:
Who Are We?

Wildcard creates theatre to shine a light on the absurdity of the world we live in, as well as nurturing those who are passionate about pursuing a career in the arts. Established in 2015, Wildcard has enjoyed many success so far, having produced three fringe productions in 2016 to critical acclaim. Most recently Wildcard has become a charity (no. 1170677), it consists of 10 members and is governed by 4 trustees.

If you would like to know more about us please go to our website www.wildcardtheatre.co.uk or drop us an email at info@wildcardtheatre.co.uk and we'd be happy to answer any questions you may have. Alternatively, just say hello and we can have a nice chat!

Why This Play?

After Party tells an important story about the need for human connection and how tragedy can shatter the ability to find it. This is so apparent in our divided world today, where the need to connect with each other is being over shadowed by the hatred that divides us. In this microcosm After Party challenges how we are operating as a society and poses the question, is it possible to accept the past and stand side by side in the present?

Put simply, it asks, is it possible to love instead of hate?

How Will Your Donation Help?

Wildcard receives no core funding and is run by a small, dedicated team of volunteers. In order to put After Party on we need to raise £8,000. This is to cover production costs including insurance, set, costume, lighting, props, rehearsal space and marketing campaign to get bums on seats! Also, Wildcard has recently signed the Equity Fringe Agreement - Professionally Made, Professionally Paid - as we are dedicated to paying our actors and creatives the industry standard wage. This has been a huge step for Wildcard and it's a cause we strongly believe in and it's your donations that will help stop unethical employment in this industry. 

We're currently applying for multiple grants and awards as well as organising fundraising events to help reach our total budget, but we will be short without the kind support of the general public. We are eternally grateful for any donation, however big or small, you may be able to give. 

In return we can offer you a selection of Wildcard goodies as well as mentions on our social media platforms and website.

If you have any questions or would like to know how your money is being spent, please don't hesitate to email us at info@wildcardtheatre.co.uk and we'll keep you updated on exactly where it is going and what it is helping us to achieve. Alternatively, if you are interested in becoming a long term supporter of Wildcard please email joseph@wildcardtheatre.co.uk. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes it is not always possible to offer financial support! 

However, you can help us to make this campaign and production a success by sharing, liking, talking about and generally spreading the word about this campaign, the production and also about Wildcard in general. 

We're on Twitter @wildcardtheatre Facebook /wildcardtheatre and Instagram @wildcardtheatre 

We hope you will support us in anyway you can.

Thanks for reading and have a lovely day! 

W I L D C A R D

story:
About Empty Rooms

Jennifer, a brilliant coder, is preparing for a conference that could make or break her tech company. But between Sara, the mom re-entering the workforce; Natalie, the whip-smart but underutilized (and unpaid) intern; Frank, the coder-turned-admin in over his head; Margot, the PR specialist called in to reverse an inevitable crisis; and one-sided convos with Ada Lovelace, the world's first (and long-dead) computer programmer, Jennifer has her work cut out for her.  Can Jennifer’s revolutionary new program save the company, or will savage rivalries and personal egos destroy everything?

Empty Rooms is an irreverent comedy that will be touring across Atlanta, taking over the common rooms of tech offices, coding schools and universities. Each performance will be a truly unique experience for audiences, as we'll be transforming each of our Host Venues into a theatrical set. We'll be utilizing their existing furniture, lighting, sound systems, projection equipment and room configurations, and each venue will host a max of three performances. As far as we know, nothing quite like this tour has ever been done before!

For this production, we've sought feedback from professionals currently working in the tech sector to make sure our story accurately portrays the opportunities and challenges of working in tech. The script has received developmental work and feedback at playwriting centers across the country, and named a semi-finalist of one of the top playwriting awards in the country: The Eugene O’Neill Playwrights Conference.

Performances & Host Venues

  • Tuesday, Sept. 19 @ 7pm at General Assembly Atlanta at Ponce City Market (click to reserve your seat)
  • Wednesday, Sept. 20 @ 6pm at The Garage at Tech Square (click to reserve your seat)
  • Thursday, Sept. 21 @ 7pm at Alkaloid Networks in Inman Park (click to reserve your seat)
  • Friday, Sept. 22 @ 6pm at General Assembly Atlanta at Ponce City Market (click to reserve your seat)
  • Thursday, September 28 @ 6pm at Strongbox West (click here to reserve your seat)
  • Sunday, Oct. 1 @ 3pm at Emory Center for Ethics (click to reserve your seat)
  • Wednesday, Oct. 4 @ 8pm at Lewis Finch Studios in Stone Mountain (click to reserve your seat)
  • Sunday, Oct. 8 @ 7pm at Emory Center for Ethics (click to reserve your seat)

Our Team

Our team of professional, Atlanta-based artists have individually worked at some of the top theaters and cultural centers in town, including the Alliance, Atlanta History Center, Dad's Garage, 7 Stages, Serenbe, Actor's Express, Horizon, and others.

  • Producer: Found Stages
  • Playwright: Annie Harrison Elliott
  • Director: Nichole Palmietto
  • Co-Artistic Director: Neeley Gossett
  • Production Manager: Kara Procell
  • Stage Manager: Max McCreary
  • Design Team: Catalyst Arts Atlanta
  • Props Master: A. Julian Verner
  • Costume Designer: Chelsea Steverson
  • Sound Designer: Bennett Walton
  • Projections Designer: Liz Schad
  • Fight Choreographer: Barrett Doyle
  • Film Team: Gaslight Picturehouse
  • Cinematographer: Evan Williams
  • Film Editor: Alan Goldman
  • Casting Director: Emily Kleypas
  • Jennifer: Candace Mabry
  • Frank: Jeffery Zwartjes
  • Natalie: Jin Jo
  • Sara: Mary Russell
  • Margot: Holly Stevenson
  • Dramaturg: Addae Moon
  • Press Relations Manager: Megan Schaeffer
  • Business Sponsorships Manager: Julia Hudgins

About Found Stages

Since 2014, Found Stages has been taking an innovative approach to plays: We don't do them in theaters. Instead, we partner with businesses, community organizations and nature centers to present our stories in the actual settings in which they take place. Empty Rooms will be our third fully produced project, and our largest to date. We're finding our niche, and want to be here to stay. You could say, that with this production, we're claiming a room in our Atlanta home.

Found Stages believes that theater is the best way to build empathy among (not-so-) different groups of people. We present our plays in site-specific locations because we believe that's the best way for our stories to reach the people that most need to see them. Empty Rooms has the potential to spark positive and productive conversations about how we build our future and tell its stories. Laughter is the best medicine, remember?

Since our first production - at Dunwoody Nature Center in 2014 - Found Stages has built a track record of presenting high-quality, innovative, original plays that affect audience members in personal ways that just couldn't happen in a traditional theater venue. We think theater should give people a reason to get out of the house and go join their community. We make shows that we would want to attend as audience members.

Visit our website for more info: www.foundstages.org

Why Contribute?

All performances of this show are being presented for FREE to ensure that anyone who wants to attend can do so. Ticket sales normally cover 50% of a production's budget. We can't change the world in an empty room, so here's where we need your help: If you think this story is worth telling and want to see immersive and site-specific theater continue in the Atlanta area, please contribute.

As the digital world becomes more and more intertwined with our physical world, women and men of all colors and walks of life need to collaborate - sharing opinions, experiences, talent and ideas - to make the new infrastructure of our world the best it can be. Tech and the arts share a gender gap - more tech inventions and more plays by men are being marketed than those by women.

Your contribution will prove that women can be funny, successful, intelligent, beautiful, likeable, ambitious, talented, leaders, writers, directors, producers, coders, visionary geniuses, wives, mothers, sisters, friends, advocates, collaborators, and [fill in the blank]. And it will give inclusivity the kick-in-the-butt it needs!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! We want to be friends with your friends. So, give us an intro - use the Indiegogo share tools up at the top!
  • If you're a business looking to increase positive awareness of your brand by sponsoring this show, email us at foundstagestheatre@gmail.com for business-specific benefits!

Special Thanks to our Sponsors & Host Venues

Playwright: Annie Harrison Elliott

Director: Nichole Palmietto

Co-Artistic Director: Neeley Gossett
Production Manager: Kara Procell
Stage Manager: Max McCreary
Design Team: Catalyst Arts Atlanta

Props Master: A. Julian Verner
Costume Designer: Chelsea Steverson
Sound Designer: Bennett Walton
Projections Designer: Liz Schad
Fight Choreographer: Barrett Doyle
Film Team: Gaslight Picturehouse

Cinematographer: Evan Williams
Film Editor: Alan Goldman
Casting Director: Emily Kleypas
Jennifer: Candace Mabry
Frank: Jeffery Zwartjes
Natalie: Jin Jo

Sara: Mary Russell
Margot: Holly Stevenson
Dramaturg: Addae Moon
Press Relations Manager: Megan Schaeffer
Business Sponsorships Manager: Julia Hudgins

About Found Stages
Since 2014, Found Stages has been taking an innovative approach to plays: We don't do them in theaters. Instead, we partner with businesses, community organizations and nature centers to present our stories in the actual settings in which they take place. Empty Rooms will be our third fully produced project, and our largest to date. We're finding our niche, and want to be here to stay. You could say, that with this production, we're claiming a room in our Atlanta home.
Found Stages believes that theater is the best way to build empathy among (not-so-) different groups of people. We present our plays in site-specific locations because we believe that's the best way for our stories to reach the people that most need to see them. Empty Rooms has the potential to spark positive and productive conversations about how we build our future and tell its stories. Laughter is the best medicine, remember?
Since our first production - at Dunwoody Nature Center in 2014 - Found Stages has built a track record of presenting high-quality, innovative, original plays that affect audience members in personal ways that just couldn't happen in a traditional theater venue. We think theater should give people a reason to get out of the house and go join their community. We make shows that we would want to attend as audience members.
Visit our website for more info: www.foundstages.org


Why Contribute?
All performances of this show are being presented for FREE to ensure that anyone who wants to attend can do so. Ticket sales normally cover 50% of a production's budget. We can't change the world in an empty room, so here's where we need your help: If you think this story is worth telling and want to see immersive and site-specific theater continue in the Atlanta area, please contribute.
As the digital world becomes more and more intertwined with our physical world, women and men of all colors and walks of life need to collaborate - sharing opinions, experiences, talent and ideas - to make the new infrastructure of our world the best it can be. Tech and the arts share a gender gap - more tech inventions and more plays by men are being marketed than those by women.
Your contribution will prove that women can be funny, successful, intelligent, beautiful, likeable, ambitious, talented, leaders, writers, directors, producers, coders, visionary geniuses, wives, mothers, sisters, friends, advocates, collaborators, and [fill in the blank]. And it will give inclusivity the kick-in-the-butt it needs!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! We want to be friends with your friends. So, give us an intro - use the Indiegogo share tools up at the top!
If you're a business looking to increase positive awareness of your brand by sponsoring this show, email us at foundstagestheatre@gmail.com for business-specific benefits!

Special Thanks to our Sponsors & Host Venues

story:
Kristina Aleksova & Fernando Troya

FOUND IN TRANSLATION

DANCE PROJECT

www.foundintranslation.si

Facebook page

 

As you are reading this Kristina and Fernando are communicating through a web page www.foundintranslation.si. They are observing the testimonies of their bodies  and inviting YOU to step into the world of all the lost, overseen, unheard or transformed meanings that we all experience in every day life.

You have an opportunity to follow a creative process of two artists that are alternating in sending out their material; their emotional states and thoughts from which they are building a dance performance.

The premiere of the performance will take place in the creative space Foundus (Tobačna Ljubljana) on 24th May 2017. 

 

 

what is lost and what is found?

Body speaks a unique language that belongs to the world of trans-personal. If you observe carefully enough you can catch some information that is so often overseen or overheard.

Nowadays when the information that we share travels faster than we realise and when it seems that we are not the only creators of our wishes and dreams the questions raised by this project are all the more relevant : 

  • What is left there to rely upon?
  • How can we blindly trust our feelings?
  • How to develop a personality receptive enough to properly arrange all the information we receive, especially in a world dominated by data and impulses?

This dance project is a study of physical actions and reactions in everyday communication. A research of all the meanings that are lost overlooked or found and added while we interpret certain information. Kristina and Ferndando would like to find anew these missing elements through a movement.

 

who?

Kristina Aleksova & Fernando Troya are two young enthusiastic performance artists, dancers and choreographers. The project began when the two met working at the National Opera and Ballet in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Now, both of them freelance artists, they decided to step out of the institutional routine and do a joint contemporary project.

 

why do we need you?

We believe that this dance project is opening  doors to greater understanding that is very much needed today. Until now we managed to raise some funds, but in order to produce an outstanding performative experience we need your contribution. 

We are kindly inviting you to join us in creating this unique research and performance. Your funding will help us develop a great experience. We hope you join us and keep the creativity going! 

 

Want to help more? Be our Ambassador

There are several ways you can help our project!

Come and see the show!

Like us on Facebook and share our page with your friends and family.

Spread the news of this Crowdfunding campaign far and wide!

___________________________________________________________________

The team:

Idea and performance: Kristina Aleksova

Co-author and performance: Fernando Troya

Photo, video, design: Živa Petrič

Graphics & Layout : Sabell-Christina Fabian

Music: Kleemar

https://kleemar.bandcamp.com/album/banana-split

https://soundcloud.com/kleemar

Web design: Gorazd Guštin

Stage and light design: Dejan Filipović

Producer: Nina Smerkol

Coproduction: Kulturno društvo Center 21 & Hupa Brajdic

Supported by City of Ljubljana - Department of Culture

story: •

Hamburger Cat Cabaret

Hamburget Cat Cabaret rose from the crucible of Bay Area Avante Garde Performace Art and is founded on the style of Post-Neo Preposterous Nihilism.  With your help, we can show to the world what Serious Business is all about! 

This should not be taken lightly what is transpiring here will send ripples through the art world that will be felt and remembered and talked about and sung about and have musicals made about for years to come. 

Reasons and Rewards

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • This money will go directly to the performers who will enthrall you with there wit and vigor! It will also help with marketting this show (hah) and for boring things like pay for printing materials, staples, balloons and silly stuff for the audience like lasers that they can chase!
  • We are the only Indiegogo campaign in the world to offer cuisine from the fabled Fleeky of Flanco Mystic Chef of Antiquity. 
  • If we dont reach our entire goal, its ok we will just go broke paying out of pocket for all of this anyways. 

Serious Business

This campaign is so so important !

  • We are here to make you happy and to support Artists in doing what they love. 
  • Making shows is an ongoing process and this is only the beginning

Coffee is for closers

This show is a big fat giant risk and we are all losing sleep and having heart palpitations about it. We want you going into this with your eyes wide open.

  • This show is happening no matter what, even if we don't get your money its happening, yes we are that crazy.
  • This Campaign is mostly for marketing so tell your friends.

HALP .. but if you cant help a lot ..

  • The main thing we hope is that you tell your friends and come to our small tiny show and spend a few fun moments with us. Thanks for all the cheetos and hope to see you soon.

story:
The Playwright

Andy Dispensa

  • New York Native
  • Off-Broadway Actor (Credits at The Cherry Lane, Soho Playhouse, Mcginn/Cazale etc.)
  • Published Playwright (The Dionysian)
  • AADA/Elon University Graduate
  • Teacher at New York Film Academy (ESL Program)

What We Need & What You Get

Funding for-

  • Rehearsals 
  • Handmade Specialized Set (basically a new york city apartment hallway)
  • Costumes 
  • Programs 
  • Marketing 
  • Photography, Props and Miscellaneous things

What you get-

*All prizes levels build upon each other

$0-19 dollars - Hand written 'Thank You' note

$20-99 - Thank you in the program as a donor (Lacy Level)

$100-499 - Producer Credit, name in the playbill (Dante Level)

$500-999 - Signed Production Still/Poster by the cast + Producer Credit + Tickets for you and a friend to opening or closing night (Marisa Level)

$1000+ - Executive Producer Credit + tickets to any one of the 3 performances for you and 3 friends

$3250 - Dinner with the writer at a classic NYC Italian restaurant + all the aforementioned prizes

The Impact

From the mind of the writer to opening night, putting on a play is an exhilarating undertaking. You will be helping an up and coming playwright/actor make his vision come alive. This piece I've written comes from a somewhat dark and painful place for me and I have wanted to get it out there into the ether for some time now. I can't do it without your help!

My track record with theatre has been fortunate in my short tenure. Last year 'The Commedia Cinderella', a play in which I had a lead role (Pantalone) won Best Off-Broadway Family Show at The Off-Broadway Alliance Awards. Last April I originated the role of The Caterpillar in Billie Aken Tyers' 'Your Alice' with Ophelia Theatre Group. The show is now in talks for a run at a big Off-Broadway theatre house. I have been mentioned/reviewed in The New York Times, New York Theatre Review, On Stage Blog, and several others journals for my acting. 

I am constantly looking to continue my growth as an artist, but additionally for this festival I am hoping to showcase the talents of my contemporaries who I hold in high regard.

Risks & Challenges

Though I have primarily been an actor (appearing in 20+ shows over the past 3 years), this is my first full length play and directorial debut. I am excited, grateful, nervous and all of the above for this experience, but that being said, I am confident in my abilities and in the surrounding circumstances due to:

  • A full production team of seasoned theatrical veterans at the helm.
  • My unwavering love for acting, theatre, and original story telling.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute with a donation, don't worry!

  • Spreading the word about the show will go a long way! Winterfest is a competition with awards for best actor/actress, play and director, so the more buzz, the better!
  • You can always use the Indiegogo share tools to share with friends!

Thank you!!!

story:
Short Summary

The Growing Up Gonzales team is on the move. My name is Felix Rojas, I am the writer/director/producer of this wonderful show that I am very proud of and humbled by. Our show is a very touching and hilarious story of two brothers. The younger brother passes away and it's the older brother's responsibility to clean out his deceased brother's apartment. While cleaning he finds a box filled with notes and memoirs that change his life forever.

Our goal is to travel the world with Gonzales with our first step being Chicago. We have been invited to a festival in Chicago run by a non profit organization called The Chicago Latino Theatre Alliance. The festival is covering most of our expenses but we need a little help to complete the package. We will be in Chicago from October 10th through the 15th. We are taking a very small team. Actor, Andres "Chulisi" Rodriguez, Tech Director James Carter, Audio/Visual director Nick Rojas, Press rep and Producer Freddy Ramirez and myself. A traveling production like ours normally travels with twice as much staff but in order to make it work we will take the bare minimum.

story:
Short Summary

Hey! Khalil here...Glad to have your attention and thrilled to share a few details about the development of my new play ILLINOIS BOY BLUES. It is another one-man show filled with dynamic characters, stories of Illinois that you've never heard and make no mistake about it, "it's the blues baby!!! I can not wait to share it with you all...If you're not familiar with my work, I'm the creator and performer of the award winning one-man show PRYOR TRUTH*, the first ever one-man show to celebrate the life and legacy of comedian "Richard Pryor". I call it an actor's tribute. The folks over at TimeOutNY viewed it as "a love letter to the legendary comedian Richard Pryor...hilarious & deeply personal, an inspiring reminder of the need to fight for honesty within ourselves." In any case, that play changed my life! Imagine feeling as though you are performing exclusively for your IDOL, but in actuality you are performing in front of a room full of people, and in doing so, it is your responsibility to capture their attention for 90 minutes. It was magical. I fulfilled a childhood dream. I was the first to do it. It was a spiritual journey. I learned a lot. I learned a lot about myself. I learned I have a lot to offer. I am a storyteller. I fell in love with the art of solo performance. 

Originally produced with The Collective-NY, we earned the 2016 United Solo Theatre Festival Award for Best One-Man Show, and the 2016 New York International Fringe Festival Award for Overall Excellence in a Solo Performance. In addition, we were nominated for the 2016 Audelco Award for Outstanding Solo Performance.

      "The magnificent observation of the character of 'Mudbone,' as played by Pryor, that Muhammad now portrays, is riveting...You are watching a master craftsman in action, and it's breathtaking.:--Jacquelyn Claire NY Theatre Guide 

That was Richard's story; I do have my own! Richard taught me a lot, and I am eager to share what I've learned from that experience and where I am now! My second creation, ILLINOIS BOY BLUES, is an original story; it's my story!

...Surprisingly, Mark Twain's work has made a unique impression on me while creating this play. Revisiting his work as an adult has been an enlightening experience. What do Pryor & Twain have in common? Well, for one, they're great chroniclers of childhood! I am deeply inspired by their work. 

What We Need & What You Get

With your contribution, I will be able to finish off my research trip by traveling to Hannibal, MO (Twain's hometown) & Quincy, IL. This area has a strong influence within the play. Romaine was born in Quincy, IL; a city on the Mississippi River and just across from Mark Twain's hometown Hannibal, MO. It is important that I capture the essence of Quincy so that it is authentic in my storytelling. As the solo performer, I must uphold the imagination of the writer while bringing the words to life as the actor. It is a fully engaged experience that I would love to take you on. 

             "It is the audience who must supply the imagination...What is really important is not to put anything 'over,' but to bring the audience up onto the stage and into the scene with you. It is they who must give you even more than you give them in the way of imagination and creative power." ~Ruth Draper {Acting Solo; by Jordan R. Young}

In order for me to bring this creation to the stage, and as an Independent Producer, I need all the help I can get. By reaching my goal I will be able to finish off my research and get this play, up on it's feet; I have a story to tell. The cost of making all of this happen can be straining, but it comes with the territory and I have faith that I will be able to make it happen. Some of the expenses include:

  • Travel expenses to Hannibal, MO/Quincy,IL for (4) days
  • Graphic artist expense                           
  • Costume/Props                           
  • Promotional photos                           
  • Theatre festival submission fees                         
  • Licensing/insurance fees                           
  • Stage manager fees
  • Stage reading expenses

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that everyone can't contribute financially, but you can help by spreading the word. The more folks that are aware of this project, the better it is in the long run. Any assistance is greatly appreciated. So please, forward this to your rich friends ;-)

 

Any questions? Email: illinoisboybluesplay@gmail.com

Much Love,

~Khalil Muhammad

*Pryor Truth is not endorsed, supported or sponsored in any manner by the estate of Richard Pryor, and currently not in production.

Costume/Props

Stage manager fees
Stage reading expenses

Much Love,

story:
THE PROJECT

'First Violin' is a solo performance piece by multidisciplinary artist Sean Devare, investigating cultural inheritance and musical evolution through his personal discovery of the oldest ancestor of the violin and its connection to the Hindu epic poem, the Ramayana. With autobiographical spoken word poetry and narration, he chronicles his search for and recreation of the fabled first violin, invented by the demon(ized) King Ravana.

 

 

WHY NOW?

First Violin asks: where does a culture begin and end, and who can claim it? In examining and re-appropriating  the musical practices of rock icons like the Beatles and Led Zeppelin, Devare undertakes a journey in both artistic and personal discoveries to lend a new voice to the first generation Asian-American experience.

 

 

WHO IS IT FOR?

The piece is for people trying to make sense of the cultural collision we are experiencing on a direct level. For anyone seeking a greater connection to lost history and heritage, and anyone feeling the burdens and isolation that come with assimilation and disconnection from family. It is live performance as devotional prayer to generations past and present.

 

 

WHO WE ARE

Sean Devare (writer/performer/producer) is a multi-disciplinary performer, director, designer, and musician. His work explores questions of cultural evolution through reinterpreting ancient performance traditions and folktales. He was a resident actor at The Flea and has since focused on original collaborative pieces in the city and abroad as a founding member of Trinacria Theatre Company. MFA in Theatre, Sarah Lawrence; BFA in Illustration, RISD. www.seandevare.com

 

Alex M. Lee (director)  is a director, writer, and visual artist from Seoul, Korea, recently based in New York City. Her personal work is focused on intimate storytelling through transformative media, and she is thrilled to make her NYC directorial debut working with a piece and collaborator both very close to her heart. She is a graduate of the Brown/RISD Dual Degree Program from which she holds a BA in Theatre Arts and a BFA in Film/Animation/Video.

story:
Agua, Vida y Tierra is a new bi-lingual documentary/multi-media theatre piece named after the poem by Julia de Burgos, exploring the past, present, and future of Puerto Rico through the lens of Hurricane Maria. Consisting of interviews, research, photography, music, and dance, this play will be developed over the next year in San Juan and New York City by What Will the Neighbors Say? and a diverse group of collaborators.

This development process will yield a devised piece deeply rooted in Puerto Rican culture that will be a living testament of the power of art within tragedy. Part epic poem, part searing historical drama, part celebration and part funeral liturgy, the audience will be taken back and forth across time and space, never quite sure if what they are seeing is real or imagined.

Your contributions will help pay for travel costs, production needs, and ensure that the artists working on this project are properly compensated for their hard work and dedication.

Explore Untold Stories

This piece represents a real life and modern day untold story: one of colonial oppression, American intervention, and multi-generational neglect that culminated in the circumstances that made Hurricane Maria the disaster it was.  

Travel to Puerto Rico

In March, the team will conduct an initial interview and fact finding trip, traveling to the island to begin shaping the structure of the piece through the stories we find. We will spend two weeks conducting interviews with both community members and organizers, as well as visiting institutions and historical sites. The goal is to cast a wide net and get a breadth of source material (sound, video, photography, etc) to begin our work back in New York

Brooklyn Summer Workshop

Upon our return to NY, the team will begin devising the piece with an aim to present a workshop production in the end of June. This will be a rough draft and act as a proof of concept to seek future funding and productions. 

Platform for Latinx Artists

Agua, Vida y Tierra presents a unique opportunity for Latinx artists in both Puerto Rico and New York. The team of devisers brought together by WWTNS? will consist entirely of actors, artists, dancers, and designers of Latinx heritage, giving a platform to a group often cast aside.

To make this project a reality we are seeking funding in two main areas: time for research in Puerto Rico and Development in NYC. Without your help we will not be able to adequately give this story the time and resources it deserves!

Cost Breakdown:

$750    Room & Board for Artists travelling to PR

$1,500 Development Workshop in Brooklyn in June

$2,750  Artist Compensation both in PR and NYC

= $5,000

For more information about our company and our programming, please visit us at www.wwtns.org!

Feel free to reach out to info@wwtns.org with any questions, requests, or suggestions.

You can also follow us on social media!

 Facebook @wwtnstheatre Instagram @wwtnstheatre

story:
How it all began

When I wrote the book "Giovanni and the Camino of St. Francis" and prepared to go on tour, I decided I wanted to do something I had always wanted to do - write and perform a musical based on the life of St. Francis of Assisi. He's been my spiritual mentor since I was young and I believe his message of peace is so important today. Earlier this year I began traveling and sharing "Brother Sun, Sister Moon" and I was amazed at the result - especially by how I excited I was to share this beautiful story. 

Then the opportunity presented itself to share the musical on the off-Broadway stage. The idea of bringing St. Francis to New York for two weeks was too good to be true, but we began planning the cross country tour. I decided that I would travel across the US as close to how Francis himself would have traveled - penniless and in complete trust. I would need to rely upon people along the way to provide food and shelter, and even a ride from city to city. We even decided to do something in New York that had never been done before - to invite the homeless into the theater each night of the show. During the day I'll join volunteers on the street as we pass out free passes to the musical, then share a bowl of soup with all the attendees before the show begins.

But to accomplish all this we need your help. If we can raise $20,000 we'll be able to accomplish all these goals. I hope you'll consider making a donation - big or small - and help St. Francis share his message with the world. We have so many incentives to spark your imagination, from free downloads to St. Francis and St. Clare dolls knitted here in Mexico.

Take the time to look around and see how you want to help. And St. Francis and I hope to see you on the road.
