story:
Version Française (Text in English below)

Goma Dance Festival (GDF en sigle), est une initiative des jeunes danseurs de la ville de Goma en collaboration avec quelques jeunes opérateurs culturels de cette ville touristique de l’Est de la République Démocratique du Congo.

Une rencontre annuelle de danses urbaines, contemporaines et traditionnelles, dont le but est de promouvoir, soutenir et renforcer les capacités de danseurs locaux avec une formation professionnelle grâce aux différents ateliers.
Le festival se situe entre la rue et la scène. Amour, joie et unité y sont présentes. Différents danseurs africains et danseurs professionnels internationaux s’y rassemblent, afin de dépasser les barrières politiques, culturelles, ethniques et rassembler les gens autour du langage commun « la danse »

- Téléchargez le Rapport 2018

- Téléchargez le Rapport 2017

Au programme cette année vous trouverez :

En plus du programme et événements qui ont fait la force du festival en 2017 et 2018, pour 2019 nous voulons ajouter d’autres activités en danse et éléments de la culture Hip-Hop :

- Formation et création : Avec notre partenaire BATALO EAST nous voulons former les filles danseuses de Goma et travailler sur une création d’une pièce de danse théâtre qui unira les danseuses de Goma avec celles de l'Ouganda. La pièce sera présentée au prochain BATALO EAST festival à Kampala. Le but et d’encourager et d’initier les femmes de notre région à la danse.

- GDF Théâtre : organiser une soirée d’exhibition de pièce de danse du genre Hiphop Theater et contemporaine qui seront présentées par différentes compagnie de danse de Goma et d’ailleurs.

- Conférences : Une conférence sous le thème « FAIRE DE LA DANSE UNE PROFFESSION ». Vu la présence à cette nouvelle édition des invités de grande envergure dans le monde de la danse, nous comptons motiver les danseurs de la région à faire de la danse une profession au-delà d’un loisir.

- GRAFFITI workshops & exposition : Réorganiser des workshops de GRAFFITI, pour permettre aux jeunes de véhiculer et exposer des messages positifs et de paix à travers la peinture et le dessin.

- GOMA HIP-HOP SESSION : Sera une rencontre, un moment d’échanges et initiations à la culture Hip-Hop aux artistes pratiquant cette discipline sans connaissance. Le but est aussi de développe des actions autour des pratiques artistiques du hip hop : du RAP, DJING, GRAFFITIS, DANSE & BEATBOXING.

- Lilou Congo Dance tours : Le champion du monde Bboy Lilou revient en RDC accompagné de deux autres artistes Hip-Hop. C’est grâce à l’appui de notre partenaire inconditionnel Institut Français, que nous ferons une tournée d’échange et résidence artistique dans quelques grandes villes de la RD Congo dont Kinshasa, Kisangani et Goma.

Pourquoi ?

A l’Est de la R.D.Congo plusieurs jeunes danseurs sont talentueux, mais manquent de formations ou stages professionnelles. Ils sont tous abandonné à leur propre sort et ne bénéficient d’aucune promotion ou soutien. En grandissant la majorité abandonne la danse suite au manque de promotion, d’espace d’expression ou d’un moyen de franchir les étapes vers une carrière professionnelle. C’est pour soutenir et promouvoir ces jeunes courageux et talentueux, que nous avons pensé à créer GOMA DANCE FESTIVAL afin de leur offrir des opportunités pour une carrière professionnelle et un espace d’expression.

Les objectifs :

• Créer un événement annuel pour montrer l’importance et la valeur de danse urbaine, contemporaine et traditionnelle à la jeunesse congolaise.

• Promouvoir et renforcer les capacités de jeunes danseurs, leur permettre de se prendre en charge dans leurs créations et le soutenir pour un développement professionnel.

• Promouvoir le respect, la liberté et solidarité pour consolider la paix et la cohabitation dans la région des grands-lacs Africain.

• Permettre aux danseurs d’échanger et de s’exprimer librement, afin qu’ils se sentent égaux et valorisés

• Cultiver dans la communauté un gout de soutien et de promotion de la danse urbaine et contemporaine comme une profession artistique et un élément important pour le développement de la jeunesse.

De quoi avons-nous besoin ?

Grâce à l’implication et l’engagement des danseurs de la région, cette édition sera encore une réussite.

Cette année, nous travaillons en étroite collaboration avec l’Institut Français de Goma pour prise en charge des voyages des artistes venants de la France. L'Institut Françcais nous donne aussi un espace pour l’hébergement des danseurs visiteurs et pour les ateliers de danse.

Le centre Kivu Youth Entertainment qui va s'occuper du multimédia et la documentation (photos +videos), le festival Batalo East qui accueille les gagnants de notre complétion de danse GDF Championship et bien d’autres personnes de bonne volonté nous tendent la mains.

Pour cette 3ème édition, cette collecte de fonds vise à rassembler le montant pour couvrir :

-          les couts de transport

-          la location de la salle de spectacles pour la compétition et les spectacles

-          les couts de la restauration des danseurs invités et des bénévoles.

Ce que vous obtenez :

Un réel sentiment de satisfaction et de joie à aider un groupe de jeunes passionnés et motivés.

Mais aussi pour ceux qui ceci intéresse :

- pour $10 : une lettre de remerciement

- pour $20 ; une Carte de vœux

- pour $30 : une photo GDF personnalisée

- pour $50 : une Carte de vœux et une photo GDF personnalisée

- pour $200 : un Joli portrait (dessin) de toi

- pour $500 : Parrain officiel, une lettre de remerciement, une carte de vœux, une photo GDF personnalisée, Joli portrait (dessin) de toi

L’impact :

Votre soutien va contribuer à ceci:

• Des milliers de jeunes seront réunis pour promouvoir le respect, la liberté et solidarité pour consolider la paix et la cohabitation dans la région des grands-lacs Africain

• Les capacités de jeunes danseurs seront renforcées pour une future carrière professionnelle

• Les gagnants à GDF Championship vont participer à d’autres festivals au niveau international

• La communauté de la région développe le gout de soutien et de promotion de la danse urbaine et contemporaine comme une profession artistique et un élément important pour le développement de la jeunesse.

Pour nous aider à faire en sorte que cet évènement se réalise, vous pouvez :

- Faire une donation

- Partager sans modération cette page avec vos proches

- Nous suivre sur : Facebook, Instagram, Twitter

Et vous êtes bien sûr les bienvenus au Goma, au festival, et venez visiter ce magnifique endroit! Grand Merci!

Contacts:

Tél: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230

Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.com

Web : http://rinhadanceprojects.org

 

ENGLISH VERSION

Goma Dance Festival (GDF acronym), is an initiative of the young dancers of the city of Goma in collaboration with some young cultural operators of this tourist city of the East of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

An annual meeting of urban, contemporary and traditional dances, whose purpose is to promote, support and strengthen the capacities of local dancers with professional training through different workshops.
The festival is between the street and the stage. Love, joy and unity are present. Various African dancers and international professional dancers come together to overcome political, cultural and ethnic barriers and bring people together around the common language of "dance"

- Download the 2018 Report

- Download the 2017 Report

On the program this year you will find :

In addition to the program and events that have been the strength of the festival in 2017 and 2018, for 2019 we want to add other activities in dance and elements of the Hip-Hop culture:

- Training and creation: With our partner BATALO EAST we want to train the girls dancers of Goma and work on a creation of a theater dance piece that will unite the dancers of Goma with those of Uganda. The play will be presented at the next BATALO EAST festival in Kampala. The goal is to encourage and introduce women of our region to dance.

- GDF Théâtre: organize an exhibition evening of a dance piece of the Hiphop Theater and contemporary genre that will be presented by different dance companies from Goma and elsewhere.

- Conferences: A conference under the theme "MAKE DANCE A PROFFESSION". Given the presence at this new edition of the large-scale guests in the world of dance, we intend to motivate the dancers of the region to make dance a profession beyond a hobby.

- GRAFFITI workshops & exposition: Reorganize GRAFFITI workshops, to allow young people to convey and expose positive messages and peace through painting and drawing.

- GOMA HIP-HOP SESSION: Will be a meeting, a moment of exchanges and initiations to the culture Hip-Hop to the artists practicing this unconscious discipline. The goal is also to develop actions around the artistic practices of hip hop: RAP, DJING, GRAFFITIS, DANCE & BEATBOXING.

- Lilou Congo Dance tours: World Champion Bboy Lilou returns to the DRC accompanied by two other Hip-Hop artists. It is thanks to the support of our unconditional partner Institut Français, that we will make a tour of exchange and artistic residency in some big cities of the DR Congo including Kinshasa, Kisangani and Goma.

Why ?

East of R.D.Congo, several young dancers are talented, but lack training or professional training. They are all left to their own fate and receive no promotion or support. Growing up the majority gives up dancing due to lack of promotion, space for expression or a way to take the steps towards a professional career. It is to support and promote these brave and talented young people, that we thought to create GOMA DANCE FESTIVAL in order to offer them opportunities for a professional career and a space of expression.

Goals :

• Create an annual event to show the importance and value of urban, contemporary and traditional dance to Congolese youth.

• Promote and reinforce the capacities of young dancers, empower them to take charge of their creations and support them for professional development.

• Promote respect, freedom and solidarity to consolidate peace and coexistence in the Great Lakes region of Africa.

• Allow dancers to freely exchange and express themselves so that they feel equal and valued

• Cultivate in the community a taste of support and promotion of urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and an important element for the development of youth.

What do we need ?

Thanks to the involvement and commitment of the dancers of the region, this edition will be another success.

This year, we are working closely with the French Institute of Goma to take care of the travels of artists coming from France. The Institut Françcais also gives us a space for the accommodation of visiting dancers and for dance workshops.

The Kivu Youth Entertainment center, which is going to take care of multimedia and documentation (photos + videos), the Batalo East festival, which welcomes the winners of our GDF Championship dance completion and many other people of goodwill are reaching out to us.

For this 3rd edition, this fundraising aims to collect the amount to cover:

- transport costs

- the rental of the theater for the competition and shows

- the costs of the restoration of the invited dancers and volunteers.

What you get :

A real sense of satisfaction and joy to help a group of passionate and motivated young people.

But also for those who are interested:

- for $ 10: a thank you letter

- for $ 20; a greeting card

- for $ 30: a personalized GDF photo

- for $ 50: a greeting card and a personalized GDF photo

- for $ 200: a nice portrait (drawing) of you

- for $ 500: Official Godfather, a thank you letter, a greeting card, a personalized GDF photo, Nice portrait (drawing) of you

The impact :

Your support will contribute to this:

• Thousands of young people will come together to promote respect, freedom and solidarity to consolidate peace and coexistence in the African Great Lakes region

• The capacities of young dancers will be strengthened for a future professional career

• GDF Championship winners to participate in other international festivals

• The community of the region develops the taste for supporting and promoting urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and an important element for youth development.

To help us make this event happen, you can:

- Make a donation

- Share without moderation this page with your relatives

- Follow us on: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter

And you are of course welcome at Goma, at the festival, and come and visit this beautiful place! Big thanks!

Contacts :

Tel: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230

Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.com

Web: http://rinhadanceprojects.org

L'Institut Françcais nous donne aussi un espace pour l’hébergement des danseurs visiteurs et pour les ateliers de danse.Le centre Kivu Youth Entertainment qui va s'occuper du multimédia et la documentation (photos +videos), le festival Batalo East qui accueille les gagnants de notre complétion de danse GDF Championship et bien d’autres personnes de bonne volonté nous tendent la mains.Pour cette 3ème édition, cette collecte de fonds vise à rassembler le montant pour couvrir :-          les couts de transport-          la location de la salle de spectacles pour la compétition et les spectacles-          les couts de la restauration des danseurs invités et des bénévoles.Ce que vous obtenez :Un réel sentiment de satisfaction et de joie à aider un groupe de jeunes passionnés et motivés.Mais aussi pour ceux qui ceci intéresse :- pour $10 : une lettre de remerciement- pour $20 ; une Carte de vœux- pour $30 : une photo GDF personnalisée- pour $50 : une Carte de vœux et une photo GDF personnalisée- pour $200 : un Joli portrait (dessin) de toi- pour $500 : Parrain officiel, une lettre de remerciement, une carte de vœux, une photo GDF personnalisée, Joli portrait (dessin) de toiL’impact :Votre soutien va contribuer à ceci:• Des milliers de jeunes seront réunis pour promouvoir le respect, la liberté et solidarité pour consolider la paix et la cohabitation dans la région des grands-lacs Africain• Les capacités de jeunes danseurs seront renforcées pour une future carrière professionnelle• Les gagnants à GDF Championship vont participer à d’autres festivals au niveau international• La communauté de la région développe le gout de soutien et de promotion de la danse urbaine et contemporaine comme une profession artistique et un élément important pour le développement de la jeunesse.Pour nous aider à faire en sorte que cet évènement se réalise, vous pouvez :- Faire une donation- Partager sans modération cette page avec vos proches- Nous suivre sur : Facebook, Instagram, TwitterEt vous êtes bien sûr les bienvenus au Goma, au festival, et venez visiter ce magnifique endroit! Grand Merci!Contacts:Tél: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.comWeb : http://rinhadanceprojects.org ENGLISH VERSIONGoma Dance Festival (GDF acronym), is an initiative of the young dancers of the city of Goma in collaboration with some young cultural operators of this tourist city of the East of the Democratic Republic of Congo.An annual meeting of urban, contemporary and traditional dances, whose purpose is to promote, support and strengthen the capacities of local dancers with professional training through different workshops.The festival is between the street and the stage. Love, joy and unity are present. Various African dancers and international professional dancers come together to overcome political, cultural and ethnic barriers and bring people together around the common language of "dance"- Download the 2018 Report- Download the 2017 ReportOn the program this year you will find :In addition to the program and events that have been the strength of the festival in 2017 and 2018, for 2019 we want to add other activities in dance and elements of the Hip-Hop culture:- Training and creation: With our partner BATALO EAST we want to train the girls dancers of Goma and work on a creation of a theater dance piece that will unite the dancers of Goma with those of Uganda. The play will be presented at the next BATALO EAST festival in Kampala. The goal is to encourage and introduce women of our region to dance.- GDF Théâtre: organize an exhibition evening of a dance piece of the Hiphop Theater and contemporary genre that will be presented by different dance companies from Goma and elsewhere.- Conferences: A conference under the theme "MAKE DANCE A PROFFESSION". Given the presence at this new edition of the large-scale guests in the world of dance, we intend to motivate the dancers of the region to make dance a profession beyond a hobby.- GRAFFITI workshops & exposition: Reorganize GRAFFITI workshops, to allow young people to convey and expose positive messages and peace through painting and drawing.- GOMA HIP-HOP SESSION: Will be a meeting, a moment of exchanges and initiations to the culture Hip-Hop to the artists practicing this unconscious discipline. The goal is also to develop actions around the artistic practices of hip hop: RAP, DJING, GRAFFITIS, DANCE & BEATBOXING.- Lilou Congo Dance tours: World Champion Bboy Lilou returns to the DRC accompanied by two other Hip-Hop artists. It is thanks to the support of our unconditional partner Institut Français, that we will make a tour of exchange and artistic residency in some big cities of the DR Congo including Kinshasa, Kisangani and Goma.Why ?East of R.D.Congo, several young dancers are talented, but lack training or professional training. They are all left to their own fate and receive no promotion or support. Growing up the majority gives up dancing due to lack of promotion, space for expression or a way to take the steps towards a professional career. It is to support and promote these brave and talented young people, that we thought to create GOMA DANCE FESTIVAL in order to offer them opportunities for a professional career and a space of expression.Goals :• Create an annual event to show the importance and value of urban, contemporary and traditional dance to Congolese youth.• Promote and reinforce the capacities of young dancers, empower them to take charge of their creations and support them for professional development.• Promote respect, freedom and solidarity to consolidate peace and coexistence in the Great Lakes region of Africa.• Allow dancers to freely exchange and express themselves so that they feel equal and valued• Cultivate in the community a taste of support and promotion of urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and an important element for the development of youth.What do we need ?Thanks to the involvement and commitment of the dancers of the region, this edition will be another success.This year, we are working closely with the French Institute of Goma to take care of the travels of artists coming from France. The Institut Françcais also gives us a space for the accommodation of visiting dancers and for dance workshops.The Kivu Youth Entertainment center, which is going to take care of multimedia and documentation (photos + videos), the Batalo East festival, which welcomes the winners of our GDF Championship dance completion and many other people of goodwill are reaching out to us.For this 3rd edition, this fundraising aims to collect the amount to cover:- transport costs- the rental of the theater for the competition and shows- the costs of the restoration of the invited dancers and volunteers.What you get :A real sense of satisfaction and joy to help a group of passionate and motivated young people.But also for those who are interested:- for $ 10: a thank you letter- for $ 20; a greeting card- for $ 30: a personalized GDF photo- for $ 50: a greeting card and a personalized GDF photo- for $ 200: a nice portrait (drawing) of you- for $ 500: Official Godfather, a thank you letter, a greeting card, a personalized GDF photo, Nice portrait (drawing) of youThe impact :Your support will contribute to this:• Thousands of young people will come together to promote respect, freedom and solidarity to consolidate peace and coexistence in the African Great Lakes region• The capacities of young dancers will be strengthened for a future professional career• GDF Championship winners to participate in other international festivals• The community of the region develops the taste for supporting and promoting urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and an important element for youth development.To help us make this event happen, you can:- Make a donation- Share without moderation this page with your relatives- Follow us on: Facebook, Instagram, TwitterAnd you are of course welcome at Goma, at the festival, and come and visit this beautiful place! Big thanks!Contacts :Tel: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.comWeb: http://rinhadanceprojects.org
campaign_city: Goma, Congo, the Democratic Republic of the

story:
www.squirelane.co.uk

Squire Lane Theatrical and Baby Crow Productions are bringing two new theatrical works to Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2017, the first and largest fringe theatre festival in the world.

 

In theatre, as in life, few things are more important than finding your people. What inevitably brought Squire Lane, Baby Crow, Kevin, Margaret, Joy and I together is a shared belief in the potential for theatre to provoke dialogue, inspire empathy, and provide a platform for socially relevant stories and underrepresented voices.

WHORE: A Kid's Play is also about finding your people. It began 3 years ago as 10-minute play, exploring slut-shaming and internalized sexism and its socialization on the playground. Over the next year and a half, collaborating with different casts and directors, a full-length version began to take shape. Working on the play often became a catalyst for countless stories about childhood friendships, Catholic school, and coming out. In so many respects, these were versions of my story.

Around the same time, Joy (who played a big part in the development of Kids Play) had already begun assembling fragments from her 6th grade journals for the solo play that would eventually become 13 & Not Pregnant.

At one point or another in my life I’ve been all of these characters. For me, writing a play is an act of extreme empathy. There’s a push to expand feeling and understanding into the imagined lives of others. I believe this act of imagining the lives of others has a modest yet profound role in the fight for a more just and tolerant society.

While no play can directly change the problems of society, our hope is that bringing these stories to audiences can bring immediacy and awareness to the struggles of young people who weren’t as lucky as I was.

— Reese Thompson, playwright, WHORE: A Kid's Play

 

The CDC reports that suicide is the third leading cause of death among young people, resulting in about 4,400 deaths per year. According to Yale University’s Office of Public Affairs, victims of bullying are 2 to 9 times more likely to consider suicide than non-victim. A study conducted in Britain by the charity Beatbullying says that nearly half of suicides among 10 to 14-year-olds are due to bullying, with girls and gay youth being at particularly high risk.

“Young women, those 18-24, experience certain severe types of harassment at disproportionately high levels: 26% of these young women have been stalked online, and 25% were the target of online sexual harassment. In addition, they do not escape the heightened rates of physical threats and sustained harassment common to their male peers and young people in general.”

—Pew Research Center, Online Harassment, 2014

While social media has acted as a particularly dangerous catalyst for the dehumanization of women, the instinct to shame and harass women has strong roots in society that stretch far back.

“It seems the word slut can be applied to any activity that doesn't include knitting, praying, or sitting perfectly still lest any sudden movements be deemed whorish.”

“...people dislike or condemn promiscuity in the abstract, in hypothetical experimental scenarios, or for some distant 'others,' but that they're much more likely to accept it, understand it or excuse it when it concerns themselves or their already close friends.”

 —Zhana Vrangalova, “Do Promiscuous People Really Have Fewer Friends?” Psychology Today

“Technology has ramped it up so much that there are no boundaries ... It’s so faceless and they are free to say whatever, they’re free to say and do whatever without thinking about it.”

—Carol Todd, mother of victim, Amanda Todd

 

WHORE: A Kid's Play
Written by Reese Thompson, Directed by Margaret Grace Hee

Set against a backdrop of small-town gossip amplified by social media, limitless shame, and the hell-fire of the confession booth, WHORE: A Kid's Play is a darkly funny account of the pressures to be both normal and exceptional in a world hostile to misfit girls and queer kids, when nothing is quite so momentous as friendship, nor so utterly monstrous as ourselves. #BFF4NOW  #KIDSPLAY4EVER

“Bratty, insolent and wise, WHORE is a mash up of John Hughes, Jean Genet, and Jem and the Holograms.”   — Stephen Karam (author of Speech & Debate and The Humans)

Jenn, 13, wants two things from God: 1) to be pretty, and 2) for Andrea to be her best friend. Jenn’s arch-nemesis, Patrick, dutifully preps for the Junior Regional Spelling Bee - though what he really wants to do is dance. Meanwhile, Andrea, also 13, just wants someone to tell her if those awkward encounters with Jenn’s stepbrother over summer break mean she’s not a virgin anymore. Years later, when Jenn shows up on Andrea’s doorstep, nursing a concussion, the two must confront the events that led to their falling out as kids.

“Reese (Thompson) is a truly original new voice in the theatre — exploring areas no one else is, saying things no one else would, and finding both humor and meaning in the madness of contemporary life. To be so unique in outlook and talented in execution is beyond rare in emerging artists. His work speaks to our moment with deep wit and insight, and is always a theatrical delight.” — Christopher Shinn (author Four, Dying City, and Teddy Ferrara)

 

13 & Not Pregnant
Written & Performed by Joy Donze, Directed by Mia Capotorto Sommese

 WINNER BEST COMEDY 2016 UNITED SOLO FESTIVAL

With 90’s musical dance tantrums, heartbreaking journal entries, and the severing of dolls heads, 13 & Not Pregnant presents the aggressively hormonal writings of a Midwestern US, nineties, pre-teen as she navigates her erratically evolving girlhood.

The entire show is verbatim entries from Joy Donze‘s 6th grade journal, massaged and spliced & diced in the rehearsal room with Director Mia Capotorto Sommese. The show is developed to be first and foremost universally entertaining. Beyond that, Joy Donze explains, “I wanted go back and explore this crucial pivotal time we all go through; Puberty. When we search within our tormenting selves and dare to ask….who am I?”

“Hilarious, poignant and shockingly honest!” -Karen Ludwig (solo performer, author of WHERE WAS I?)

“I can’t remember the last time I laughed so hard for the entire duration of a show. Go see Joy Donze… SO FUNNY.” - Daniel Kwiatkowski (thehollowsonline.com)

“What a fab funny funny show. Go see her!” - Richard Mazda (Executive Producer - The Secret Theatre NYC)

“13 & Not Pregnant was both hilarious and honest. It lovingly takes a journey back to a tie where EVERYTHING matters. Young Joy thinks she knows everything, but the audience can laugh and relate because we know she knows nothing.” - Pamela Wess, filmmaker

 

Thanks to a $10,000 anonymous donation and seed funding from our team, we've reached the point where we can definitely take these projects to Edinburgh.

We are raising $35,000 to bring "13 & Not Pregnant" and "WHORE: A Kid's Play" to Edinburgh Fringe Festival and bring these much needed stories to the world.

Edinburgh Fringe Festival is generally not a place to go if you're looking to make money, but rather a festival where artists grow, lifetime networks are built, and new shows get their legs. Bringing two shows with primarily New York based artists is a costly endeavour. Our total cost of producing these projects, including flying cast and crew from New York to Edinburgh, housing them, feeding them, renting venues, marketing the shows and putting up two great shows is approximately $42,648, including about a 10% contingency.

Venues $11,620.49
Production $1,373.30
Accomodations $5,580.00
Travel $5,819.53
Press & Marketing $8,593.13
Administration $248.00
Artist & Creative Fees $5,536.60
Contingency $3,877.10

$42,648.15

 

We believe these stories are important and you will want to be a part of the our success, but your investment in this project will give you more than just the "good feels".

The first 50 contributors over the $100 level will receive an exclusive ticket to our NYC Preview Performances (July 2017).

We have put together some great perks that will make you a part of the experience as well.  From a very thoughtful Thank You from the cast and crew and the collaborating production companies on all our social media outlets, to a post card from the cast in Edinburgh, to tickets to see the shows, to Official Signed Posters, we've got a little something for everybody.

For those of you looking for more of an experience, we have perks that include a Dance Lesson from our choreographer, Benjamin Rowan, or a Voice Lesson from actor Joy Donze, or maybe you're working on a Monologue for your next audition and you need some help from one of our cast members (all MFA Drama Grads) or our Director Margaret Grace Hee (a MFA Directing Grad).

We also have opportunities for you to sit in on a rehearsal (in New York or Edinburgh) and then have dinner and a 2 hour discussion with a cast member, the director or the playwright. Talk about your playwrighting ideas, interesting in getting into directing, or just want to know the ins and outs of acting in New York City?

Some levels of our perks include tickets to our shows in Edinburgh, but we'll give all levels of our supporters an opportunity to purchase discount tickets for our shows in Edinburgh after the campaign as well.

NEW T-SHIRT DESIGNS

  • To ease your checkout here on Indiegogo, you will receive a survey a couple weeks after our Indiegogo campaign completes that will allow you to choose the design, color and size of your perk t-shirt, and the design of any branded products.

* Fine Print: All of the experiential perks require you to get there (either NY or Edinburgh), we do not cover the cost of travel or housing. Any unused experiential perks (including tickets) are not refundable; If you cannot get to New York or Edinburgh, maybe we can come up with another perk for you. If you cannot get to a performance on a specific date, we'll try to get you tickets for another performance. Please note that there is only one rehearsal in Edinburgh, so there is only one day where that perk may be "redeemed". Some perks that require us to ship something to you are only open to the United States and United Kingdom, but we've done our best to include perks that can be shipped worldwide.

 

 

"13 & Not Pregnant" and "WHORE: A Kid's Play" evaluate universal themes of youth, gender expectations, bullying, misogyny and the human experience with a heavy influence on the female perspective.

These are relevant, timely subjects that need to be discussed. What a better way to do that then through the theatre. Squire Lane Theatrical and Baby Crow Productions believe in creating art with a purpose. With every production we develop and produce, we donate a portion of ticket sales to local causes that make a difference.

Baby Crow Productions focuses on creating work that is accessible to a broad audience, provokes dialogue and inspires action. It is a laboratory for ambitious artists to explore new ways of approaching collaboration in rehearsal and performance. The Flock believes that art can tangibly affect change in the world, by carefully creating and choosing pieces that are socially and environmentally responsible and cultivating relationships with community organizations. Baby Crow productions has produced and developed socially aware productions since 2009.

Squire Lane Theatrical develops and produces socially critical and relevant stories for the stage to provoke dialogue and inspire action on 21st century issues facing our world. With a goal of capturing real people in socially relevant stories, we have a passion for looking in on the lives of those not talked about, the situations that are hard to talk about, and the relationships that can't be talked about. As theatre-makers, and makers of media, we believe we have a responsibility to open people's eyes to the worlds that they have never been introduced to.

 

REESE THOMPSON's (PLAYWRIGHT, WHORE) work has been performed at The Bowery Poetry Club, The Nuyorican Poets Cafe, Carnegie Hall, The Soho Arts Festival, The Barrow Street Theatre, Metropolitan Playhouse, Manhattan Repertory Theatre, The New School for Drama, and The Drama League. He’s been published in The Yale Review, The Beliot Poetry Journal, VanityFair.com, among others. He has three monologues in 222 More Comedy Monologues (edited by John Capecci and Irene Ziegler), forthcoming from Smith and Kraus publishers. He was a Yaddo fellow, a finalist for the Fulbright, a semi-finalist for The O’Neill Conference. He currently has a screenplay is in development with Embrem Entertainment. He received his MFA in Playwriting from The New School for Drama (CoPA) in 2016.

MARGARET GRACE HEE (DIRECTOR, WHORE) is the founding Artistic Director of Baby Crow Productions. As a director, actress and teaching artist she focuses on ensemble generated devised work. She believes that theatre can be a catalyst for influencing positive change in our world. As a means of addressing her artistic values she develops partnership with organizations and communities that can benefit from the work being produced. Margaret holds her MFA in Directing from the New School for Drama, and he BFA in Acting from the Santa Fe University of Art and Design. She has also studied at American Conservatory Theatre, Ithaca College London Center, Stella Adler Conservatory, and the Art of Acting Studio.

MATT KATZ-BOHEN (ORIGINAL MUSIC & MUSICAL DIRECTION BY, WHORE), since 2008, has played keyboard in Blondie, consistently touring the world. He co-wrote 6 songs on Blondie's albums "Panic of Girls" and "Ghosts of Download" including the singles "What I Heard" and "A Rose by any Name". His collaboration with Manila Luzon, "Best XXXcessory" reached #37 on the iTunes dance chart. He has won SESAC's Abe Olman Award for songwriting, a TV Land Icon Award, and an NME Godlike Genius Award. Blondie's 2013 UK Single, "A Rose by any Name", featuring Beth Ditto, received Prime rotation on BBC Radio 2. He is also acting sub-Musical Director for Hedwid and the Angry Inch on Broadway. Katz-Bohen has toured with Boy George, Tony Bennett, Ashford and Simpson, Theophilus London, Psychic TV, Raja Gemini & Manila Luzon (RuPaul's Drag Race).

Born in New York City, Matt Katz-Bohen started playing piano, cello, violin and guitar at LaGuardia High Schoo of Music, Art, and the Performing Arts (the school known as "FAME". As a guitarist for NYC's popular Bowieball shows, as well as for the Drag Queen Rock n Roll troupe "The Touchables", where he has worked with Jody Watley, Princess Superstar, Lady Miss Kier, Justin Vivian Bond, Mink Stole and John Cameron Mitchell.

He also musical directed Debbie Harry's sold-out, critically acclaimed residency at the legendary Cafe Carlyle, and acted as sole accompanist, on piano, guitar, synth and laptop.

JOY DONZE (WRITER, 13 & NOT PREGNANT / CAST, WHORE) is a NYC based actress/singer. She received her BFA in Musical Theatre at Avila University in Kansas City. Joy has worked with Ugly Rhino Productions, Baby Crow Productions, Mastodon Theatre Company, Mount Carmel Theatre Company,  Matthew Corozine studio, Theatre for Young Americans, RWS and Associates Entertainment. After years of touring and gaining a greater perspective of humanity while coming into a new inspiration of artistry, Joy decided to focus on new work and went receive her MFA in acting. She is excited to be spreading her wings at The New School for Drama in New York City, where she is gearing her artistic endeavors towards social and political theatre that push the boundaries and step outside tradition.

MIA CAPOTORTO SOMMESE (DIRECTOR, 13 & NOT PREGNANT) is a New York based director, writer, visual artist, and choreographer. With a  passion for musical theatre, Mia is dedicated to creating original and provocative musicals. She co-wrote her first musical, Sapien Sapien Sapien, alongside composer/arranger Jonathan Winton Brenner. Sapien Sapien Sapien was most recently seen at the New York Theatre Barn New Works Series in March of 2016, and was devised, developed, and originally produced through Baby Crow Productions under the direction of Margaret Grace Hee.

KEVIN MICHAEL REED (PRODUCER) grew up on the stage stepping into roles in musicals and straight plays that others have written, playing the significant other in ballets with dance companies throughout the North Eastern United States, and designing (lights and sets) for several productions as well. After an injury, and a self-examination, Kevin left the theatre to pursue corporate jobs. He landed in account management at advertising firms before realizing that “the creative” was the only. Upon returning, He spent 19 years as a successful fashion photographer which allowed him to study people and relationships. With an intense need to tell his own stories, He began writing, producing and directing for film and returned to designing lights for several theatre companies in New York and Connecticut. He now sits in a foreign city, London, exploring his passion for writing and being a flâneur of sorts.

MATTHEW BOVEE (ACTOR, WHORE) A theater and dance artist from San Francisco, Matthew graduated from UC San Diego with dual degrees in Theater and Dance. In NYC he has worked as a performer and movement director with The Flea Theater, Pipeline Theater Company, Ma-Yi Theater Company, Ensemble Studio Theater, Movement Workshop Group, The Next Stage Project, New York Theater Workshop, and Columbia Stages. Regionally, he has worked at the Williamstown Theatre Festival, The Old Globe, San Diego Rep, Hollywood Fringe Festival, and San Diego Dance Theater. He has been a teaching artist in NYC as well as at the Tony Award-winning La Jolla Playhouse. Thrilled to be playing with these crazy kids on this excellent play.

ERIN MARGARET PETTIGEW (ACTOR, WHORE) is a New York based actress from Los Angeles. She holds a BFA in Acting form University of California Santa Barbara and a MFA in Acting from The New School for Drama.

 

 

 

BENJAMIN PAUL ROWAN (CHOREOGRAPHER, WHORE) is ecstatic to be choreographing Kids Play for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival! On stage credits include; Tours: Saturday Night Fever, Yo Gabba Gabba Live, Sesame Street Live, Chuggington Live, Cyrano de Bergerac. New York: A Chorus Line – The One Production (Broadening Theatrics), Reawaken Wonder (ft. Lin-Manuel Miranda), Siren’s Den (NY New Works Festival), Club IF (NY Winterfest Festival). Regional: Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, Peter Pan (Arizona Broadway Theatre), CATS, Seussical (Pittsburgh Musical Theatre), Billy Elliot, Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story (The Palace Theatre NH), SWING, Damn Yankees (OCTC), The Music Man (Broward Stage Door). Behind the tables, Benjamin has directed and choreographed for the Nickelodeon programing on board Norwegian Cruise Line and currently musically directs/supervises for the Emmy winning RWS Entertainment Group. Benjamin is also an after school instructor for the Leadership Program teaching creative arts programs throughout NYC.

ANTHONY HAGAN (COSTUME DESIGNER) came from a Missouri farm to London and then settled in Brooklyn, Anthony has pursued his career in fashion editorial and creative media while continuing to nurture his theatrical roots. He has styled and costumed numerous productions in the states and abroad putting his hodgepodge of niche cultural references to use. Anthony is ecstatic to be bringing his skills to the stage and such a phenomenal cast. #longhairdontcare

 

Calum Mac (GRAPHIC DESIGNER & MERCHANDISE DESIGNER) is the founder of both queer cabaret comedy group the ‘Sex Shells’ and design collective ‘Bare Bones’, based in Shoreditch, London.

 

 

 

 

With the potential for the funding cut to the National Endowment for the Arts and tightening of budgets for organizations that provide grants and fellowships for artists, we feel that now is one of the most important times to show how important art is to the world.

Our "artists' pockets" cannot fund this whole project alone. We've put together an amazing team of professional theatre makers seeking to make great theatre and do good in the world.

Bringing one piece to Edinburgh Fringe Festival is expensive and challenging, but we're bringing two. Planning for this project began over a year ago, we've got pages of pages of marketing plans and production documents outlining our steps to success.

Thankfully with our current level of funds raised, seed funding from the team as well as an anonymous donation from a patron of the arts, we have secured enough funds to take these shows to Edinburgh -- but now we're trying to give the shows the production value and marketing that they deserve.

 

 

We understand that you may not be in a position right now to support this project financially, but there are other ways that you can help.

  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter.
  • Visit our website and sign up for our mailing list.
  • Don't need the perks through our Indiegogo Campaign? You can donate directly to our projects and it will also be tax deductible. Check out our website for more information.
  • If you work for a company, or own a company, that offers matching grants or corporate sponsorship, please let us know. More info here.
  • Talk about our projects with your friends. We know that nothing is more powerful than your endorsement. If you feel that these projects need to be seen, let others know.

 

THANK YOU!

www.squirelane.co.uk

“Young women, those 18-24, experience certain severe types of harassment at disproportionately high levels: 26% of these young women have been stalked online, and 25% were the target of online sexual harassment. In addition, they do not escape the heightened rates of physical threats and sustained harassment common to their male peers and young people in general.”
—Pew Research Center, Online Harassment, 2014
While social media has acted as a particularly dangerous catalyst for the dehumanization of women, the instinct to shame and harass women has strong roots in society that stretch far back.
“It seems the word slut can be applied to any activity that doesn't include knitting, praying, or sitting perfectly still lest any sudden movements be deemed whorish.”
“...people dislike or condemn promiscuity in the abstract, in hypothetical experimental scenarios, or for some distant 'others,' but that they're much more likely to accept it, understand it or excuse it when it concerns themselves or their already close friends.”
 —Zhana Vrangalova, “Do Promiscuous People Really Have Fewer Friends?” Psychology Today
“Technology has ramped it up so much that there are no boundaries ... It’s so faceless and they are free to say whatever, they’re free to say and do whatever without thinking about it.”
—Carol Todd, mother of victim, Amanda Todd
 

WHORE: A Kid's PlayWritten by Reese Thompson, Directed by Margaret Grace Hee
Set against a backdrop of small-town gossip amplified by social media, limitless shame, and the hell-fire of the confession booth, WHORE: A Kid's Play is a darkly funny account of the pressures to be both normal and exceptional in a world hostile to misfit girls and queer kids, when nothing is quite so momentous as friendship, nor so utterly monstrous as ourselves. #BFF4NOW  #KIDSPLAY4EVER
“Bratty, insolent and wise, WHORE is a mash up of John Hughes, Jean Genet, and Jem and the Holograms.”   — Stephen Karam (author of Speech & Debate and The Humans)
Jenn, 13, wants two things from God: 1) to be pretty, and 2) for Andrea to be her best friend. Jenn’s arch-nemesis, Patrick, dutifully preps for the Junior Regional Spelling Bee - though what he really wants to do is dance. Meanwhile, Andrea, also 13, just wants someone to tell her if those awkward encounters with Jenn’s stepbrother over summer break mean she’s not a virgin anymore. Years later, when Jenn shows up on Andrea’s doorstep, nursing a concussion, the two must confront the events that led to their falling out as kids.
“Reese (Thompson) is a truly original new voice in the theatre — exploring areas no one else is, saying things no one else would, and finding both humor and meaning in the madness of contemporary life. To be so unique in outlook and talented in execution is beyond rare in emerging artists. His work speaks to our moment with deep wit and insight, and is always a theatrical delight.” — Christopher Shinn (author Four, Dying City, and Teddy Ferrara)
 

13 & Not PregnantWritten & Performed by Joy Donze, Directed by Mia Capotorto Sommese
 WINNER BEST COMEDY 2016 UNITED SOLO FESTIVAL
With 90’s musical dance tantrums, heartbreaking journal entries, and the severing of dolls heads, 13 & Not Pregnant presents the aggressively hormonal writings of a Midwestern US, nineties, pre-teen as she navigates her erratically evolving girlhood.
The entire show is verbatim entries from Joy Donze‘s 6th grade journal, massaged and spliced & diced in the rehearsal room with Director Mia Capotorto Sommese. The show is developed to be first and foremost universally entertaining. Beyond that, Joy Donze explains, “I wanted go back and explore this crucial pivotal time we all go through; Puberty. When we search within our tormenting selves and dare to ask….who am I?”
“Hilarious, poignant and shockingly honest!” -Karen Ludwig (solo performer, author of WHERE WAS I?)
“I can’t remember the last time I laughed so hard for the entire duration of a show. Go see Joy Donze… SO FUNNY.” - Daniel Kwiatkowski (thehollowsonline.com)
“What a fab funny funny show. Go see her!” - Richard Mazda (Executive Producer - The Secret Theatre NYC)
“13 & Not Pregnant was both hilarious and honest. It lovingly takes a journey back to a tie where EVERYTHING matters. Young Joy thinks she knows everything, but the audience can laugh and relate because we know she knows nothing.” - Pamela Wess, filmmaker
 


Thanks to a $10,000 anonymous donation and seed funding from our team, we've reached the point where we can definitely take these projects to Edinburgh.
We are raising $35,000 to bring "13 & Not Pregnant" and "WHORE: A Kid's Play" to Edinburgh Fringe Festival and bring these much needed stories to the world.
Edinburgh Fringe Festival is generally not a place to go if you're looking to make money, but rather a festival where artists grow, lifetime networks are built, and new shows get their legs. Bringing two shows with primarily New York based artists is a costly endeavour. Our total cost of producing these projects, including flying cast and crew from New York to Edinburgh, housing them, feeding them, renting venues, marketing the shows and putting up two great shows is approximately $42,648, including about a 10% contingency.
Venues $11,620.49Production $1,373.30Accomodations $5,580.00Travel $5,819.53Press & Marketing $8,593.13Administration $248.00Artist & Creative Fees $5,536.60Contingency $3,877.10
$42,648.15
 


We believe these stories are important and you will want to be a part of the our success, but your investment in this project will give you more than just the "good feels".
The first 50 contributors over the $100 level will receive an exclusive ticket to our NYC Preview Performances (July 2017).
We have put together some great perks that will make you a part of the experience as well.  From a very thoughtful Thank You from the cast and crew and the collaborating production companies on all our social media outlets, to a post card from the cast in Edinburgh, to tickets to see the shows, to Official Signed Posters, we've got a little something for everybody.
For those of you looking for more of an experience, we have perks that include a Dance Lesson from our choreographer, Benjamin Rowan, or a Voice Lesson from actor Joy Donze, or maybe you're working on a Monologue for your next audition and you need some help from one of our cast members (all MFA Drama Grads) or our Director Margaret Grace Hee (a MFA Directing Grad).
We also have opportunities for you to sit in on a rehearsal (in New York or Edinburgh) and then have dinner and a 2 hour discussion with a cast member, the director or the playwright. Talk about your playwrighting ideas, interesting in getting into directing, or just want to know the ins and outs of acting in New York City?
Some levels of our perks include tickets to our shows in Edinburgh, but we'll give all levels of our supporters an opportunity to purchase discount tickets for our shows in Edinburgh after the campaign as well.
NEW T-SHIRT DESIGNS


To ease your checkout here on Indiegogo, you will receive a survey a couple weeks after our Indiegogo campaign completes that will allow you to choose the design, color and size of your perk t-shirt, and the design of any branded products.
* Fine Print: All of the experiential perks require you to get there (either NY or Edinburgh), we do not cover the cost of travel or housing. Any unused experiential perks (including tickets) are not refundable; If you cannot get to New York or Edinburgh, maybe we can come up with another perk for you. If you cannot get to a performance on a specific date, we'll try to get you tickets for another performance. Please note that there is only one rehearsal in Edinburgh, so there is only one day where that perk may be "redeemed". Some perks that require us to ship something to you are only open to the United States and United Kingdom, but we've done our best to include perks that can be shipped worldwide.

 
 

"13 & Not Pregnant" and "WHORE: A Kid's Play" evaluate universal themes of youth, gender expectations, bullying, misogyny and the human experience with a heavy influence on the female perspective.
These are relevant, timely subjects that need to be discussed. What a better way to do that then through the theatre. Squire Lane Theatrical and Baby Crow Productions believe in creating art with a purpose. With every production we develop and produce, we donate a portion of ticket sales to local causes that make a difference.
Baby Crow Productions focuses on creating work that is accessible to a broad audience, provokes dialogue and inspires action. It is a laboratory for ambitious artists to explore new ways of approaching collaboration in rehearsal and performance. The Flock believes that art can tangibly affect change in the world, by carefully creating and choosing pieces that are socially and environmentally responsible and cultivating relationships with community organizations. Baby Crow productions has produced and developed socially aware productions since 2009.
Squire Lane Theatrical develops and produces socially critical and relevant stories for the stage to provoke dialogue and inspire action on 21st century issues facing our world. With a goal of capturing real people in socially relevant stories, we have a passion for looking in on the lives of those not talked about, the situations that are hard to talk about, and the relationships that can't be talked about. As theatre-makers, and makers of media, we believe we have a responsibility to open people's eyes to the worlds that they have never been introduced to.
 

REESE THOMPSON's (PLAYWRIGHT, WHORE) work has been performed at The Bowery Poetry Club, The Nuyorican Poets Cafe, Carnegie Hall, The Soho Arts Festival, The Barrow Street Theatre, Metropolitan Playhouse, Manhattan Repertory Theatre, The New School for Drama, and The Drama League. He’s been published in The Yale Review, The Beliot Poetry Journal, VanityFair.com, among others. He has three monologues in 222 More Comedy Monologues (edited by John Capecci and Irene Ziegler), forthcoming from Smith and Kraus publishers. He was a Yaddo fellow, a finalist for the Fulbright, a semi-finalist for The O’Neill Conference. He currently has a screenplay is in development with Embrem Entertainment. He received his MFA in Playwriting from The New School for Drama (CoPA) in 2016.
MARGARET GRACE HEE (DIRECTOR, WHORE) is the founding Artistic Director of Baby Crow Productions. As a director, actress and teaching artist she focuses on ensemble generated devised work. She believes that theatre can be a catalyst for influencing positive change in our world. As a means of addressing her artistic values she develops partnership with organizations and communities that can benefit from the work being produced. Margaret holds her MFA in Directing from the New School for Drama, and he BFA in Acting from the Santa Fe University of Art and Design. She has also studied at American Conservatory Theatre, Ithaca College London Center, Stella Adler Conservatory, and the Art of Acting Studio.
MATT KATZ-BOHEN (ORIGINAL MUSIC & MUSICAL DIRECTION BY, WHORE), since 2008, has played keyboard in Blondie, consistently touring the world. He co-wrote 6 songs on Blondie's albums "Panic of Girls" and "Ghosts of Download" including the singles "What I Heard" and "A Rose by any Name". His collaboration with Manila Luzon, "Best XXXcessory" reached #37 on the iTunes dance chart. He has won SESAC's Abe Olman Award for songwriting, a TV Land Icon Award, and an NME Godlike Genius Award. Blondie's 2013 UK Single, "A Rose by any Name", featuring Beth Ditto, received Prime rotation on BBC Radio 2. He is also acting sub-Musical Director for Hedwid and the Angry Inch on Broadway. Katz-Bohen has toured with Boy George, Tony Bennett, Ashford and Simpson, Theophilus London, Psychic TV, Raja Gemini & Manila Luzon (RuPaul's Drag Race).
Born in New York City, Matt Katz-Bohen started playing piano, cello, violin and guitar at LaGuardia High Schoo of Music, Art, and the Performing Arts (the school known as "FAME". As a guitarist for NYC's popular Bowieball shows, as well as for the Drag Queen Rock n Roll troupe "The Touchables", where he has worked with Jody Watley, Princess Superstar, Lady Miss Kier, Justin Vivian Bond, Mink Stole and John Cameron Mitchell.
He also musical directed Debbie Harry's sold-out, critically acclaimed residency at the legendary Cafe Carlyle, and acted as sole accompanist, on piano, guitar, synth and laptop.
JOY DONZE (WRITER, 13 & NOT PREGNANT / CAST, WHORE) is a NYC based actress/singer. She received her BFA in Musical Theatre at Avila University in Kansas City. Joy has worked with Ugly Rhino Productions, Baby Crow Productions, Mastodon Theatre Company, Mount Carmel Theatre Company,  Matthew Corozine studio, Theatre for Young Americans, RWS and Associates Entertainment. After years of touring and gaining a greater perspective of humanity while coming into a new inspiration of artistry, Joy decided to focus on new work and went receive her MFA in acting. She is excited to be spreading her wings at The New School for Drama in New York City, where she is gearing her artistic endeavors towards social and political theatre that push the boundaries and step outside tradition.
MIA CAPOTORTO SOMMESE (DIRECTOR, 13 & NOT PREGNANT) is a New York based director, writer, visual artist, and choreographer. With a  passion for musical theatre, Mia is dedicated to creating original and provocative musicals. She co-wrote her first musical, Sapien Sapien Sapien, alongside composer/arranger Jonathan Winton Brenner. Sapien Sapien Sapien was most recently seen at the New York Theatre Barn New Works Series in March of 2016, and was devised, developed, and originally produced through Baby Crow Productions under the direction of Margaret Grace Hee.
KEVIN MICHAEL REED (PRODUCER) grew up on the stage stepping into roles in musicals and straight plays that others have written, playing the significant other in ballets with dance companies throughout the North Eastern United States, and designing (lights and sets) for several productions as well. After an injury, and a self-examination, Kevin left the theatre to pursue corporate jobs. He landed in account management at advertising firms before realizing that “the creative” was the only. Upon returning, He spent 19 years as a successful fashion photographer which allowed him to study people and relationships. With an intense need to tell his own stories, He began writing, producing and directing for film and returned to designing lights for several theatre companies in New York and Connecticut. He now sits in a foreign city, London, exploring his passion for writing and being a flâneur of sorts.
MATTHEW BOVEE (ACTOR, WHORE) A theater and dance artist from San Francisco, Matthew graduated from UC San Diego with dual degrees in Theater and Dance. In NYC he has worked as a performer and movement director with The Flea Theater, Pipeline Theater Company, Ma-Yi Theater Company, Ensemble Studio Theater, Movement Workshop Group, The Next Stage Project, New York Theater Workshop, and Columbia Stages. Regionally, he has worked at the Williamstown Theatre Festival, The Old Globe, San Diego Rep, Hollywood Fringe Festival, and San Diego Dance Theater. He has been a teaching artist in NYC as well as at the Tony Award-winning La Jolla Playhouse. Thrilled to be playing with these crazy kids on this excellent play.
ERIN MARGARET PETTIGEW (ACTOR, WHORE) is a New York based actress from Los Angeles. She holds a BFA in Acting form University of California Santa Barbara and a MFA in Acting from The New School for Drama.
 
 
 
BENJAMIN PAUL ROWAN (CHOREOGRAPHER, WHORE) is ecstatic to be choreographing Kids Play for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival! On stage credits include; Tours: Saturday Night Fever, Yo Gabba Gabba Live, Sesame Street Live, Chuggington Live, Cyrano de Bergerac. New York: A Chorus Line – The One Production (Broadening Theatrics), Reawaken Wonder (ft. Lin-Manuel Miranda), Siren’s Den (NY New Works Festival), Club IF (NY Winterfest Festival). Regional: Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, Peter Pan (Arizona Broadway Theatre), CATS, Seussical (Pittsburgh Musical Theatre), Billy Elliot, Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story (The Palace Theatre NH), SWING, Damn Yankees (OCTC), The Music Man (Broward Stage Door). Behind the tables, Benjamin has directed and choreographed for the Nickelodeon programing on board Norwegian Cruise Line and currently musically directs/supervises for the Emmy winning RWS Entertainment Group. Benjamin is also an after school instructor for the Leadership Program teaching creative arts programs throughout NYC.
ANTHONY HAGAN (COSTUME DESIGNER) came from a Missouri farm to London and then settled in Brooklyn, Anthony has pursued his career in fashion editorial and creative media while continuing to nurture his theatrical roots. He has styled and costumed numerous productions in the states and abroad putting his hodgepodge of niche cultural references to use. Anthony is ecstatic to be bringing his skills to the stage and such a phenomenal cast. #longhairdontcare
 
Calum Mac (GRAPHIC DESIGNER & MERCHANDISE DESIGNER) is the founder of both queer cabaret comedy group the ‘Sex Shells’ and design collective ‘Bare Bones’, based in Shoreditch, London.
 
 
 
 


With the potential for the funding cut to the National Endowment for the Arts and tightening of budgets for organizations that provide grants and fellowships for artists, we feel that now is one of the most important times to show how important art is to the world.
Our "artists' pockets" cannot fund this whole project alone. We've put together an amazing team of professional theatre makers seeking to make great theatre and do good in the world.
Bringing one piece to Edinburgh Fringe Festival is expensive and challenging, but we're bringing two. Planning for this project began over a year ago, we've got pages of pages of marketing plans and production documents outlining our steps to success.
Thankfully with our current level of funds raised, seed funding from the team as well as an anonymous donation from a patron of the arts, we have secured enough funds to take these shows to Edinburgh -- but now we're trying to give the shows the production value and marketing that they deserve.
 
 


We understand that you may not be in a position right now to support this project financially, but there are other ways that you can help.


Share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter.

Visit our website and sign up for our mailing list.
Don't need the perks through our Indiegogo Campaign? You can donate directly to our projects and it will also be tax deductible. Check out our website for more information.

If you work for a company, or own a company, that offers matching grants or corporate sponsorship, please let us know. More info here.

Talk about our projects with your friends. We know that nothing is more powerful than your endorsement. If you feel that these projects need to be seen, let others know.

 THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary

This is a campaign to raise production budget for the first international play to be produced by J.O. International Productions. It offers to up and coming actresses the chance to star in a gritty funny and real story of women in todays society. Helping build a platform for wonderful careers.  Your support will help continue to support the industry here in Australia, in particular bringing real stories to life and creating roles for women. 

What We Need & What You Get

This is the first Australian Tour and so we are raising funds to help with our production costs including:

  • Theatre Hire - Good venues can be expensive and require deposits. Its important that the the nature of the show be supported by the venue. Hosting at the appropriate venue also build great crowds.
  • Props - The show requires minimal props however these props must be transported between tour locations of three cities. This will aid us in supplying vehicle transportation and fuel.
  • Airfares & Accommodation (including contribution to bring our US Writer & Director to Australian Shores). We would like to supply both our cast and crew with reasonable accomodation, this is not only signs of professionalism but also aids in ensuring our cast and crew are well rested and at their best for the production.
  • Published Materials - All shows require marketing. This will enable us to produce great posters for the project to be submitted in our publicity campaigns.

All funds will be going towards the production irrespective of what is raised. In particular to support venue expenses and props.

 

The Impact
In this business, its important we support the Industry in Australia to see it grow and expand; including offering avenues for international writers & directors to bring their material down under. For artists and supporters of the Entertainment Industry, your contribution will help encourage more productions here in Australia. This play in particular focuses on women and the roles we play in our society. A cause that is very important to the growth in our industry and community. Support inclusion, diversity and gender matters. This play deserves credit for trying to cover so many issues as realistically as it does in an intelligent and enlightening production.

This play has received wonderful views from across the globe and its only fitting we should continue that trend here in Australia. Please visit our website for more details and previous media

www.yourmothersvjj.com

 

 

Risks & Challenges

As with any production we stand the risk of not getting enough interests from our audiences. We have a wonderful team in place to help us with this, and also are speaking with a PR rep to help build as much media awareness as possible. In addition, we have sought out two investors. One secured the other still in mediation. This just ensures that we have at least enough capitol to break even and ensure we can deal with the problems we face.

No matter what, this show will go ahead. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cant donate, perhaps help us by passing this through your network. Maybe you know someone who can? Or maybe you are interested in coming to watch the show? You can always buy a ticket to show support and join us?

  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

About Producer

Jessica Orcsik’s professional career began at age 4 on TV show Richmond Hill. Since then Jess has worked on various TV shows, Films and featured in commercials. Jessica starred in Triple J Unearthed sensation Andy Jans Brown’s music video “Girl Dressed In A Woman's Clothes” music video, and recently (TV Pilot) "Soil", “Wings” finalist for the Focus On Ability International Short film festival. Established performer and choreographer working with various dance companies, performed on television shows and in a number of events across Australia and choreographed Australian performing artist tours. Director of internationally acclaimed production company J.O. International Productions, Jess has had been a leading facilitator for international careers for Australian performers and actors. Produced nation wide events and competitions including “On Broadway” and Don’t Dis Disabilities dance Extravaganza” that support inclusion & diversity in the performing arts; facilitated international prize experiences for various international events and written several articles on industry practises and experiences for Dance Informa Magazine. Jessica was invited to speak at the Actors Symposium alongside Breakdown Services seminar in Vancouver on international performers who relocate to Los Angeles in 2014 and continued success with the “LA Experience” program designed alongside The Australian Film & Television Academy. Jessica works with international development of Focus On Ability International Film Festival. and is a proud alumni of wonderful programs dedicated to supporting talent all over the world. Jessica not only works as a talent on stage and screen but develops projects in Stage, Film & Television. She launches “Your Mother’s Vagina” as her first international play production and is thrilled to be working alongside mentor, friend and incredible director Amy Chaffee.

story:
VARIATIONS ON THE MAIN

  • Performed by 
  • Kate Benson
  • Catherine Brookman
  • Marisela Grajeda Gonzalez
  • Layla Khoshnoudi
  • Production designed by Megan Lang
  • Composed by Catherine Brookman
  • Co-directed by William Burke and Bryn Herdrich
  • Stage managed by Renee Yeong
 

The show is about us being with each other even when we don't have the correct words.

I have been able to produce and present my own work in NYC and Brooklyn largely in part to my collaborators believing in the work that I do and transcending the limited resources that define self producing in New York.

Alec Duffy and JACK presented my first full play in 2013 based  off of an email and (I think) a deep curiosity of what I would do.  Since then I've covered the audience in plastic Elmo hats, brought dogs into the space, made it snow and hung actors in a giant net over an audience and countless other acts that most theaters wouldn't even entertain.

You, the audience has been there since the beginning and we need you to help us send off 505 1/2 Waverly into the sky and be a stepping stone for the great pastures of JACK's new space.

Things I've done:

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1500 to get us over the proverbial hump.

  • The $ will go to the actors and the designers.
  • DONATE!  We will acknowledge you in an unexpected way.   We will send you a part of JACK.  Hint.  It will be tinfoil.

The Impact

 

  • I'm proud of the shows I make since I feel like we transcend the traditional budgetary limitations of producing theater in this very complicated city.

Risks & Challenges

Theater in this city is hard.  I'm always amazed by the amount of small donations I receive.  These feel better than the rare large ones I get. (Don't let this sentence stop you though)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't donate at the moment, I get it!  Come to the show.  Tell others.  Help us close out a chapter of JACK!

VARIATIONS ON THE MAIN

  • Performed by 
  • Kate Benson
  • Catherine Brookman
  • Marisela Gonzalez
  • Production designed by Megan Lang
  • Composed by Catherine Brookman
  • Co-directed by William Burke and Bryn Hredrich
  • Stage managed by Renee Yeong

story:
Why a Midwinter Faire?

About four years ago, I was walking to my car in a typical Rochester snow storm and I found my thoughts turning to warmer weather and start of Renaissance Faire season.  As a Rochester native, I did not find myself pining for warmer climes, but pondering why there was no Ren Faire activity during the winter months.  After discussions with many of my fellow patrons, I confirmed that there was, indeed interest in some sort of Faire-type activity for what has always been considered the "off-season".

And that's how the idea for the Midwinter Faire was born.  Now the venue is booked, so we just need your help to make it the best Faire it can possibly be.

What We Need

Money.  Yeah, I figured you knew that already, but that's what this is all about.  I've worked on shoestring (and no-string) budgets, but this will require real funding to make it work as I know it can.  I have calculated that $5,000 is the minimum amount required to pull this off.

Now, where does that money go?

  • We have budgeted $2,500 towards paying the various acts we're bringing in to make sure a wide variety of entertainment is on display.
  • $1,500 to cover the rent of the venue itself.
  • $1,000 for costumes for cast and crew, concessions, programs and the various perks that must be manufactured.

Any money raised beyond our initial $5,000 will go towards adding more (and bigger) acts and making the Faire look just as good as it possibly can.

What You Get

To help you make up your mind, we've put together a number unique items for all interests and budget levels:

  • A T-shirt to show your dedication to the Faire
  • A Midwinter Faire collectible pin.  I know there are pin collectors out there who'd like to add the Shield of the Tudor Lilac to their collection!
  • A personalized video from Phil Shakespeare - Want a sonnet or soliloquy recited?  A tune played for you on the ancient Eunuch Flute?  A reading of a series of stupid jokes by Jonette the Definitely-Not-Elizabethan furry monster?  The possibilities are endless!  (Well, not really.  Let's keep this PG-13...)
  • Tickets to the show (at a considerable discount)!

Also, all items (except the Season Pass) will be available as add-ons to the various perk levels, so you can build your own bundle or add more items!

Why Become a Backer?

As I said, the venue is booked, the Faire is happening.  But here are some reasons your support is still essential for the success of the Faire:

  • Advance ticket sales will help with booking of additional acts by showing there will be an audience.
  • Having a lot of backers (even at lower dollar amounts) helps indicate the demand for this kind of event in the wintertime and could lead to bigger things in the future.

Risks & Challenges

There are, of course, several very real risks, as with any venture.

  • Let's face it, this is Rochester.  We could get socked with a massive snowstorm on one or more Faire days.  I'm very much a "show must go on" kind of guy, but "no-travel" advisories *do* happen. 
  • One or more of the announced acts could, due to unforseen circumstance, back out.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to buy anything or just can't make it?  There are other ways you can help us reach our goal:

  • Most importantly, spread the word!  If you have friends in the area who might like to see something like this, let them know!
  • Don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!  Lots of ways to get the word out!

In Conclusion

I've been working towards something like this for a very long time.  It's an exciting opportunity to do something that's a little bit theater, a little bit Ren Fest and a whole lot of fun.  I hope you can join us for a ride like no other...

story:
September 5th – 21st
Bath House Cultural Center (Dallas, TX)
Tickets go on sale August 1st.

Our Journey Thus Far...

My name is Eric Berg (in the video, I'm in the middle).  And for the past year, US/THEM has been my passion project.

US/THEM was unlike any play I'd read before:  it was magical, yet rooted in reality; radical in its simplicity and compassion; a children's show that would challenge any adult audience.  When I finished the play for the first time, my first thought was, "I have to put this onstage."

Luckily, many other talented Dallas theater artists have shared in my passion for this story.  Director, Katy Tye (PRISM CO, Shakespeare in the Bar,) and Actor, Kristen Lazarchick (Radiant Vermin at Kitchen Dog Theatre,) both agreed to come onto the project before we even had a theater in which to perform!  It was a challenge to find a theater willing to produce "a children's play about terrorism," but Echo Theatre was up to the task.

We have a theater.  We have a cast.  We have a story that aches to be told. 

But we need your donation to complete the final part of our journey and make this production a reality!

A Children's Play about Terrorism

After the tragedy of the Beslan School Siege,  adult society fractured the story into different competing narratives about what happened and who to blame.  US/THEM is a play that focuses the conversation back on the children, giving them control over their own story.

Because this is a story about schoolchildren, it is important that students--the children who would've been affected by the events of this play--get to hear this story.  This play will be a starting point for conversations between adults and children about the difficult topic of terrorism.

To that end, Echo Theatre is offering up to four student matinees, specifically designed to give young people (ages 13 and up) access to the show.  There will be a Pay-What-You-Can preview to ensure price does not keep anyone out of the conversation.  And every performance will have a talk-back moderated by a trained trauma specialist.  

How Your Donation Matters

Before any of this important work can be done, we have to fund the production itself. Most of our budget has already been accounted for, but there are still some crucial elements of the production that must be funded:

Artist Stipends ($1000) – It takes many, many talented people to produce a play, from actors and directors to designers and stage managers.  We have the funds to pay most of our dedicated artists, but we still need your help to raise the last $1,000. Echo believes in respecting their artists and paying people for their time.  If we do not raise enough to meet our goal, we may be forced to sacrifice other elements of the production in order to pay the artists.

Set ($500) –The set is a crucial part of the children’s story telling; it is not just a backdrop behind the actors, but a part of the play itself. This modest set budget will give the actors the tools they need to make the play come to life!

Props ($500) – This play uses a lot of hand props: chalk, string, balloons, etc.  These items are not expensive individually, but over time the items add up. If we only use 20 balloons per performance, 13 performances makes 260 balloons—and if you account for balloons in rehearsal, it brings the total number of balloons to almost 500!

Costumes ($170) – The actors need clothes! There are hidden costs in keeping the costumes fresh for the duration of the run: incidental repairs, post-show dry cleaning, etc.  Your money will literally keep clothes on the actors’ backs!

Lighting & SFX ($80) – There are a few theatrical goodies that will be used for this show.  If we do not meet our goal, the special effects will be the first items to be cut.  You can stop that from happening with your donation!

Sound ($50) – Our phenomenal sound designer, Claire Carson, needs your help to make our production sound as good as it looks.

Your Rewards

This campaign is not run by Echo Theatre, but by the individuals involved in the production--so all of your donations go directly towards the costs of the show! While not tax deductible, there are perks for every level of support.

No matter the size of the donation, every donor will receive credit for their contribution in the playbill for the show.  But here are the other rewards you can get by giving a little bit more:

+$10 -  A personalized thank you email with photos and a description of your donation being put to use!

+$25 - A real prop used in the play signed by the cast (limited to first 75 donors) + personalized thank you 

+$50 - 1 reserved ticket + signed prop

+$100 - 2 reserved tickets + an invitation to the exclusive Donor Pre-show Party 

+$250 - 4 reserved tickets + invite to the Donor Pre-show Party 

+$500 - 4 reserved tickets + invite to the Donor Pre-show Party  +
a dedication in the Curtain Speech (limited to first 5 donors)

+1,000 - all of the rewards for our $500 level donors + a poster signed by the cast + an invitation to an exclusive sneak-peek into the rehearsal process 

Donations of any amount are appreciated.  But please, give until it feels good!

Other Ways You Can Help

We're theatre people.  We understand keeping a tight budget.  Even if you can't contribute $1 yourself, please:

  • Share our campaign on social media
  • Ask friends, family, or anyone who would be interested in this project to donate
  • Come and see the show!

About Echo Theatre

Echo Theatre’s name springs from the nymph "Echo" of Greek mythology; cursed to forever repeat the words of others, never speaking for herself.  

Since its foundation 1998, Echo Theatre has been dedicated to bridging the gender gap in live theatre. Echo exclusively produces works by female-identifying playwrights. To this day, Echo remains the only theater in the Dallas-Fort Worth area that is dedicated to solely producing plays by women.

There are no other stipulations in Echo’s mission, and the plays Echo produces are as different and varied as the women who write them. Over the past 21 seasons, Echo has produced over 80 main-stage productions, which have received numerous awards and accolades.  Echo also offers free performances of staged readings through their Echo Reads Salon Series to ensure all have access to work by women playwrights. Echo Theatre is proud to US/THEM to its long and illustrious list!
