story:
"Comfort Women: A New Musical" is raising funds to support it's budget.  With your donation, we will be able to pay some of our cast of over 50 actors.  With the funds raised, we will buy more advertising space to help promote and market "Comfort Women: A New Musical."  Set in 1941, Comfort Women takes us to Seoul, Korea, where we meet Goeun, a young woman whose brother is attempting to revolt against the Imperial Japanese Army. Goeun meets a man who promises her a good paying job at a factory in Tokyo.  Feeling like she has no other options to support her family, she chooses to leave her home and take the job.  Unfortunately Goeun soon realizes that this is not the dream opportunity that she has been promised.  She is held hostage, transported to Indonesia, and is forced to become a Japanese Imperial Army sexual slave. We follow Goeun through this life-altering experience as she befriends fellow slaves (Comfort Women) and they plan their impossible escape.  

Comfort Women is based on the real-life accounts of a few of the approximately 200,000 women who were trafficked into sexual slavery by the Japanese Army from 1930- 1945.  Women and girls as young as 14 were coerced or kidnapped from their homes and forced to service 50 to 100 soldiers a day.  As a result of this treatment, combined with unsafe practices, only 25- 30% of these women survived the war, and those who did live were forever changed.  Comfort Women gives voice to a story that has been silenced far too long.  

During World War II, approximately 200,000 women – and young teenagers – from across Asia were forced into sexual slavery at “comfort stations” for the Imperial Japanese Army. Inspired by testimonies from the women survivors, "COMFORT WOMEN: A New Musical" features a cast of fifty-three Asian & Asian-American actors to tell these stories which are excluded from history books.  The breakdown of the money raised is simple:  

1) $11,000 (34%) to buy Advertisements across NYC, including PR Newswire.

2) $5,500 (17%) to purchase additional Sound and Lighting equipment.

3) $16,000  (49%) to pay some of our cast.

Each audience member will receive a copy of "CAN YOU HEAR US: The Untold Narratives of Comfort Women." A portion of proceeds will go to "House of Sharing," the home for surviving Comfort Women living in South Korea.  Currently, we are in rehearsals, in Manhattan, NY. We're planning for an Off-Broadway Debut at the Theatre of St Clements on July 31st. Every purchased ticket will receive the book, "Can You Hear Us? A collection of interviews with Comfort Women survivors". But we need your help to get us to that next level. 

We launched this campaign to raise money for the Marketing and Promoting of our musical. We want to reach as many people as possible, We feel that this is an important subject that needs to brought into the light. We need your help to get this show out there, for people to see. We have carefully chosen social media marketing campaigns that are focused on interested local audiences. We have designed a timely series of newspaper and magazine ads that will give us the exposure we need. But all of this comes with a price tag. That is why we are asking for your help today.
story_txt:
"Comfort Women: A New Musical" is raising funds to support it's budget.  With your donation, we will be able to pay some of our cast of over 50 actors.  With the funds raised, we will buy more advertising space to help promote and market "Comfort Women: A New Musical."  Set in 1941, Comfort Women takes us to Seoul, Korea, where we meet Goeun, a young woman whose brother is attempting to revolt against the Imperial Japanese Army. Goeun meets a man who promises her a good paying job at a factory in Tokyo.  Feeling like she has no other options to support her family, she chooses to leave her home and take the job.  Unfortunately Goeun soon realizes that this is not the dream opportunity that she has been promised.  She is held hostage, transported to Indonesia, and is forced to become a Japanese Imperial Army sexual slave. We follow Goeun through this life-altering experience as she befriends fellow slaves (Comfort Women) and they plan their impossible escape.  
Comfort Women is based on the real-life accounts of a few of the approximately 200,000 women who were trafficked into sexual slavery by the Japanese Army from 1930- 1945.  Women and girls as young as 14 were coerced or kidnapped from their homes and forced to service 50 to 100 soldiers a day.  As a result of this treatment, combined with unsafe practices, only 25- 30% of these women survived the war, and those who did live were forever changed.  Comfort Women gives voice to a story that has been silenced far too long.  
During World War II, approximately 200,000 women – and young teenagers – from across Asia were forced into sexual slavery at “comfort stations” for the Imperial Japanese Army. Inspired by testimonies from the women survivors, "COMFORT WOMEN: A New Musical" features a cast of fifty-three Asian & Asian-American actors to tell these stories which are excluded from history books.  The breakdown of the money raised is simple:  
1) $11,000 (34%) to buy Advertisements across NYC, including PR Newswire.
2) $5,500 (17%) to purchase additional Sound and Lighting equipment.
3) $16,000  (49%) to pay some of our cast.
Each audience member will receive a copy of "CAN YOU HEAR US: The Untold Narratives of Comfort Women." A portion of proceeds will go to "House of Sharing," the home for surviving Comfort Women living in South Korea.  Currently, we are in rehearsals, in Manhattan, NY. We're planning for an Off-Broadway Debut at the Theatre of St Clements on July 31st. Every purchased ticket will receive the book, "Can You Hear Us? A collection of interviews with Comfort Women survivors". But we need your help to get us to that next level. 
We launched this campaign to raise money for the Marketing and Promoting of our musical. We want to reach as many people as possible, We feel that this is an important subject that needs to brought into the light. We need your help to get this show out there, for people to see. We have carefully chosen social media marketing campaigns that are focused on interested local audiences. We have designed a timely series of newspaper and magazine ads that will give us the exposure we need. But all of this comes with a price tag. That is why we are asking for your help today.

story:
About the Show

Hailed as "one of the year's best new plays" by New YorkTheatre.com, Straight Faced Lies is excited to be an official selection of this year's New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC.)

Grab a plate, sharpen your knives, and join us for an unforgettable Thanksgiving with the Ryans, where family battles are as bitter as the cranberry sauce and the secrets more delicious than the stuffing. 

To be selected to perform in FringeNYC is an esteemed honor, and the biggest step in the show's development process thus far. As the largest performing arts festival in North America, FringeNYC will provide the cast, director and playwright with a one-of-a-kind opportunity to showcase our work to new, diverse audiences. Your tax-deductible contribution through this campaign or our contribution page  is vital to our success.

Production Budget Breakdown

Like most things in New York City, mounting a show is very expensive, yet our total budget of $8,000 enables this production of Straight Faced Lies to best serve the material without being extravagant.

Our incredible actors, who all have significant theater credits, are generously working for far below what they are worth, yet still need to be paid fairly. Similarly, a great stage manager and production crew are vital to keep things running smoothly. Participation and insurance fees quickly add up, while excellent marketing (including postcards and program ads) will ensure that Straight Faced Lies stands out among Fringe's many other shows.

Cast and Creative

MAN DOWN Productions is proud to introduce our extraordinary cast (pictured from left to right): Geraldine Librandi (HBO: The Sopranos), Curtis Wiley (Off Broadway: Pageant - The Musical), Cindy Marchionda (City Center Encores: The Apple Tree; Joseph Jefferson Award Best Actress in Kiss of the Spider Woman), Jacob Thompson (Olympus Records - FringeNYC), Dana Domenick (Illuminati - Planet Connections Award, Outstanding Lead Actress), and Joey Collins (Broadway: The Glass Menagerie; Off-Broadway: Bug). 

Director Andrew Block received the Ovation and L.A. Drama Critics Circle Awards for Best Director and Best Production for his world premiere production of Small Engine Repair. He has several critically-acclaimed and sold-out productions in FringeNYC, including an extension to the Encore Series at the Lucille Lortel, as well as numerous productions in NYC and regionally, Best Director and Best Play awards in a variety of NY festivals, and a GLAAD Media nomination for Outstanding Theatre. Andrew is also the Manager of Off-Off Broadway Services at Theatre Development Fund (TDF).

Playwright Mark Jason Williams is a multi-award winning playwright and essayist. His plays have been produced in New York City, Chicago, Minneapolis, Washington D.C., and his essays are published by Salon, Out Magazine, Jezebel and the Daily Dot. Mark has a BFA in Dramatic Writing from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. His play, Recovery (also directed by Andrew Block), was an audience favorite in the 2011 New York International Fringe Festival. 

MAN DOWN PRODUCTIONS (Producer) is dedicated to creating continued, collaborative relationships with playwrights, and development of work fresh to the New York Stage. The company was founded by Andrew Block and Steven De Luca in 2014. Man Down's most recent show, Why Bother? An Evening of One Act Comedies, was awarded Outstanding Overall Production at The Planet Connections Theatre Festivity. 

This talented ensemble of artists is sure to make a splash in this year's Fringe, but we need your help to make this production possible.

Thank You!

Straight Faced Lies is a deliciously dark comedy, but also a poignant and timely play about facing painful truths and confronting the ones we love. Thank you for helping us bring this play to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign. Spread the word to your friends and family, and follow us on Twitter @str8facedlies for the latest updates. And, of course, we'd love to see you at the show. Tickets are now on sale on the FringeNYC website.

Straight Faced Lies: a new play by Mark Jason Williams is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Straight Faced Lies: a new play by Mark Jason Williams are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
The Background

Bhawani Bashir Yasir, an alumnus of the National School of Drama in New Delhi, founded the Ensemble Kashmir Theatre Akademi (EKTA) in 1988. Although EKTA could not remain functional after the militant insurgency in 1990, it was re-invigorated in 2004 to re-enforce a new spirit in the theatre movement of Kashmir. Under the aegis of the Ensemble – EKTA School of Drama-&-Repertory was established in March 2006, to pave the way for providing professional training in Theatre Arts to promising young artistes in Kashmir, who are otherwise deprived of avenues to go outside the state. The School awards different short-term and full term courses, including a one year Professional Diploma course and a six-month certificate course in Theatre Arts, under the academic guidance and principles of National School of Drama, New Delhi; admitting 20-25 students every year.

The Dream

EKTA has conceived a dream project to build its own campus that will consist of the following:

  • Proscenium Auditorium: Since Kashmir currently lacks a contemporary proscenium auditorium, the EKTA campus seeks to create a space with the seating capacity for fifteen hundred people, with the required technical facilities for theatre performances.
  • Intimate Theatre Studio: In the basement of the auditorium building, we envision a mini auditorium for music and dance performances and smaller theatre activities/productions.
  • Open-Air theatre: The folk-theatre of Kashmir is legendary and traditionally takes place in open air spaces.
  • Art Gallery/Painting Studio: Since theatre is a multiple composite performance art form we would like to have a gallery space for local and visiting artists to showcase their work and to hold painting workshops for interested participants.
  • Exhibition Hall: The campus would also provide an open hall for multi-purpose exhibition of folk arts & crafts.
  • Heritage Museum: Keeping in view the rich cultural heritage of the Valley, we need a heritage museum within the campus that could house traditional, social, art and cultural belongings of Kashmiri ways of living right -- from the remote rural villages to the urban areas.
  • Open Arena Space: An open arena space to hold theatre festivals and conferences.
  • Residential quarters: Guest rooms and dormitories that are designed to host EKTA’s team and visiting artists. We expect to host individual artists-in-residence and groups from schools/colleges/universities that might be interested in cultural learning programmes.

The Plan

Since the land for this campus has already been pledged by local supporters of EKTA, we would like to begin our work in 2015 with these steps. 

  • Building the compound wall for the site
  • Building the residential quarters
  • Building one large rehearsal space for workshops and performances to occur before the other envisioned spaces are ready for use

It is our goal to complete these steps by December 2016, at which point we will move forward with the construction of the other spaces in EKTA’s Cultural Campus.

The Budget

While we are currently seeking financial support for infrastructural costs, we would like to assure our donors that we are working on different avenues of income so as to assure the sustainability of the EKTA Cultural Campus. In addition to existing support from the Government of India’s Ministry of Culture, which has been providing salary grants for actors and production grants for performances, we are in the process of creating an educational outreach programme.

In this outreach programme, we plan to collaborate with educational organizations toward offering intensive cultural learning workshops and short courses for visiting students. Targeting the growing need for experiential education programmes in international curricula, these workshops and short courses will offer a ‘cultural immersion’ for students of all ages. In addition to these educational outreach programmes being a source of income for EKTA’s sustainability, we also hope that this component to our work will give the world a positive exposure to the true, age-old, and rich civilization of Kashmir.

Given this context, the amount that we are seeking to raise in 2015, toward completing the steps listed above, is 1,25,000 USD.

story:
Short Summary

The Colorado Improv Awards was founded by longtime improvisers, Emily March and Chris Gallegos, when they decided that Colorado needed to recognize and pay tribute to the hard work being done by improvisers across the state. As an improviser, Emily has performed consistently for over 15 years and continues to be a driving force behind many improv groups playing in and around Denver today. Chris Gallegos was one of the founding members of the Denver Improv Festival and the GroupMind Foundation and has been an improviser since 2001, and performs in groups such as the musical improv group SoundBox and Makeshift Shakespeare and produces Radio Voodoo, a monthly, live improvised show.

Chris and Emily produced the inaugural CIA's on a shoestring budget, and it was a great success, but in 2015, they have decided to create an event worthy of the performers being honored. That means moving the awards to the Jones Theater in Denver, a larger and prestigious theater in the Denver performing community.

The change of venue as well as the costs of creating the awards (each award is handcrafted by Emily herself...seriously), fees, costs for promotion and additional staffing, means an increase in the budget that requires your help to fund.

What We Need & What You Get

All of the funds collected will go directly to paying the rental fee of the Jones Theater ($1,100) as well as the cost of the awards (approximately $500), decoration costs, and a stipend for a small, but dedicated staff.

If you are a performer in Denver or Colorado, you understand the impact that being recognized for your work can have on a performer.  Your donation will make it a wonderful and memorable night for improvisers who work hard to entertain the masses.

    The Impact

    The Denver improv scene is relatively new if compared to places like Chicago or New York. However, we are regularly producing top notch improv performers who have gone on to create shows like "Girls Only" and "The Grawlix" and "Governor Jack" all nationally recognized improv groups that originated in Denver.  Most awards and media take note of traditional actors as well as stand up comics, but until now, there has been nothing to honor the work of the very talented improvisers in Colorado.  Your donation can help change that.

      Risks & Challenges

      The Colorado Improv Awards works to not only honor the improv performers working today, but also to recognize those who laid the foundation that helped bring the art to where it is now.  Without your help, it will be very difficult to honor those we enshrine into the Colorado Improv Hall of Fame and to create the kind of event that is worthy of the work being done on stages every night in Colorado

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Please help us by donating and spreading the word about the Colorado Improv Awards. Any amount helps and letting others know can only help our effort.  thank you so much for donating.  Also, if you donate, you will receive a handwritten letter from an improvisers you have adopted.  It will be typed up and printed out and sent to you via email telling you about shows they are performing in that you should probably go see.  Thank you again!

story:
Hello! We are a contemporary dance company based in San Francisco called Tim Rubel Human Shakes, under the direction of Choreographer, Tim Rubel. We are raising money to help fund our exciting new dance work Menace, which will premiere at the San Francisco International Arts Festival May 22-24 2015. This piece will be fiercely danced by Brenda Li, Holly Martin, Svetlana Pivchik and Hannah Westbrook. We are raising money so we can give our dancers, designers and technical staff the salaries they deserve for their hard work, plus give us a little nest egg for the next iteration of this piece. That's right! Although we are premiering Menace this year, we will continue to develop it into a full evening length work, which will be presented at the 2016 San Francisco International Arts Festival.

Producing dance at the professional level is an expensive task. With artist fees, studio rentals, marketing,  costumes, lighting and scenery, it truly takes a village to fund a dance company. That's where you come in. Any help you can offer will have an incredible impact on this project, our company and the communities we serve. No donation is too small (or too large!). Wanna know more about us? Please visit our website at www.humanshakes.com. And check out the rest of this campaign! If we don't already know each other, we're super excited to introduce ourselves and our work to you. If you're already a human shaker, spread the word. Either way, we hope you'll support our campaign and come to our show. May 22-24. Get tickets at www.sfiaf.org.

Here's a little more about Menace. Taking a look at the dirty and less flattering side of humanity, Menace explores the relationship between a predator and it's prey. It asks who do choose to devour and who do we choose to save? And why? These questions will be teased out on stage through high energy dancing, original text and a few live animals. Really. So come check us out and get involved. Thank you so much for your time. We look forward to working with you.

story:
Short Summary

Thank you for your interest in ImmerCity's latest project, a completely immersive re-imaginging of Shakespeare's "MacBeth" featuring an all-female cast of only three. Beneath the roots of an ancient tree, three hooded figures will weave the fate of a great warrior, luring him into a life of murder and tyranny with sweet prophecies. The extraordinary cast blends Shakespeare’s original text with puppetry, violent choreography, and the incredible storytelling Immercity is known for. This design concept combines Norse, Celtic and Greek folklore to create a uniquely mythic world. The audience will bear witness as the sisters weave the winding threads that determine the fate of all humankind. Embedded in this timeless place of powerful sorcery, the audience watch and assist as the three sisters manipulate Macbeth’s life from afar. There will be a live percussive score and elemental magic that uses fire, earth and water as part of the sister’s ominous rituals.

So Why All-Female?

I was frustrated by the lack of strong female roles compared to the number of amazing female actors. It’s not intentionally feminist to cast more women than men, it actually makes for better theatre because you have more choice. I get hundreds of women replying to open casting calls, I rarely get more than ten men.

 The production will premiere for two nights in the gardens at Tymperlys in Colchester. In July it will move to an R&D period in Bruges, followed by a short run at the Heilige Magdalenakerk, a deconsecrated church. After this it will have a London run in the autumn at a TBC venue.

What We Need & What You Get

We need £2,000 in order to pay for rehearsal space and travel during our initial rehearsal period in June, as well as costume/props/set for the production, We also need the funds to cover our trip to Colchester and Bruges, where we have been invited to research the production and perform it. Finally, we need the funds to hire three actors, a fight director, and a musician. Everything is in place - we just need the funds to do it! So, as a thank you for supporting our campaign, here's what you get:

£1- THANK YOU: Yes, for just one pound you will get a personalized thank you on ImmerCity and MSP's social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, and our website). Way to go, you star!

£5 - SPELL (For good, not evil): We will personally create a spell in haiku form that will bring you good fortune, and post it to your social media profiles/e-mail it to you.

£10 - FREE POTION! ImmerCity is hosting several parties and events over the next few months in London and in Bruges, and if you donate £10 you will recieve a free potion, courtesy of the Wyrd sisters. Events are free entry, and you can find out more about them on ImmerCity's website.

£25 - THE MACBETH KIT: In addition to a spell posted to your social media profiles, we will print the spell onto an origami raven and post it to you along with your own thread of life and a poster for the show featuring original artwork by acclaimed calligrapher Brody Neuenschwander.

£50 - FREE TICKET OR DRINKS AND A VIDEO: You can chose: one free ticket to the production in Colchester or Bruges, or a free cocktail at EVERY MacBeth fundraising event throughout the summer. You will also receive a video of ImmerCity's company singing your spell to the tune of your choice.

There rewards are all accumulative - so for instance, if you donate £25 you will also receive a spell posted to your social media page+a thank you online+one free cocktail at any ImmerCity event, and if you donate £50 you will receive the MacBeth kit plus a free ticket/cocktails/video+the kit+spell on social media+a thank you.

If you wish to donate more than £50, please contact ImmerCity directly, as this would make you eligible to enter onto our sponsorship program, which includes year-round perks including free tickets, free drinks, and personal time with the artists.

If you are planning to donate in a foreign currency, please note that we will be charged $25 for each foreign transaction. Please contact Maggie at maggieschroeder@sbcglobal.net if you wish to donate in USD, EUR, or any other non-GBP currency.

If we don't reach our entire funding goal, the money will be spent on the bare minimum - travel, production costs, and hiring the talent - but we will be charged more by Indiegogo!

The Impact

Aside from this massive opportunity to support women in the arts - where female fight directors are consistently paid less than their male counterparts and given fewer opportunities - this project will help to launch ImmerCity as an international company. Travelling to Bruges as part of an international festival will allow us to work with artists from around the world and develop audiences in mainland Europe. Our goal is that by financing this production, we will be able to continue as a company without asking for crowdfunding money again.

We already have a successful track record, having received five star reviews from Everything Theatre and The Upcoming and been dubbed "ingenious" by The Stage (****) and Scots Gay (****). You can see more audience reactions and reviews on our website, and given the number of shows we have produced successfully, we are confident in our ability to produce yet another stand-out show if we can just find the funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can help financially - we've all been there. But you can still provide massive support to our campaign by sharing our crowdfunder and our project on social media, and talking about it to people you know might be interested. You can also purchase tickets to the show (if you buy ahead of time online you get a discount!), or come along to one of our (FREE!) fundraising events. Finally, if you know anyone who would be interested in getting involved with the project, providing free rehearsal space, discounted materials, or perhaps providing a venue in or outside of the UK, please get in touch. We appreciate everything our audiences and friends have done for us so far - just one more push!
story_txt:
Short Summary Thank you for your interest in ImmerCity's latest project, a completely immersive re-imaginging of Shakespeare's "MacBeth" featuring an all-female cast of only three. Beneath the roots of an ancient tree, three hooded figures will weave the fate of a great warrior, luring him into a life of murder and tyranny with sweet prophecies. The extraordinary cast blends Shakespeare’s original text with puppetry, violent choreography, and the incredible storytelling Immercity is known for. This design concept combines Norse, Celtic and Greek folklore to create a uniquely mythic world. The audience will bear witness as the sisters weave the winding threads that determine the fate of all humankind. Embedded in this timeless place of powerful sorcery, the audience watch and assist as the three sisters manipulate Macbeth’s life from afar. There will be a live percussive score and elemental magic that uses fire, earth and water as part of the sister’s ominous rituals.
So Why All-Female?
I was frustrated by the lack of strong female roles compared to the number of amazing female actors. It’s not intentionally feminist to cast more women than men, it actually makes for better theatre because you have more choice. I get hundreds of women replying to open casting calls, I rarely get more than ten men.
 The production will premiere for two nights in the gardens at Tymperlys in Colchester. In July it will move to an R&D period in Bruges, followed by a short run at the Heilige Magdalenakerk, a deconsecrated church. After this it will have a London run in the autumn at a TBC venue.   What We Need & What You Get We need £2,000 in order to pay for rehearsal space and travel during our initial rehearsal period in June, as well as costume/props/set for the production, We also need the funds to cover our trip to Colchester and Bruges, where we have been invited to research the production and perform it. Finally, we need the funds to hire three actors, a fight director, and a musician. Everything is in place - we just need the funds to do it! So, as a thank you for supporting our campaign, here's what you get:
£1- THANK YOU: Yes, for just one pound you will get a personalized thank you on ImmerCity and MSP's social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, and our website). Way to go, you star!
£5 - SPELL (For good, not evil): We will personally create a spell in haiku form that will bring you good fortune, and post it to your social media profiles/e-mail it to you.

If you are planning to donate in a foreign currency, please note that we will be charged $25 for each foreign transaction. Please contact Maggie at maggieschroeder@sbcglobal.net if you wish to donate in USD, EUR, or any other non-GBP currency.

story:
"Did we get the whole story? Take a behind the scenes look at the award winning podcast Serial. This game-changing parody follows an obsessive journalist's experiences with love, ham, and Matthew McConaughey. An untold story told scene by scene." - Olga & Brandi

    SERIAL:  The Parody! is an original sketch show written by us, Olga Elliot & Brandi Bravo, based on the Serial podcast, and with your help it'll be getting its world premiere as part of the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival!!!  We don't have sponsors like Mail "Kimp" to fall back on - we need YOU!  (But we promise, we'll always pronounce your name correctly.)

    Featuring Brandi as an ever-neurotic and lovesick Sarah Koenig and Olga as four different characters (a looney psychic,  a ghostly lawyer, a dingy assistant, and a certain big-name actor) - this show is a wild behind-the-scenes view of what was REALLY going on behind the scenes.  Oh yeah, and we've got a kickass director:  Jessica Kane, writer and co-director on UCB Maude team (212).

    Okay, enough about the show.  Let us tell you why we're doing it.  Earlier this year we were feeling a little powerless.  We found ourselves wondering why the hell there were so few awesome parts out there for women like us?  Olga said she'd give her right arm if she could just play some funny, fun characters in a crazy out-of-control play.  So really, that's why you should donate:  Because if you do, Olga will cut off her right arm.

    Every penny you give us will go to our production costs: lights, costumes, sets, props, rehearsal spaces, marketing and PR, and stipends for our kick-ass cast, crew and producing team.

    Wait...when and where is it?

    We're performing at FringeNYC Venue #8 Theater Under St. Marks - and it's our DREAM venue:) For show dates and times, check out www.SerialParody.com - tickets go on sale on Friday, July 17th!

    Thank you for taking the time to check this campaign out.  Even if you don't donate, we'd love to have you come check out the show:  subscribe for updates on our beautiful website www.serialparody.com , like us on facebook (www.facebook.com/serialparody) and follow us on twitter (www.twitter.com/serialparody) and instagram (www.instagram.com/serialparody).

    We'll see you soon!

    -Olga & Brandi

story:
(En castellano a continuación)

Lajee Center’s 2015 Cultural Advocacy Tour will take place across Basque Country, Madrid, Catalonia, Valencia and Andalusia in June 2015. Nineteen members of the Center - dancers, a photographer and coordinators - will embark on a 3-week tour, performing traditional Dabka dancing, exhibiting their award-winning photography work, screening their films and speaking about all aspects of the Palestinian case.

The Center’s international cultural tours are an important aspect to Lajee’s work. The greatest success of the previous tours is the wide audiences they attracted, outreaching to a variety of people about the Palestinian situation and life, and building and strengthening the solidarity movement internationally. This resulted in more people expressing their support of Lajee’s work and the Palestinian case.

We are calling on any individual, charity, organization, society or group around the world who are able to support us in turning this project into a reality. We are close to realizing this dream and every pound, dollar or euro that can be donated to the project will bring us one step closer.

The organization of this tour is voluntary and therefore no funds will be used to cover salaries or stipends for the coordinators and volunteers.

------------------------------------------------------------

La visita cultural anual del Centro Lajee 2015 tendrá lugar en junio de este año en el País Vasco, Madrid, Cataluña, Valencia y Andalucía. 19 miembros del Centro – bailarines, fotógrafos y coordinadores – tomarán parte en este tour de tres semanas. Durante este tiempo realizarán actuaciones de baile tradicional palestino, expondrán exhibiciones de fotografía, mostrarán cortos documentales y hablarán de la situación en Palestina.

Las visitas culturales son una parte esencial del trabajo que realiza el Centro Lajee. El mayor logro de las visitas de otros años fue la cantidad de gente que atrajeron, informando a una gran variedad de personas sobre la situación que viven en Palestina y sobre su cultura. También ayudan a construir y reforzar los lazos entre los movimientos de solidaridad internacionales. Esto ha resultado en un mayor apoyo al Centro Lajee y a la causa del pueblo palestino.

Con esta campaña hacemos un llamamiento a todas las personas, grupos, organizaciones y asociaciones del mundo para que nos apoyen en hacer de este proyecto una realidad. Estamos muy cerca de este sueño, y todo euro, dólar o libra que se dona nos llevará un paso más cerca a realizarlo.

La organización de este tour es voluntaria y no se utilizará nada de lo recaudado para pagar a coordinadores o voluntarios, la integridad del dinero que se recaude será destinada a financiar los costes de la visita cultural.

story:
Short Summary

About 6 months ago I was accepted into the Atlantic Acting School in New York (founded by David Mamet & William H. Macy) on a full scholarship for three years of full time study. Since the announcement I have been working full-time to prepare myself financially, but three years is a long time - especially when your visa won't allow you to work (legally, that is), so this is my final card I have to play to really give me that extra boost. I leave in a month and a half and ANY amount of assistance would be greatly greatly appreciated.

So, I'd be lying if I told you there was a tangible number that I was aiming for but the truth is that this is all very new to me; I don't know what to expect from New York or the Theatre School... However, all is not lost - my Mum has managed to get a loan from the "trusty" bank of $20,000 as a safety net which I hope not to touch with a ten foot pole (I've been down that road before). My mother, being the angel she is, will do her best to support me with her own finances but that will only go so far. So all donations will go towards her peace of mind - and my ability to eat food.

In all honesty, I have a feeling the next three years is going to be hard. and no amount of day job slavery will fully prepare me for what's to come, but this is my dream. For the last ten years I've dreamed of an opportunity like this one, and I'm asking you to join me. Because at the end of the day, nobody wants to see money get in the way of dreams. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're in the arts as well, you'll find that money (or rather, the lack of it) gets in the way pretty regularly. So no dramas if you can't donate - you can still be a massive help by sharing this page to gather as much support for "Luke's Last Leap" as possible.

And that's all there is to it!

Thankyou!

story:
who we are 

The Gangbusters Theatre Co. were formed in the Autumn of 2001. Since then they have produced twenty-six plays including seminal productions of Balm in Gilead  by Lanford Wilson, Streamers by David Rabe, Talk Radio by Eric Bogosian, All in The Timing by David Ives, Sexual Peversity in Chicago by David Mamet, Night of the Living Dead by Leon Shanglebee and the Vietnam classic Tracers. 
In 2013 Artistic Director and founder Christian Levatino wrote his first play, Sunny Afternoon. It was a huge critical success garnering a Best of Fringe honor before being presented as a World Premiere at the Asylum Theatre in October 2013. Sunny Afternoon ran until February of 2014 and was nominated for over a dozen Los Angeles theatre awards.
In 2015 Levatino's second play King Dick was workshopped at the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival where it once again won a Best of Fringe distinction as well as being nominated for two Best Playwright Awards (The Ezra Buzzington Spirit of the Fringe Award and the O Face Award).


KING DICK the play

The Manson case is in full swing, and we’re knee deep in Vietnam…. and as if that isn't fucked enough, Mercury is in retrograde.

Christmastime, 1970: The King just spent 100 G’s on gifts, and he’s on the run from Graceland. His kata form cannot be topped. He pops pills like peanut butter and banana sandwiches but leaves needles and drugs to the doctors. Underneath it all, his momma’s lesson stays with him – to give to those in need. After a horrifying vision, The King concocts a scheme to offer the leader of the free world his influential voice in exchange for a new symbol of power.

King Dick examines the true events that led Elvis Presley to seek out President Richard Nixon, the only man with more pull than E himself, for a Federal Agent-at-Large badge. He wants to do his part to save the youth from the perils of drugs. The future of our great country depends on The King – Elvis – a man who will buy 40 handguns and 10 Mercedes Benzes without blinking. Will Dick Nixon say yes?

This was the last time anyone would be allowed to cold call the President.

In 90 minutes, King Dick takes you inside the Oval Office to present the most provocative piece of pop culture history you’ve never seen. It’s about our heroes, their true identities, and the only ones who can hurt them at their very core.


what your contribution goes too

The entire $5,000 will be put towards theatre space, rehearsal hours, actor salary, set design, publicity, flyers, programs, etc.
Every dollar counts and they add up fast. We appreciate every American cent you can give.


KING DICK production team

Playwright//Christian Levatino

Director//Leon Shanglebee

Producer//LQ Victor ● Corryn Cummins ● Matt Quinn

Stage Manager//Alyssa Champo

Sound Designer//J Warner 


KING DICK Opens 

Friday, September 4th 2015

@ The Asylum Lab Theatre 

6320 Santa Monica Blvd. 

Los Angeles, Ca 90038

for more information on the gangbusters theatre company go to:

www.gangbusterstheatre.com
